questions.text: Which of the following nerve is related to marked arrow groove?
questions.solution:
The marked arrow is a Radial groove in middle one third of posterior surface of Humerus.

Option wise explanation:

Option B: Ulnar nerve : It is related to posterior surface of medial epicondyle of humerus.

Option D: Axillary nerve : It is related to surgical neck of humerus.

Option C: Median nerve : It is not closely related to the humerus.

Reference: Human Anatomy, B D Chaurasia, Volume 1, 9th edition, Page No. 17.

It is formed by external oblique aponeurosis.
It gives origin to rectus abdominis muscle from its lateral 2/3 parts.
Its medial half form floor of inguinal canal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect for inguinal ligament?
questions.solution:
Inguinal ligament:

  • It is also called as poupart's ligament.
  • It is formed by lower border of external oblique aponeurosis which thickened and folded backwards on itself.
  • It extends from anterior superior iliac spine to pubic tubercle and lies beneath fold of groin.
  • The fascia lata is attached to the lower border.
  • The upper surface gives origin to internal oblique from its lateral two third and to transversus abdominis from its lateral one third and cremaster from its middle part.

Extensions:

  1. The pectineal part of inguinal ligament
  2. The pectineal ligament or ligament of cooper
  3. The reflected part of inguinal ligament

Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and D: are correct statements for inguinal ligament.

Option C: It gives origin to internal oblique from its lateral 2/3 part.

Reference: Human Anatomy, B D Chaurasia, Volume 2, 9th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: All of the following dural venous sinuses forms the confluence of sinuses except
questions.solution:
Confluence of sinuses: is also known as torcular Herophili, or torcula. It is the connecting point of

  • superior sagittal sinus,
  • the straight sinus,
  • the occipital sinus, and
  • the two transverse sinuses.

It drains blood from the brain to the transverse sinuses.

Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C: are sinuses that forms the confluence of sinuses.

Option D: superior petrosal sinus : does not form confluence of sinuses.

Reference: Human Anatomy, B D Chaurasia, Volume 3, 9th edition, Page No 216.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman experienced increasing malaise and a 10-kg weight loss in the last year of her life. She been increasingly obtunded, lapsed into a coma, and died. At autopsy, the liver has the gross appearance shown in the figure. Ingestion of which of the following substances is most likely to have played a role in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
A. Aflatoxin is a hepatotoxin and is the product of the fungus Aspergillus flavus, which grows on moldy cereals.

  • Aflatoxin can be carcinogenic, leading to hepatocellular carcinoma, as shown in the figure.

Incorrect Options:

B. Oysters can concentrate HAV from seawater contaminated with sewage, and eating raw oysters can result in HAV infection.

C. Aspirin has been implicated in causing Reye syndrome in children, which results in extensive microvesicular steatosis.

D. Nitrites have been causally linked with cancers in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Aflatoxin is a hepatotoxin and is the product of the fungus Aspergillus flavus, which grows on moldy cereals.

Aflatoxin can be carcinogenic, leading to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Reference: Robbins & cotran, 10th edition, page no. 869.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient with Parkinsonism was on medication for the same. Later he presented to emergency department with swollen red, tender and very painful feet (as shown in the given figure below). Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Amantadine can Cause ankle edema (reversible) and Livedo reticularis (Pinkish pigmentation of skin in form of meshwork) as shown in the image above.

Livedo reticularis

  • A characteristic side effect due to local release of CAs resulting in postcapillary vasoconstriction is livedo reticularis (bluish discolouration) and edema of ankles.
  • Side effects are accentuated when amantadine is combined with anticholinergics.

Drugs Increasing Dopamine Level at Synapse

  • Amantadine is an antiviral drug that is also useful in Parkinsonism.
  • It increases synaptic dopamine level by increasing presynaptic release and decreasing its reuptake.
  • It also possesses anticholinergic and antiglutaminergic (NMDA blocking) activity.
  • Adverse effects of this drug include nausea, insomnia, ankle edema and livedo reticularis.
  • It is indicated for treatment of dyskinesia associated with chronic levodopa therapy.

Option A, C & D: All other agents are not associated with development of livedo reticularis as side effect

Key Takeaway:

  • Amantadine can Cause ankle edema and Livedo reticularis (Pinkish pigmentation of skin in form of meshwork)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 460

questions.text: A young patient with Addison disease continues to have hyperkalemia despite receiving adequate replacement doses of hydrocortisone (cortisol). Which of the following drug should be added to the treatment regimen to reduce serum potassium levels?
questions.solution:
• Fludrocortisone is approximately 100 times more potent as a mineralocorticoid than is cortisol and is the most potent mineralocorticoid available for clinical use.
  • It acts to increase sodium retention and potassium excretion, thereby lowering serum potassium levels.

Chronic adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease)

  • Hydrocortisone given orally is the most commonly used drug along with adequate salt and water allowance.
  • Some patients who continue to excrete excess Na+ need additional mineralocorticoid: fludrocortisone is added.

Fludrocortisone

A potent mineralocorticoid having some glucocorticoid activity as well, orally active, used for following disorders

  • Replacement therapy in Addison's disease
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia in patients with salt wasting

Option A, C & D: All agents have very weak to nil mineralocorticoid activity hence not preferred here.

Key Takeaway:

  • Fludrocortisone is the most potent mineralocorticoid available for clinical use. It acts to increase sodium retention and potassium excretion, thereby lowering serum potassium levels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 314

choices.text: Kissing and licking of anus by a sexual partner

questions.text: A person of eonism derives pleasure from?
questions.solution:
• Eonism is a practice where individuals derive pleasure or satisfaction from wearing the clothes of the opposite sex. It's not about voyeurism or fetishizing specific items of clothing or sexual practices but about the act of adopting the appearance of the opposite sex.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Kissing and licking of the anus by a sexual partner: This sexual activity, often referred to as anilingus, doesn't have any specific connection to eonism.
  • Option C - Underclothing of a female: Underclothing of a female in eonism isn't about this particular item of clothing. It's about the act of dressing in clothing of the opposite sex as a whole.
  • Option D - Seeing a female undressing: This option describes voyeurism.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Eonism is a practice where individuals derive pleasure or satisfaction from wearing the clothes of the opposite sex.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 432

questions.text: In an epidemiological study null hypothesis came out to be false and rejected. However, in reality, null hypothesis was true. Type of error:
questions.solution:
In epidemiological studies, errors related to hypothesis testing are classified into two main types:

  • Type 1 Error (False Positive): Occurs when the null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected when it is actually true. This means the study suggests an effect or association exists when it does not.
  • Type 2 Error (False Negative): Occurs when the null hypothesis is not rejected when it is actually false. This means the study fails to detect an effect or association that does exist.

Given the situation where the null hypothesis was rejected, but in reality, it was true, this corresponds to a Type 1 Error.

So, the correct answer is: A. Type 1

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In the context of rejecting a true null hypothesis, the relevant error is Type 1 Error.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-09, Page No 168-174.

questions.text: All of the following symptoms and signs are the part of Gradenigo syndrome except?
questions.solution:
When the infection in CSOM goes from mastoid or middle ear upto petrous part of temporal bone it is called as petrositis.

Petrous part of temporal bone is related to 6th cranial nerve as the nerve runs through Dorello canal near petrous apex. It is also related to 5th cranial nerve through Meckel's cave. The air cells of petrous part are connected to Mastoid air cells.

  • Due to involvement of 6th nerve there is diplopia.
  • Due to involvement of ophthalmic part of the 5th nerve there is retrobulbar pain.
  • Due to involvement of mastoid bone there is persistence of ear discharge.

These three symptoms and signs are together called as Gradenigo syndrome. It is characteristic of Petrositis.

Option B - Palatal palsy is seen in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (trotter's triad) and it is not a part of Gradenigo syndrome.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 99.

Small round blue cells with scant cytoplasm and indistinct cell borders

questions.text: A 5-year-old child diagnosed with retinoblastoma undergoes enucleation due to advanced intraocular disease. The histopathological examination of the enucleated eye reveals a retinal mass with extensive calcification, neuroblastic rosettes, and extensive focal necrosis. Given these findings, which of the following histopathological features is most characteristic and essential for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological examination of retinoblastoma commonly reveals:

  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes: These are characteristic rosette formations with a central lumen and are indicative of retinoblastoma. These structures are formed by neuroblastic cells arranged around a central space, resembling the structure of the normal retinal structure but with pathological changes.

Histopathological confirmation of retinoblastoma relies on the identification of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes among other findings.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood. It arises from the immature cells of the retina and can be either hereditary or non-hereditary. Early diagnosis is critical for both vision preservation and survival.

Etiology and Genetics:

  • Genetic basis: Caused by mutations in the RB1 gene located on chromosome 13.
  • Inheritance:
    • Hereditary form (40%): Can be bilateral and multifocal, transmitted in an autosomal dominant manner.
    • Non-hereditary form (60%): Usually unilateral and unifocal, with no family history.

Clinical Features:

  1. Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex):
    • The most common presenting sign, seen in 60% of cases.
    • Parents may notice a white reflection from the child's eye in photographs taken with flash.
  2. Strabismus:
    • Misalignment of the eyes, the second most common presentation (20%).
  3. Other Signs: Decreased vision., Red, painful eye with secondary glaucoma. Hyphema or bleeding in the eye in advanced cases, Proptosis (in cases of orbital extension).

Diagnosis:

  1. Fundoscopy:
    • Direct visualization of a cream-colored, solid, vascular tumor in the retina.
    • Tumor often has areas of calcification.
  2. Imaging:
    • Ultrasound B-scan: Demonstrates a solid intraocular mass with characteristic calcifications.
    • MRI: To assess optic nerve involvement and extraocular extension.
    • CT scan: Rarely used due to radiation exposure, but can show calcification.

Treatment:

  1. Focal Therapies (used in early-stage disease):
    • Laser photocoagulation: Destroys the tumor's blood supply.
    • Cryotherapy: Freezes small tumors.
    • Brachytherapy: Radioactive plaque applied to the tumor.
  2. Systemic Chemotherapy:
    • Used for reducing the tumor size (chemoreduction), particularly in bilateral or advanced cases.
    • Common agents include carboplatin, etoposide, and vincristine.
  3. Intra-arterial Chemotherapy:
  4. Enucleation:
    • Required in advanced, unilateral cases with no vision potential, or when there's a risk of metastasis.
  5. External Beam Radiotherapy:
  6. Intravitreal Chemotherapy:

NOTE: Homer Wright Rosettes:

  • These are less specific but can be observed in some cases. They are rosette formations without a central lumen and are found in the context of neuroblastomas and other neuroblastic tumors.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, pp. 683-689.

questions.text: A 60 year old male diabetic patient presented with complain of Greenish ear discharge since 1 month. On examination Granulation tissue was found at the junction of bony and cartilaginous part of EAC. What will be the next step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history and examination the most probable diagnosis in this case is Malignant otitis externa.

It is an infective and locally invasive condition of EAC caused by pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is most commonly seen in immunocompromised states like diabetes, HIV positive and patients on steroids.

On examination EAC shows greenish discharge, Erythema, granulations, and edema. The patient can have facial nerve paralysis. Cranial nerve 9, 10 and 11 can also get involved.

Management: The first step in diagnosis here is to prove that causative agent is pseudomonas thus Microbial culture of ear secretions is taken first.

This is followed by biopsy from the granulation tissue. MRI and CT scan are useful for mapping of the disease.

It is managed by antipseudomonal antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin, ceftazidime, piperacillin for 3 to 6 weeks. Debridement of necrotic material is done.

Option A - IV antibiotics have more bioavailability than oral antibiotics.

Option C - debridement is started after initiating antibiotics.

Option D - Mastoidectomy is done for middle ear pathologies.

Reference: Disease of ear, nose and throat by PL Dhingra, 8th ed, pg 61

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with complain of dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation, hoarseness and cough. On Barium swallow outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa is seen. All of the following is true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
• Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Zenker's diverticulum.
  • It is most commonly seen in elderly patients. It develops due to neuromuscular incoordination between thyropharyngeal and cricopharyngeal
  • It is a pulsion diverticulum as it develops due to raised intraluminal pressure.
  • Option A - It is a false diverticulum as it does not involve all the layers of the pharyngeal wall. It contains only mucosa.
  • Option B - It is a posterior pouch as it is lying posterior to cervical oesophagus initially.
  • Investigation includes Barium swallow lateral view.
  • Management includes surgical excision of the pouch thus option D is not correct here. Endoscopic stapling diverticulotomy known as Dohlman's procedure is also used.

Image of barium swallow of zenker's diverticulum

Reference: Disease of ear, nose and throat by PL Dhingra, 8th ed, pg 324.

questions.text: PCCs (phaeochromocytoma) and PGLs (paraganglioma) are collectively abbreviated to PPGL. Overall, about 70% of PPGLs are sporadic and the rest occur as part of inherited endocrine tumour syndromes, which include all of the following except____
questions.solution:
The incidence of PCC is about 0.6 in 100000 and 75% are thought to be sporadic. The incidence of sporadic PGL is not known, but is less common than PCC, and the association with hereditary conditions is more common. Overall, about 70% of PPGLs are sporadic and the rest occur as part of inherited endocrine tumour syndromes, which include:

  • Hereditary PPGL syndromes
  • MEN 2
  • Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL)
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)

MEN 1 syndrome includes: (Remember as : MEN 1 : pan(pancreas), par(parathyroid), pit(pituitary))

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery, 28th edition, chapter 57, page 912.

questions.solution:

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 50 per 1000 live births.

  • Neonatal mortality rate = No, of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year
  • In this population, there were 4000 live births (no. of total births - no. of stillbirths).

NMR = (50+150) × 1000/4000 = 100/2 = 50

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Neonatal mortality rate = No, of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year

Reference: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Chapter 9, Page No-643.

questions.text: Which of the following fetal complications is most commonly associated with vacuum-assisted delivery?
questions.solution:
Option A: Brachial plexus injury

Brachial plexus injury is more commonly associated with shoulder dystocia during vaginal delivery rather than vacuum-assisted delivery. This injury occurs due to excessive traction on the baby's head and neck, usually when the shoulders are stuck behind the mother's pubic bone. It is not typically associated with the use of a vacuum extractor.

Option B: Subgaleal hemorrhage

Subgaleal hemorrhage is the most commonly associated complication of vacuum-assisted delivery. It occurs when the emissary veins between the scalp and the periosteum of the skull are torn, leading to bleeding into the subgaleal space. This can be a life-threatening condition due to the potential for significant blood loss. The use of excessive vacuum pressure or multiple attempts can increase the risk of this complication.

Option C: Clavicle fracture

Clavicle fracture is a common injury associated with vaginal delivery, especially in the context of shoulder dystocia, but it is not specifically linked to vacuum-assisted delivery. It occurs due to the pressure exerted on the baby's shoulder during delivery but is less directly related to the use of a vacuum extractor.

Option D: Fetal hypoxia

Fetal hypoxia, a condition where the fetus does not receive adequate oxygen, can occur in any complicated or prolonged delivery scenario, but it is not specifically associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. While vacuum delivery may be performed in response to signs of fetal distress to expedite delivery, it is not the vacuum extraction itself that typically causes hypoxia.

Type: Must know

Topic: Ventouse delivery

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no. 661-663

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is in the second stage of labor. Despite adequate contractions and maternal effort, the fetal head remains at +2 station for an extended period. The fetal heart rate tracing shows non-reassuring patterns, and the decision is made to proceed with an instrumental delivery using forceps to expedite the delivery. The procedure is successful, and a healthy baby is delivered. Which maternal complication is most commonly associated with the use of forceps in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Forceps delivery increases the risk of severe perineal tears, especially third or fourth-degree tears, due to the mechanical forces applied during the procedure to assist in the delivery of the baby.

Following are the common complications of ventouse and forceps delivery:

Explanation:

Option A: Uterine rupture

Uterine rupture is a serious but rare complication typically associated with a history of uterine surgery, such as a previous caesarean section, or with excessive uterine contractions, such as those from oxytocin misuse. It is not commonly associated with forceps delivery, especially in a primigravida without prior uterine surgery or scar.

Option B: Postpartum haemorrhage

Postpartum haemorrhage can occur following any delivery, including those with instrumental assistance, but it is not the most common complication specific to forceps use. While trauma from forceps can contribute to bleeding, postpartum haemorrhage is more commonly due to uterine atony, retained placenta, or coagulopathy, rather than the direct effect of forceps application.

Option C: Third or fourth-degree perineal tears

Third or fourth-degree perineal tears, which involve the anal sphincter complex, are the most common maternal complications associated with forceps delivery. The use of forceps can increase the risk of significant perineal trauma due to the mechanical force exerted on the perineum and surrounding tissues during extraction. Proper technique and protective measures can reduce but not eliminate this risk.

Option D: Deep vein thrombosis

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is not specifically associated with forceps delivery. It is more related to immobility, hypercoagulability, and endothelial damage, which can occur in any postpartum period, regardless of the delivery method. The risk of DVT is not increased specifically by the use of forceps.

Type: Must know

Topic: Forceps delivery

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no. 659

questions.text: Which of the following anti filarial drugs is commonly used in mass drug administration (MDA) programs for lymphatic filariasis?
questions.solution:
Mass Drug Administration (MDA) programs for lymphatic filariasis are public health interventions aimed at reducing the transmission and burden of the disease by administering anti filarial drugs to entire populations living in endemic areas.

Goal: The primary goal of MDA programs for lymphatic filariasis is to interrupt transmission of the parasite by reducing the number of microfilariae circulating in the blood of infected individuals. By treating entire populations, including asymptomatic carriers, MDA aims to lower the overall level of infection and prevent new infections.

  1. Target Population: MDA programs target entire communities or populations residing in endemic areas where lymphatic filariasis is prevalent. This includes both urban and rural areas where the risk of transmission is high.
  2. Drug Administration: The cornerstone of MDA programs is the administration of anti filarial drugs to eligible individuals. The most commonly used drugs include albendazole (an anthelminthic) in combination with either diethylcarbamazine (DEC) or ivermectin, depending on the endemicity of onchocerciasis co-endemicity.
  3. Frequency of Treatment: MDA is typically conducted annually or biannually, depending on the prevalence of lymphatic filariasis in the target area. Multiple rounds of treatment are often required to achieve sustained reductions in infection levels and interrupt transmission.
  4. Distribution Strategy: Anti filarial drugs are distributed to the target population through various distribution channels, including fixed health facilities, community-based distribution points, schools, and mobile outreach teams. Efforts are made to ensure that treatment reaches all eligible individuals, including those who may not regularly access healthcare services.
  5. Global Coordination: MDA programs for lymphatic filariasis are supported by international partnerships and coordinated efforts, including the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF), led by the World Health Organization (WHO) in collaboration with national governments, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), donors, and other stakeholders.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Overall, MDA programs for lymphatic filariasis have been instrumental in reducing the burden of the disease in endemic areas and advancing global efforts towards its elimination as a public health problem. Continued commitment to sustained and comprehensive interventions is crucial for achieving long-term success in controlling and eliminating lymphatic filariasis.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter-5, Page no.315-321

questions.text: Concept of 'Social physician' given by which committee?
questions.solution:
The Bhore Committee, officially known as the Health Survey and Development Committee, was set up by the Government of India in 1943 under the chairmanship of Sir Joseph Bhore. It is one of the most significant committees in the history of healthcare planning in India. Below are key details about the Bhore Committee:

  1. Comprehensive Health Services: Recommended the establishment of a comprehensive, government-funded healthcare system available to all citizens, regardless of their ability to pay.
  2. Primary Health Centers (PHCs): Proposed the establishment of PHCs across rural India to provide essential health services, with one PHC serving 40,000 people.
  3. Three-tier System: Advocated a three-tier structure for health services:
    • Primary Level: PHCs and sub-centers.
    • Secondary Level: District hospitals.
    • Tertiary Level: Specialist hospitals in urban areas.
  4. Focus on Preventive Healthcare: Emphasized preventive and promotive healthcare, particularly in maternal and child health, sanitation, and control of communicable diseases.
  5. Integration of Preventive and Curative Services: Proposed the integration of preventive, curative, and rehabilitative services at all levels of care.
  6. Health Manpower Development: Suggested the creation of new medical and nursing colleges to address the shortage of trained healthcare professionals.
  7. Emphasis on Rural Health: Focused on improving rural healthcare infrastructure to reduce the disparity between urban and rural healthcare services.
  8. Free Medical Care: Recommended free healthcare services for all citizens, removing financial barriers to access.
  9. Community Participation: Encouraged community involvement in healthcare planning and implementation at the local level.
  10. Public Health Education: Stressed the importance of health education for disease prevention and health promotion in the population.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The Bhore Committee's vision continues to influence health policies in India, particularly its emphasis on rural healthcare, primary health services, and preventive medicine. It was a pioneering effort in shaping the healthcare landscape of post-independence India.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-10 ,Page no. 713-715.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of alcohol use presents with chronic abdominal pain radiating to the back and steatorrhea. Abdominal CT scan reveals calcifications in the pancreas. Which of the following investigations is the further management?
questions.solution:
Chronic Pancreatitis - Investigations

  • Early Markers: Serum amylase is elevated in the early stages, but not reliable in chronic pancreatitis.

Imaging:

  • CT scan: Shows calcifications and structural damage.
  • MRI: Outlines gland and damage; calcifications are better seen on CT.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive but less detailed than ERCP.
  • ERCP: Most accurate for evaluating pancreatic ductal anatomy, helps in identifying strictures, dilatation, and stones.
  • Sonographic Findings: Hyperechoic foci, dilated duct, hyperechoic margins, presence of stones, cysts, and lobularity.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Serum amylase: Serum amylase is elevated only in the early stages of pancreatitis and not reliable for chronic cases.

Option B) MRI scan: Although useful in evaluating the overall morphology of the pancreas, it is not as accurate as ERCP for ductal anatomy.

Option C) ERCP: Correct answer. ERCP is the most accurate investigation to elucidate the anatomy of the pancreatic duct. It can also guide therapeutic interventions like stent placement or removal of stones.

Option D) MRCP: MRCP is non-invasive and useful for evaluating biliary and pancreatic ducts, but it lacks the therapeutic capabilities of ERCP.

Key Points:

  • ERCP is the gold standard for evaluating pancreatic duct anatomy and guiding therapeutic decisions.
  • Pancreatic calcifications are a hallmark of chronic pancreatitis on imaging.

Tags:

Topic: Chronic Pancreatitis-investigations

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: NEET PG 2023

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 72, Pages-1280

choices.text: Continue analgesics and re-evaluate after 3 months

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic pancreatitis presents with intractable pain, despite being on opioid analgesics. Imaging reveals a markedly dilated pancreatic duct. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Chronic Pancreatitis - Treatment

Medical Management:

  • Treat Addiction: Help stop alcohol and tobacco use, involve a dependency counsellor.
  • Pain Management: Eliminate obstructive factors, escalate analgesia, consider coeliac axis block for intractable pain.
  • Nutritional Therapy: Low-fat, high-protein diet; pancreatic enzyme supplements with meals; correct vitamin malabsorption.
  • Pharmacological Measures: Steroids (only in autoimmune pancreatitis), micronutrient therapy (e.g., methionine, vitamins C, E, selenium).
  • Endoscopic/Radiological/Surgical Management:
    • Pancreatic Duct Obstruction: Endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy, stent placement (temporary), ERCP for stone removal.
    • Pseudocysts: Drained internally under EUS or percutaneous guidance.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Pancreatic Head Mass: Pancreatoduodenectomy or Beger procedure.
    • Duct Dilation: Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy or Frey procedure.
    • Distal Disease: Distal pancreatectomy.
    • Diffuse Disease: Total pancreatectomy may relieve pain but with significant morbidity.

Explanation:

Option A) Coeliac plexus block: Useful in managing pain, but not first-line when there's a clearly treatable anatomical obstruction like ductal dilatation.

Option B) Endoscopic pancreatic duct stenting: Correct answer. Decompression of an obstructed pancreatic duct can relieve pain in patients with ductal hypertension.

Option C) Total pancreatectomy: it is associated with significant morbidity.

Option D) Continue analgesics: Insufficient in the presence of an obstructed duct.

Key Points:

Surgery is reserved for obstruction relief or complication management. Pancreatic enzyme supplementation and nutritional support are vital.

Tags:

Topic: Chronic Pancreatitis - Treatment

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: NEET PG 2023

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 72, Pages 1278

questions.text: Which form of Giardia lamblia is typically found in the environment and is infectious?
questions.solution:
• The cyst form of Giardia lamblia is the environmentally resistant stage that remains dormant outside the host and is capable of surviving in various conditions.
  • Trophozoites are the active, motile form found in the intestines; they are not infectious as they cannot survive outside the host.
  • Oocysts are the infectious form of other coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium, but are not related to Giardia.
  • Sporocysts are associated with certain protozoa but do not pertain to Giardia lamblia's life cycle.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Trophozoites are the active form but cannot cause infection when outside the host.
  • Option C: Oocysts are specific to different parasites and do not apply to Giardia lamblia.
  • Option D: Sporocysts are linked to other protozoa and are irrelevant in the context of Giardia lamblia.

Key Takeaway:

The cyst form of Giardia lamblia is the infectious stage that is typically found in the environment, highlighting the importance of proper sanitation and hygiene to prevent infection

Reference: CDC - Giardia, CDC Giardia

choices.text: Presence of larvae in the faeces

questions.text: Which of the following is a common diagnostic feature of Trichuris trichiura infection seen in stool samples?
questions.solution:
• The whip-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura are a distinctive feature that can be identified in stool samples, which helps in confirming the diagnosis.
  • These eggs have a characteristic shape with a tapered end, resembling a whip, and are typically around 50-54 micrometers in length.
  • Infections can lead to gastrointestinal symptoms, but the primary diagnostic method is through identifying these eggs in fecal specimens.
  • The presence of larvae in feces is incorrect, as Trichuris trichiura eggs are excreted, not larvae.
  • A high eosinophil count in blood is more indicative of other parasitic infections, such as those caused by Ascaris or Strongyloides.
  • Abnormal liver function tests are not relevant for diagnosing Trichuris trichiura, as this helminth primarily affects the intestines, not the liver.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Incorrect. Trichuris trichiura eggs, not larvae, are observed in stool samples.
  • C) Incorrect. High eosinophil counts can indicate various parasitic infections but are not specific to Trichuris trichiura.
  • D) Incorrect. Liver function tests do not help in diagnosing Trichuris trichiura infections, which primarily affect the gastrointestinal tract.

Key Takeaway:

The whip-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura are a key diagnostic feature found in stool samples, aiding in the identification of this intestinal parasite.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: CDC Guideline Trichuris trichiura

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents for a gynecological examination. A fern-like pattern is observed in her cervical mucus when a sample is spread on a slide. Which hormone is primarily responsible for this characteristic pattern?
questions.solution:
Estrogen:

SOURCE

Ovary (17β-estradiol), placenta (estriol), adipose tissue (estrone via aromatization).

Potency: estradiol > estrone > estriol

Function:

  • Development of internal/external genitalia, breasts, female fat distribution.
  • Growth of follicle, endometrial proliferation, ↑ myometrial excitability.
  • causes the cervical mucus to become thinner, more alkaline, and when cervical mucus affected by estrogen is dried and examined on a slide, it forms a distinct "fern-like" pattern. This phenomenon, known as "ferning",
  • Upregulation of estrogen, LH, and progesterone receptors; feedback inhibition of FSH and LH, then LH surge;
  • stimulation of prolactin secretion
  • Increases transport proteins, SHBG; ↑ HDL; ↓LDL.

In pregnancy

  • 50-fold ↑ in estradiol and estrone
  • 1000-fold ↑ in estriol (indicator of fetal well-being)

Progesterone

SOURCE

  • Corpus luteum, placenta, adrenal cortex, testes.

FUNCTION

  • During luteal phase, prepares uterus for implantation of fertilized egg Stimulation of endometrial glandular
  • secretions and spiral artery development
  • Production of thick cervical mucus → inhibits sperm entry into uterus
  • Prevention of endometrial hyperplasia
  • ↑ body temperature
  • ↓ gonadotropin (LH, FSH) secretion
  • During pregnancy:
    1. Maintenance of endometrial lining and pregnancy
    2. ↓ myometrial excitability → ↓ contraction frequency and intensity
    3. ↓ prolactin action on breasts
  • Option a - Prostaglandin: Prostaglandins play various roles in the body, including regulating inflammation and uterine contractions.
  • Option c - Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH): FSH is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, fig.22-12, page no. 922

choices.text: Acute liver failure due to drug toxicity

questions.text:
A patient with hepatitis presents with:
- High fever
- Severe abdominal pain
- Elevated bilirubin and INR
- Liver biopsy shows massive hepatic necrosis

What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Fulminant hepatitis B is characterized by high fever, severe abdominal pain, and massive hepatic necrosis.

It is a severe form of acute hepatitis B characterized by rapid liver failure and hepatic encephalopathy within 8 weeks of symptom onset in a previously healthy individual.

  • Caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV), which triggers a massive immune-mediated destruction of hepatocytes.
  • Clinical Presentation: Early: Nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
    Rapid progression to hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and multi-organ failure.
  • Pathophysiology: Massive necrosis of hepatocytes due to the host immune response against infected liver cells. Cytokine storm and activation of innate and adaptive immune systems.
  • Diagnostic Features:
    • Elevated serum aminotransferases (AST/ALT).
    • Prolonged prothrombin time (PT) or INR >1.5.
    • Encephalopathy.
    • Serological tests: HBsAg, anti-HBc IgM, HBV DNA (often very high).

Incorrect Options:

  1. Fulminant hepatitis A is rare and typically affects children.
  2. Acute liver failure due to drug toxicity may show different histological features.
  3. Septic shock with liver dysfunction typically shows different clinical and laboratory features.

Key takeaways: Fulminant hepatitis B is characterized by high fever, severe abdominal pain, and massive hepatic necrosis.

Reference: Robbins & cotran, 10th edition, page no. 833.

questions.text: A child born by normal vaginal delivery was brought to paediatric ICU with complaints of repeated attacks of flexion of neck over the trunk and jerks in the hands. EEG shows the presence of hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following anti-epileptic is the drug of choice for this patient for treatment of hypsarrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Infantile spasms are also called Salaam seizures Seen in West syndrome treated with ACTH. Vigabatrin is given if it is associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Option A, B & D: All other drugs are not indicated in infantile spasms.

Key Takeaway:

  • Infantile spasms is also called hypsarrhythmia in which ACTH is the Drug of choice

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 450

questions.text: A 43 year old male patient named Raman with history of epilepsy was on long term anticonvulsant therapy. After several years of treatment with anti-epileptic agent he presented to ophthalmology department with complaints of decrease visual field and visual disturbances. On fundus examination he was diagnosed of having retinal atrophy (as shown in the image below). Which of the following anti-epileptic drug is likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Vigabatrin can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.
  • Vigabatrin is an irreversible inhibitor of GABA transaminase, thus increases GABAergic activity.
  • It is the DOC for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis (ACTH is DOC for all other cases).
  • It can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.

Mnemonic:

Vigabatrin - Visual field defects

Option B: Ethosuximide causes gastrointestinal intolerance, tiredness, mood changes.

Option C: Phenobarbital Long term administration (as needed in epilepsy) may produce additional side effects like-behavioural abnormalities, diminution of intelligence, impairment of learning and memory, hyperactivity in children.

Option D: Levetiracetam can cause CNS adverse effects like irritability, aggression and lability of mood.

Key Takeaway:

  • Vigabatrin can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 448

choices.text: Reduced retropharyngeal space: Children: At C2-7 mm and C6-14 mm. Adult At C 6-22 mm.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient presented with complain of fever, dysphagia, stridor and torticollis. An Acute retropharyngeal abscess was suspected. Which of the following is not a feature of acute retropharyngeal abscess on Xray soft tissue neck lateral view?
questions.solution:
• The retropharyngeal space lies in between buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and Alar fascia posteriorly. Acute retropharyngeal abscess presents with fever dysphagia, stridor and torticollis.
  • On examination there is unilateral paramedian bulge of the posterior pharyngeal wall. It has to be differentiated from a prevertebral abscess in which a midline diffuse bulge of posterior pharyngeal wall is present.
  • Xray soft tissue neck lateral view shows increased prevertebral shadow. Features are as follows:
    1. Widened retropharyngeal space: Children: At C2-7 mm and C6-14 mm. Adult At C 6-22 mm. Thus option A is correct answer.
    2. Reversal of normal cervical lordosis
    3. Air fluid level
    4. Gas

Thus option b, c and d are not correct here.

D\d's of abscess of neck

QUINSY (peritonsillar abscess)

Parapharyngeal abscess

Retropharyngeal abscess

Reference: Disease of ear, nose and throat by PL Dhingra, 8th ed, pg 313.

questions.text: Among women aged 18 to 34 years in a community, height is normally distributed with a mean of 158 cm and a standard deviation of 3cm. what percentage of women will have a height between 155-161 cm?
questions.solution:
To solve this problem, we need to determine the percentage of women whose height falls between 155 cm and 161 cm, given that the heights are normally distributed with a mean of 158 cm and a standard deviation of 3 cm.

2. Interpret the Z-scores:

A Z-score of -1 corresponds to one standard deviation below the mean, and a Z-score of 1 corresponds to one standard deviation above the mean.

3. Determine the percentage:

The percentage of data within one standard deviation of the mean (between Z = -1 and Z = 1) in a normal distribution is approximately 68%.

Therefore, the correct answer is b. 68%

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The percentage of data within one standard deviation of the mean (between Z = -1 and Z = 1) in a normal distribution is approximately 68%.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-05, Page No -101-105.

questions.text: A 65 years old male reports to medical emergency with chest pain. ECG is done which shows significant ST depression in V1-V4 leads. Troponin T is negative. He is admitted and repeat ECG after 6 hours shows ST depression in V1-V6 but troponin T is again negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The spectrum of ischemic heart disease: Important for therapeutic and prognostic decisions:

  • Stable Angina pectoris is presence of chest pain or anginal equivalents after a fixed level of exertion. There is no history of any recent change in nature/severity/duration of pain or these symptoms.
  • Unstable Angina: Unstable angina is defined as 1) occurrence at rest (or with minimal exertion), lasting >10 min; (2) of relatively recent onset (i.e., within the prior 2 weeks); and/or (3) a crescendo pattern, i.e., distinctly more severe, prolonged, or frequent than previous episodes. However, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis (elevated cardiac specific enzymes).
  • Non-ST segment elevation MI- symptoms of unstable Angina + evidence of cardiac myocyte injury (typically as elevated cardiac troponins which are specific for myocyte injury) and Non-ST elevation ECG changes.
  • ST elevation Myocardial infarction: symptoms of unstable Angina + evidence of cardiac myocyte injury (typically as elevated cardiac troponins which are specific for myocyte injury) and ST elevation ECG changes.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 1988

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with weight loss, tremors, heat intolerance, and palpitations for the last 6 months. On examination, she has a diffuse, soft goiter and mild exophthalmos. Her serum TSH is low, and her T3 and T4 levels are elevated. The patient has a family history of autoimmune diseases. She is treated initially with carbimazole. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis

  • Thyrotoxicosis refers to symptoms caused by excessive circulating thyroid hormones.
  • Types of Thyrotoxicosis:

1. Graves' Disease:

  • Most common cause of thyrotoxicosis in younger patients.
  • Diffuse toxic goitre with eye signs (exophthalmos).
  • Autoimmune disorder caused by TSH receptor antibodies (TSH-RAb).
  • Treated with antithyroid drugs, surgery, or radioiodine.

2. Toxic Nodular Goitre:

  • Occurs in middle-aged or elderly patients with a long-standing goitre.
  • Eye signs are uncommon.
  • Can be treated surgically due to its large size or with radioiodine.

3. Toxic Adenoma:

  • Solitary overactive nodule that autonomously produces thyroid hormones.
  • Surgery or radioiodine treatment is effective.

4. Rare causes include iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis and hyperfunctioning thyroid carcinoma.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Toxic nodular goitre usually presents in the elderly with long-standing goitre and minimal eye signs. It is characterized by secondary thyrotoxicosis.

Option B) Correct. Graves' disease is the most common cause of thyrotoxicosis in younger women and is associated with eye signs and a diffuse vascular goitre. It is an autoimmune disorder with circulating TSH receptor antibodies (TSH-RAb).

Option C) Incorrect. A toxic adenoma is a solitary overactive nodule, not associated with diffuse goitre or eye signs.

Option D) Incorrect. Subclinical hyperthyroidism presents with low TSH but normal T3/T4 levels and is usually asymptomatic.

Key Points:

Graves' disease is the most common cause of thyrotoxicosis in younger women and is associated with autoimmune features and eye signs.

Tags:

Topic: Thyrotoxicosis

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: NEET PG 2023; FMGE AUG 2020, JUNE 2021, DEC 2021

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 55, Page 861

questions.text: If a dermoid cyst undergoes malignant change, most common cancer seen is:--
questions.solution:
Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy arising from a dermoid cyst (mature cystic teratoma) of the ovary. Dermoid cysts contain various tissue types, including squamous epithelium, which can undergo malignant transformation. This occurs in approximately 1-2% of cases, predominantly in postmenopausal women. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequent type of cancer to develop from these cysts due to the abundance of squamous epithelial tissue within the cyst.

Option B: Adenocarcinoma

Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that originates from glandular tissue and is not typically associated with dermoid cysts. While adenocarcinomas can arise in other ovarian tumors, they are not the common type of malignancy seen in dermoid cysts undergoing malignant transformation.

Option C: Transitional cell carcinoma

Transitional cell carcinoma, when it arises in the ovary, originates from transitional epithelium similar to that lining the bladder. It is not commonly associated with dermoid cysts, as these cysts lack the transitional cell type that would lead to this cancer.

Option D: Arrhenoblastoma

Arrhenoblastoma is a rare sex cord-stromal tumor that typically secretes androgens and is not associated with dermoid cysts. It arises from ovarian stromal cells rather than the tissues found in dermoid cysts.

Type: Must know

Topic: Dermoid cyst

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 445-446

choices.text: Hyponatremia due to chronic kidney disease

questions.text: A 72 year old male undergoes surgery for benign prostatic hyperplasia. Postoperatively, he develops confusion, headache, nausea, and hypertension. His serum sodium level is found to be 120 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
TURP Syndrome

  • TURP syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), resulting from the absorption of irrigation fluids used during the procedure.
  • Causes:
    • Fluid Absorption: Excessive absorption of hypotonic irrigation fluid into the systemic circulation through open venous sinuses in the prostate.
    • Hyponatremia: Dilutional hyponatremia due to the absorption of large volumes of hypotonic fluid.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Neurological Symptoms: Confusion, headache, restlessness, visual disturbances, seizures, and coma.
    • Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypertension, bradycardia, arrhythmias, and pulmonary edema.
    • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea and vomiting.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Low serum sodium levels (hyponatremia), low serum osmolality.
    • Electrocardiogram (ECG): May show signs of electrolyte imbalances.
  • Management:
    • Fluid Management: Restrict fluid intake; administer diuretics (e.g., furosemide) to manage fluid overload.
    • Correction of Hyponatremia: Administer hypertonic saline (3%) carefully if symptomatic hyponatremia is present; monitor sodium levels closely.
  • Prevention:
    • Use of isotonic glycine as an irrigation fluid instead of hypotonic solutions.
    • Limiting the duration of the TURP procedure.
    • Monitoring fluid input and output carefully during surgery.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hyponatremia due to chronic kidney disease: Incorrect. While chronic kidney disease can cause hyponatremia, the acute onset of neurological symptoms immediately following TURP and the context of fluid absorption points more towards TUR syndrome.

Option B. TUR syndrome: Correct. TUR syndrome is characterized by the absorption of hypotonic irrigation fluid during TURP, leading to hyponatremia, hypervolemia, and subsequent neurological and cardiovascular symptoms.

Option C. Postoperative infection: Incorrect. Postoperative infection can cause fever, chills, and malaise, but it does not typically cause acute hyponatremia and the neurological symptoms described.

Option D. Acute urinary retention: Incorrect. Acute urinary retention would present with suprapubic pain, inability to void, and bladder distension, not with hyponatremia and neurological symptoms.

Key Points:

  • TUR syndrome is characterised by hyponatremia, neurological, and cardiovascular symptoms due to the absorption of irrigation fluid during TURP.

Tags:

Topic: Complications of TURP

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ: FMGE JAN 2022

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 84, Pages 1530

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of endometriosis presents with acute onset of severe right lower abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows a complex adnexal mass with fluid levels and no Doppler flow. What is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
OPTION A. Ovarian Torsion:

Ovarian torsion occurs when an ovary twists around the ligaments that support it, leading to compromised blood flow. This is a gynaecological emergency and presents with acute onset of severe abdominal or pelvic pain, often associated with nausea and vomiting. Ultrasound findings in ovarian torsion typically include an enlarged ovary with a complex mass, lack of Doppler flow (indicating loss of blood supply), and sometimes the presence of free fluid. The history of endometriosis increases the risk of ovarian cyst formation, which can predispose to torsion. Given the acute presentation, severe pain, and ultrasound findings of no Doppler flow, ovarian torsion is the most likely complication.

OPTION B. Ruptured Ectopic Pregnancy:

A ruptured ectopic pregnancy typically presents with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and signs of shock in severe cases. Ultrasound may show an adnexal mass but would typically reveal an empty uterus in a pregnant patient, with free fluid indicating haemorrhage. In this case, there is no mention of a positive pregnancy test or signs consistent with an ectopic pregnancy, and the ultrasound findings of a complex adnexal mass with no Doppler flow are more suggestive of ovarian torsion rather than a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

OPTION C. Haemorrhagic Cyst:

A haemorrhagic cyst is a functional ovarian cyst that bleeds into itself, causing acute pain. Ultrasound may show a complex cystic mass with internal echoes due to blood but usually with preserved blood flow on Doppler. Haemorrhagic cysts are common but do not typically lead to absent Doppler flow. The absence of blood flow on Doppler in this case points more toward ovarian torsion rather than a haemorrhagic cyst.

OPTION D. Tubo-Ovarian Abscess:

A tubo-ovarian abscess is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease and presents with pelvic pain, fever, and an adnexal mass. Ultrasound findings usually include a complex, thick-walled mass with internal debris, and Doppler flow is typically preserved due to the inflammatory process. This condition is less likely in a patient without a history of PID or recent infection and does not fit the acute presentation and ultrasound findings of absent blood flow, making it a less likely diagnosis in this case.

Key takeaway: Ovarian torsion is the most likely complication in this case given the acute onset of severe pain, the history of endometriosis (which increases the risk of ovarian cysts), and the ultrasound findings of a complex adnexal mass with fluid levels and absent Doppler flow, which indicate compromised blood supply to the ovary.

Type: Must know

Topic: Ovarian torsion

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 450

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents for a routine gynecological examination. Her Pap smear shows atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US). She is HPV positive for high-risk strains. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
OPTION A. Repeat Pap smear in 6 months:

Repeating the Pap smear in 6 months is an option for managing ASC-US in women who test negative for high-risk HPV or in those who are in a lower-risk category. However, since this patient is HPV positive for high-risk strains, delaying further investigation could miss a potential high-grade lesion or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). Therefore, repeating the Pap smear is not the best immediate next step for her management.

OPTION B. Colposcopy:

Colposcopy is the next recommended step when a patient has ASC-US on a Pap smear and tests positive for high-risk HPV strains. Colposcopy allows for direct visualization of the cervix and targeted biopsies of any suspicious areas. This is crucial in assessing the extent and severity of any abnormality that may not be fully appreciated through cytology alone. Given her HPV-positive status with high-risk strains, colposcopy is the most appropriate next step to identify or rule out significant cervical lesions.

OPTION C. Immediate LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure):

LEEP is a treatment procedure used to remove abnormal cervical tissue, typically indicated for confirmed high-grade lesions (such as CIN 2 or CIN 3) or early invasive cervical cancer. It is not the initial diagnostic step for ASC-US with high-risk HPV without prior colposcopic evaluation and biopsy confirmation. Immediate LEEP would be premature and overly aggressive at this stage without confirming the presence and extent of a high-grade lesion.

OPTION D. HPV vaccination:

HPV vaccination is recommended for the prevention of HPV infection and is most effective when administered before exposure to HPV (typically in the pre-adolescent years). While vaccination can be beneficial in preventing future infections with other HPV strains, it does not treat existing infections or the cellular changes they have caused. In a patient who is already HPV positive with high-risk strains and has abnormal cytology, vaccination is not an appropriate management step for the current issue.

Key takeaway: Colposcopy is the recommended next step for managing ASC-US in the presence of high-risk HPV strains. It allows for a detailed examination of the cervix and biopsy of any suspicious areas, helping to rule out or confirm high-grade cervical lesions that may require treatment.

Type: Must know

Topic: CIN

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 415

questions.text: What is the Declaration of Oslo related to?
questions.solution:
In 1970, the World Medical Association adopted a resolution on therapeutic abortion known as the Declaration of Oslo.

Other options:

  • Option A - Declaration of Tokyo: Related to human torture and other degradation.
  • Option C - Declaration of Helsinki: Concerned with human experimentation.
  • Option D - Declaration of Malta: Related to hunger strikes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- therapeutic abortion known as the Declaration of Oslo.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 400

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is told about the benefits and complications of hysterectomy and she agrees to the procedure. What kind of consent is this?
questions.solution:
This kind of consent is informed consent since the patient has been made aware of the benefits and complications and has agreed to the procedure.

Informed consent is one given by the patient after understanding the nature of the condition, proposed treatment, outcomes of the recommended treatment, alternative options to treatment, and the risks and benefits involved. The patient can accept or reject the procedure. This is also called the rule of full disclosure.

Consent refers to a voluntary agreement, compliance, or permission. It can be expressed or implied

Implied consent (option B) is that which is not written or expressly stated. It is implied that the patient is giving consent to examination in a general sense. For example, when a patient visits the hospital with an illness, it implies that he has given consent to a physical examination to find out the nature of his illness.

Expressed consent can be oral or written and refers to consent in which the terms are clearly stated in distinct and explicit language.

Opt-out (Option C) refers to a patient's refusal of the procedure, test, or treatment. It is the physician's duty to disclose the risks or consequences of refusal adequately and appropriately to the patient.

Passive consent (Option D) is not commonly described. However, in regard to research, it refers to parents signing and returning a form if they do not want to allow their child to participate in research.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Informed consent is one given by the patient after understanding the nature of the condition, proposed treatment, outcomes of the recommended treatment, alternative options to treatment, and the risks and benefits involved. The patient can accept or reject the procedure. This is also called the rule of full disclosure.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 51

questions.text: Multifocal atrial tachycardia is associated with which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Multifocal AT (MAT) is characterized by a rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.
  • Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves and the atrial rate is slower.
  • It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.
  • Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Electrical cardioversion is ineffective.
  • The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem are used to slow the atrial and ventricular rate.
  • Amiodarone is also effective for management of MAT.
  • The associated risk of thromboembolism in MAT remains unclear but is not considered to be the same as atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 1901

Murmur of aortic regurgitation with aortic stenosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a continuous murmur?
questions.solution:
• Continuous murmur- is produced when blood flow persists between two cardiac chambers or blood vessels across systole and diastole. The murmurs typically begin in systole, envelop the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.

Causes include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm with creation of aortic right atrial fistula
  • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Cervical venous hum
  • Mammary souffle

If we take example of aortic regurgitation with aortic stenosis then There is ejection systolic murmur with early diastolic murmur (or holodiastolic) murmur. S2 is audible.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 1822

questions.text: Height of a group of 50 boys aged 15 years was 140+/- 15 cm and of 20 girls aged 15 years was 135+/- 6 cm. The most appropriate test used to measure significance of the difference in height is :
questions.solution:
To measure the significance of the difference in height between two independent groups (boys and girls), the most appropriate test is the unpaired t-test (also known as the independent samples t-test.

This test compares the means of two independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them.

So, the correct answer is: B. Unpaired t test

Here is the information about usage of each statistical test:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- This test compares the means of two independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them

questions.text: Which of the following is a common symptom of yellow fever?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of yellow fever can vary from mild to severe, and it typically occurs in two phases: the acute phase and the toxic phase. 

  • It's important to note that not all individuals infected with yellow fever will progress to the toxic phase, and the severity of the disease can vary widely.
  • Some individuals may experience only mild symptoms resembling a flu-like illness, while others may develop severe and potentially life-threatening complications.
  • Prompt medical evaluation and supportive care are essential for managing severe cases of yellow fever.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Vaccination against yellow fever is the most effective preventive measure for individuals residing in or traveling to areas where the disease is endemic.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. Park,27th Edition, Chapter -5, Page no.327

questions.text: Which of the following animals serves as the primary reservoir for Japanese encephalitis virus?
questions.solution:
Birds, particularly wading birds like herons and egrets, serve as the primary reservoir for the Japanese encephalitis virus. Pigs are also important amplifying hosts, but birds are the primary reservoir in maintaining the virus in nature. Mosquitoes, mainly of the Culex species, transmit the virus between animals and humans.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The primary reservoir for Japanese Encephalitis is birds and pigs are the amplifier.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. Park,27th Edition, Chapter -5 , Page no.356

questions.text: Cardiomyopathy developing during last trimester and first 6 months after pregnancy is called as?
questions.solution:
• Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is defined as heart failure during the last trimester or within the first 6 months after pregnancy, while pregnancy associated cardiomyopathy is defined as new onset heart failure within first 6 months of pregnancy.
  • Risk factors for PPCM include are increased maternal age, increased parity, twin pregnancy, malnutrition, use of tocolytic therapy for premature labor, and preeclampsia or toxemia of pregnancy.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 1963

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with recurrent episodes of pancreatitis undergoes an MRCP, revealing that the majority of the pancreatic secretions drain through the minor papilla. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancreas Divisum

  • Failure of the embryological ventral and dorsal parts of the pancreas to fuse, causing drainage mainly through the minor papilla.
  • Incidence: Found in 5-10% of cases during autopsy or imaging (ERCP, MRCP); higher in patients with recurrent pancreatitis (25-50%).
  • Clinical Presentation: Recurrent acute pancreatitis, chronic pancreatitis, or pancreatic pain.
  • Diagnosis: MRCP, EUS, or ERCP (sometimes secretin-stimulated).
  • Treatment: Endoscopic sphincterotomy or surgical intervention (sphincteroplasty, pancreatico jejunostomy) in symptomatic patients.

Explanation:

Option A) Annular pancreas: A rare congenital anomaly where the pancreas forms a ring around the duodenum.

Option B) Pancreas divisum: Correct. It is a congenital condition where the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts fail to fuse, causing the majority of secretions to drain through the minor papilla. This can lead to recurrent pancreatitis.

Option C) Cystic fibrosis: A genetic disorder affecting multiple organs, including the pancreas, leading to thick secretions, but it doesn't specifically cause altered drainage patterns.

Option D) Congenital pancreatic cyst: These are cystic lesions present at birth, typically asymptomatic, and unrelated to the abnormal drainage described in this scenario.

Key Points:

  • Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly associated with recurrent pancreatitis. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with MRCP or ERCP.

Tags:

Topic: Pancreas divisum

questions.text: Which uterine incision is preferred for a caesarean section to reduce the risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies?
questions.solution:
Option A: Classical incision

A classical incision is a vertical incision made in the upper part of the uterus. This type of incision is associated with a higher risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies due to the involvement of the more contractile upper uterine segment. It is generally reserved for specific situations, such as when rapid delivery is needed or when there are anatomical issues that prevent a lower segment approach.

Option B: Lower vertical incision

A lower vertical incision is made vertically in the lower segment of the uterus. While it has a lower risk of rupture compared to a classical incision, it still poses a higher risk of uterine rupture in subsequent pregnancies compared to the low transverse incision. It is used when access to the lower segment is limited, but it is not the preferred choice if reducing the risk of rupture is a priority.

Option C: Low transverse incision

A low transverse incision, made horizontally across the lower uterine segment, is the preferred incision for caesarean sections to minimize the risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies. This incision type is associated with the lowest risk of rupture because it is made in the less contractile and more fibrous lower segment of the uterus, allowing for better healing and stronger scar formation. It is the most common and safest incision used in caesarean deliveries.

Option D: T-shaped incision

A T-shaped incision combines a transverse incision in the lower uterine segment with a vertical incision extending upward. This type of incision is associated with a significantly increased risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies due to the combination of vertical and transverse incisions. It is typically used in cases where there is difficulty delivering the baby or when additional space is needed, but it is not preferred if reducing rupture risk is the goal.

Type: Must know

Topic: Uterine rupture

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 1485

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines with aura seeks contraceptive advice. She is concerned about the risk of stroke with hormonal contraceptives. Which contraceptive method is most suitable for her considering her condition?
questions.solution:
Women with migraines with aura are at increased risk of stroke with combined hormonal contraceptives. The copper IUD is a suitable non-hormonal option.

Option A: Combined oral contraceptive pills

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin. For women with a history of migraines with aura, COCs are generally contraindicated due to an increased risk of stroke. Estrogen can exacerbate migraines with aura and further increase the risk of cerebrovascular events. Thus, COCs are not recommended for women with this condition.

Option B: Progestin-only pills

Progestin-only pills (POPs) do not contain estrogen, making them a safer option for women with a history of migraines with aura compared to combined hormonal methods. While they are a better choice than COCs, they still have a slightly lower efficacy and can be less convenient. Nevertheless, they are generally considered acceptable for women with a history of migraines without aura but should be used with caution for those with migraines with aura.

Option C: Contraceptive implant

The contraceptive implant is a long-acting reversible contraceptive that releases a low dose of progestin. It is generally safe for women with a history of migraines with aura because it does not contain estrogen. However, some women may experience migraines as a side effect. Therefore, while it is a better option than combined hormonal methods, it still requires careful consideration.

Option D: Copper IUD

The copper intrauterine device (IUD) is a non-hormonal contraceptive method. It does not affect estrogen or progestin levels and therefore does not influence the risk of stroke related to hormonal contraception. It is highly effective and does not exacerbate migraines, making it the most suitable contraceptive option for women with a history of migraines with aura.

For a 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines with aura, the copper IUD is the most suitable contraceptive method. It avoids the risks associated with hormonal contraceptives and does not affect the risk of stroke, making it a safe and effective choice for women with this condition.

Type: Must know

Topic: Contraindications to Combined Hormonal Contraception

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 2248

choices.text: Initiate IV antibiotics and schedule for drainage
Start oral antibiotics and follow up in 48 hours

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with severe pelvic pain and fever after recently undergoing an IUD insertion. On examination, she has marked cervical motion tenderness and adnexal fullness. Ultrasound confirms a large tubo-ovarian abscess. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A. Initiate IV antibiotics and schedule for drainage

For a large tubo-ovarian abscess, the initial management includes broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics to control the infection. Additionally, drainage of the abscess is crucial, as large abscesses may not respond adequately to antibiotics alone. Percutaneous drainage is often preferred initially over surgical intervention, but if the abscess does not improve or complications arise, surgery may be considered.

Option B. Start oral antibiotics and follow up in 48 hours

Oral antibiotics are typically used for less severe PID cases or as a step-down therapy from IV antibiotics. In the presence of a large tubo-ovarian abscess, which indicates a more severe infection, oral antibiotics alone are inadequate. Immediate intervention with IV antibiotics and drainage is necessary.

Option C. Immediate laparoscopic surgery

While laparoscopy may be necessary in cases of severe or complicated PID, including persistent or worsening abscesses, it is generally considered after initial medical management and percutaneous drainage if required. Immediate surgery is not the first-line approach unless there is evidence of severe complications or failure of other treatments.

Option D. Reassurance and pain control

Reassurance and pain control are not sufficient for managing a large tubo-ovarian abscess. This condition requires aggressive treatment, including antibiotics and drainage, to prevent further complications and manage the infection effectively.

In summary, the most appropriate initial management for a patient with a large tubo-ovarian abscess is to initiate IV antibiotics and schedule for percutaneous drainage, addressing both the infection and the abscess.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Management of acute PID

Reference: www.ncbi.com

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION C) Laparoscopy:

Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis. It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs. Through laparoscopy, the surgeon can see endometrial implants, adhesions, and other lesions characteristic of endometriosis. It also allows for biopsies, which can confirm the diagnosis histologically. Additionally, therapeutic interventions can be performed during the procedure, such as excising or ablating the endometrial lesions.

OPTION A) Ultrasound:

Ultrasound, particularly transvaginal ultrasound, is commonly used to evaluate pelvic pain and masses. It can identify endometriomas (ovarian cysts associated with endometriosis) but is generally not effective for diagnosing superficial endometriosis or lesions outside the ovaries. It is not considered a reliable method for definitive diagnosis because it cannot visualize small or deep infiltrating lesions.

OPTION B) MRI:

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is more sensitive than ultrasound for detecting deep infiltrating endometriosis and can provide detailed images of the pelvic anatomy. However, it is still not the gold standard because it may miss superficial or small lesions. MRI is typically used as an adjunct to assess the extent of disease, especially in complex cases or when surgery planning is needed.

OPTION D) CT Scan:

CT Scan (Computed Tomography) is not typically used for diagnosing endometriosis because it has limited sensitivity in detecting pelvic endometriosis and detailed structures of the reproductive organs. It may incidentally show larger masses like endometriomas, but it lacks the resolution and specificity needed for diagnosing or assessing the extent of endometriosis.

Key takeaway: Laparoscopy provides a direct view of the pelvic cavity, allowing for definitive diagnosis and treatment, making it the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis.

Type: Must know

Topic: Diagnosis of endometriosis

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 180

It is directly correlated with life expectancy
It indicates overall healthcare access and quality for infants
