questions.text: Why is Infant Mortality Rate considered an important indicator of a population's health?
questions.solution:
Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered an important indicator of a population's health due to several key reasons:

  1. Reflects Healthcare Access and Quality: IMR reflects the accessibility and quality of healthcare services available to pregnant women, infants, and newborns within a population. Low IMR suggests that adequate prenatal care, skilled attendance at birth, postnatal care, and healthcare interventions for infants are available and utilized effectively.
  2. Sensitivity to Social Determinants of Health: IMR is influenced by a wide range of social, economic, and environmental factors, known as social determinants of health. These include maternal education, socioeconomic status, access to clean water and sanitation, nutrition, housing conditions, and access to healthcare services. A high IMR often indicates underlying social inequities and disparities in health outcomes.
  3. Early Warning Indicator: IMR serves as an early warning indicator of broader health problems within a population. High IMR may signal deficiencies in healthcare infrastructure, inadequate healthcare financing, poor maternal and child nutrition, limited access to preventive and curative healthcare services, and other systemic challenges.
  4. Population Health Status: IMR is closely linked to overall population health status. A decline in IMR over time indicates improvements in maternal and child health, healthcare delivery systems, public health interventions, and socioeconomic conditions.
  5. Impact on Life Expectancy: High IMR can significantly impact life expectancy at birth and overall population health outcomes. Reductions in IMR contribute to increases in life expectancy and overall improvements in population health indicators.
  6. Global Development Goals: IMR is a key indicator used to monitor progress towards global development goals, such as the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). SDG 3 aims to ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all ages, with a specific target to reduce IMR to fewer than 25 deaths per 1,000 live births by 2030.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: IMR provides valuable insights into the overall health status, healthcare access, and quality of care within a population. Monitoring IMR is essential for identifying health disparities, informing health policies and interventions, and tracking progress towards improving maternal and child health outcomes.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. Park,27th Edition, Chapter -09, Page no.605

questions.text: A four-year-old girl fell down while playing was brought by her parents to hospital. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. An x-ray showed a spiral fracture of the right femur. Which of the following programs can provide support services to this child and prevent further such incidents?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards child abuse. The INSPIRE strategy was introduced to eliminate such violence against children and also provide support services.

  • INSPIRE is a set of seven evidence-based strategies for countries and communities working to eliminate violence against children. Launched in 2016, INSPIRE serves as a technical package and handbook for selecting, implementing and monitoring effective policies, programmes, and services to prevent and respond to violence against children.
  • INSPIRE is an acronym, with each letter representing a strategy
    • I for the implementation and enforcement of laws
    • N for norms and values
    • S for safe environments
    • P for parent and caregiver support
    • I for income and economic strengthening
    • R for response and support services; and
    • E for education and life skills.
  • There are also two crosscutting activities (multisectoral action and coordination, and monitoring and evaluation) that connects the seven strategies and monitor the extent of their implementation and impact on the problem.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The INSPIRE strategy was introduced to eliminate such violence against children and also provide support services.

Reference: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 9, Page No-671.

questions.text: The flow volume curve which is shown below is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Flow volume curves:

Explanation:

  • Flow Volume Curve Characteristics:
    • The curve displays expiratory and inspiratory loops, with the expiratory loop scooped out in cases of airway disease.
  • Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD):
    • Scooping of the curve occurs due to:
      • Loss of elastic recoil in lung parenchyma.
      • Increased airway resistance at lower lung volumes, leading to significant airflow reduction.
  • Comparison with Other Conditions:
    • Pulmonary Fibrosis: Shows a restrictive pattern with a reduced overall lung volume but a normal flow rate, not scooped.
    • Fixed Intrathoracic Obstruction: Presents with a flattened curve during expiration, affecting peak flow rates but not producing a classic scoop.
    • Fixed Extrathoracic Obstruction: Typically leads to a similar flat expiratory loop, not characteristic of the scooped appearance seen in COPD.

Also try to remember the airflow curves of different disease:

Why Not Others:

  • B) Pulmonary fibrosis: This condition shows a restrictive pattern, leading to a normal shape of the flow-volume curve, not scooped.
  • C) Fixed intrathoracic obstruction: This results in a flattened expiratory curve, unlike the characteristic scoop of COPD.
  • D) Fixed extrathoracic obstruction: Similar to intrathoracic obstruction, this does not display the characteristic scooping seen in COPD.

Key Takeaways:

  • The scooped appearance of the flow-volume curve is a hallmark of chronic obstructive airway disease (COPD).
  • Understanding different flow volume curves aids in differentiating between obstructive and restrictive lung diseases.
  • Recognizing these patterns is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management in pulmonary medicine.

Topic- Pulmonary function test

Type : Must Know

Difficulty: high

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal Medicine 21st edition page no 2135

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding adipocere formation?
questions.solution:
Preservation by saponification:

Adipocere formation, also known as "grave wax," is a process where body fat turns into a waxy substance due to saponification.

This process involves the hydrolysis of fats in the body by bacteria, leading to the formation of a soapy, wax-like substance that helps in the preservation of the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - High temperature needed:

Adipocere formation generally occurs in a cool, moist environment. High temperatures are not conducive to this process; rather, the process is enhanced in cooler conditions which slow down decomposition and support the saponification process.

Option C - Cool and dry climate needed:

While a cool climate can favor adipocere formation, a dry climate is not ideal.

Adipocere formation requires moisture to facilitate the saponification process. Therefore, a cool and moist environment is more conducive to adipocere formation.

Option D - Occurs within minutes to hours:

Adipocere formation is a relatively slow process that can take several weeks to months to develop fully, not minutes to hours.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Adipocere formation involves the conversion of body fat into a waxy substance via saponification, which is a preservation process that occurs over time in cool and moist conditions.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 171

questions.text: A patient presents after a motor vehicle accident with suspected bladder injury. Cystography shown. What type of bladder injury is this?
questions.solution:
Bladder Trauma: Intraperitoneal vs. Extraperitoneal

  • Extraperitoneal Rupture: Commonly caused by pelvic fractures, with contrast leakage around the bladder in the pelvic cavity.
  • Intraperitoneal Rupture: Typically caused by a direct blow to a full bladder, showing contrast in the peritoneal cavity.
  • Diagnosis: Cystography is the imaging modality of choice.
  • Management: Extraperitoneal injuries usually managed conservatively; intraperitoneal injuries require surgical repair.

Key Points:

  • Extraperitoneal rupture shows contrast confined to the pelvic area.
  • Intraperitoneal rupture requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman undergoes a normal vaginal delivery at 39 weeks of gestation. Shortly after delivery, she experiences heavy vaginal bleeding and is diagnosed with postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony. In her medical history, it is noted that she has chronic hypertension, which has been well controlled throughout her pregnancy. Which uterotonic agent should be avoided in this patient due to her hypertensive condition?
questions.solution:
Methylergonovine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension or preeclampsia because it can cause significant vasoconstriction, which may worsen hypertension and increase the risk of complications such as stroke or seizures.

List of drugs used for treatment of PPH:

Option A: Oxytocin

Oxytocin is the first-line uterotonic agent used for the prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to its ability to effectively induce uterine contractions. It has minimal cardiovascular side effects and is safe for use in patients with hypertension. Therefore, oxytocin can be safely administered to this patient.

Option B: Misoprostol

  • Explanation: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog used as a uterotonic to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It is safe for use in patients with hypertension because it does not significantly affect blood pressure. Misoprostol is a suitable option for this patient.

Option C: Carboprost

Carboprost is a prostaglandin analog used to treat postpartum hemorrhage; however, it can cause bronchospasm and should be used with caution in patients with asthma. While it can cause mild elevations in blood pressure, it is not strictly contraindicated in hypertensive patients but should be used cautiously.

Option D: Methylergonovine

Methylergonovine, an ergot alkaloid, is a potent uterotonic agent that can cause significant vasoconstriction and elevate blood pressure. It is contraindicated in patients with hypertensive disorders, including chronic hypertension, preeclampsia, and eclampsia, due to the risk of hypertensive crisis. Thus, methylergonovine should be avoided in this patient due to her hypertensive condition.

Type: Must know

Topic: Drugs in management of PPH

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Page no. 578

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis?
questions.solution:
Amsel criteria for Bacterial vaginosis includes:

Option A: Fishy odor

A fishy odor is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, especially noticeable after adding potassium hydroxide (KOH) to the vaginal discharge, known as the whiff test. This odor is due to the production of amines by anaerobic bacteria overgrowing in the vaginal environment.

Option B: Clue cells on microscopy

Clue cells are a key diagnostic feature of bacterial vaginosis. They are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, giving them a stippled appearance under the microscope. The presence of clue cells is one of Amsel's criteria for diagnosing BV.

Option C: Thick, white cottage cheese-like discharge

Thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge is characteristic of a yeast infection (candidiasis), not bacterial vaginosis. BV typically presents with a thin, gray, homogenous discharge. This option is the correct answer because it does not describe a feature of bacterial vaginosis.

Option D: pH > 4.5

A vaginal pH greater than 4.5 is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis, indicating a disruption of the normal acidic environment due to the overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria. This elevated pH is one of the diagnostic criteria for BV.

Type: Must know

Topic: Bacterial vaginosis

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page no. 60

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia for the past two years. She has been trying to conceive from the last year without success. On pelvic examination, there is tenderness in the posterior fornix, and a fixed retroverted uterus is noted. An ultrasound reveals ovarian cyst with ground-glass appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION B. Endometriosis:

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, commonly affecting the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and the pelvic peritoneum. Symptoms include chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility, which match the patient's presentation. A fixed retroverted uterus and tenderness in the posterior fornix are also clinical signs associated with endometriosis. The "ground-glass" appearance of ovarian cysts on ultrasound is characteristic of endometriomas, which are cysts formed from endometrial tissue within the ovary. Given these symptoms and findings, endometriosis is the most likely diagnosis.

OPTION A. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

PCOS is characterized by irregular menstrual cycles, hyperandrogenism (such as acne or hirsutism), and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. While it can be associated with infertility, PCOS does not typically cause chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia (painful intercourse), or a fixed retroverted uterus. The ovarian cysts in PCOS usually appear as multiple small follicles arranged peripherally ("string of pearls" appearance) rather than a "ground-glass" appearance. Therefore, PCOS is unlikely to be the correct diagnosis for this patient.

OPTION C. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID):

PID is an infection of the upper genital tract, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, and adjacent pelvic structures, usually caused by sexually transmitted infections. Symptoms include pelvic pain, fever, abnormal vaginal discharge, and tenderness during pelvic examination. However, PID does not cause the characteristic "ground-glass" appearance of ovarian cysts seen on ultrasound. A fixed retroverted uterus is also less specific to PID.

OPTION D. Ovarian Cancer:

Ovarian cancer can present with nonspecific symptoms such as abdominal distension, pelvic pain, and changes in bowel habits, and can also be associated with adnexal masses on examination. However, ovarian cancer does not usually present with the chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia described in this case. The "ground-glass" appearance on ultrasound is not typical for ovarian cancer but is instead characteristic of endometriomas associated with endometriosis.

Key takeaway: The patient's chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, infertility, examination findings of a fixed retroverted uterus, and the ultrasound finding of a "ground-glass" appearance of an ovarian cyst strongly suggest endometriosis, particularly the presence of an endometrioma.

Type: Must know

Topic: Endometriosis

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 178-180

choices.text: Photo screening - This method is useful for initial screening in young children but may not provide accurate measurements for specific refractive errors like astigmatism.
Subjective Refraction - Suitable for older children who can communicate their visual experience, but may not be effective in young children with difficulty providing consistent feedback
Retinoscopy - An objective method to estimate refractive errors, including astigmatism, without requiring subjective feedback from the child
Autorefraction - Provides an automated estimate of refractive error, but might be less accurate in very young children or those with significant astigmatism

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents for a routine eye exam. The child has difficulty seeing distant objects clearly and complains of headaches after prolonged reading. During the refraction test, subjective responses are inconsistent, and retinoscopy shows a significant amount of astigmatism. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial method for assessing this child's refractive error?
questions.solution:
• Retinoscopy is the most appropriate initial method for assessing refractive errors in a young child. It is an objective technique that measures the light reflex from the retina to estimate refractive error, including astigmatism, without relying on the child's subjective responses.
  • Photo screening is useful for initial screenings but lacks specificity for detailed refractive error assessment.
  • Subjective Refraction requires the child to provide feedback on lens choices, which can be challenging for younger children or those with inconsistent responses.
  • Autorefraction provides automated measurements but may not always be as accurate in young children with significant astigmatism or other complex refractive issues.

Methods of Refraction:

  • Subjective Refraction: Typically used in older children who can provide feedback on lens choices.
    • Techniques: Using phoropter or trial frame and lenses to determine the most accurate prescription.
  • Objective Refraction:
    • Retinoscopy: Measures the light reflex from the retina to estimate the refractive error.
    • Autorefraction: Automated device that provides an estimate of refractive error.

Reference: Kanski, J.J., Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Chapter on refraction, pp. 62-73.

questions.text: Which fungus is primarily responsible for causing Tinea Nigra?
questions.solution:
• Malassezia furfur: Associated with conditions like dandruff and tinea versicolor, but not responsible for Tinea Nigra.
  • Pityrosporum ovale: A synonym for Malassezia furfur, also not involved in Tinea Nigra.
  • Hortaea werneckii: The correct pathogen responsible for Tinea Nigra, characterized by dark, painless skin lesions on the palms or soles.
  • Candida albicans: A yeast commonly linked to candidiasis, not involved in Tinea Nigra.

Why Not Others:

  • a) Malassezia furfur: Involved in other skin conditions, not Tinea Nigra.
  • b) Pityrosporum ovale: Synonym for Malassezia furfur, hence irrelevant to Tinea Nigra.
  • d) Candida albicans: Related to different fungal infections, specifically candidiasis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tinea Nigra is caused by Hortaea werneckii.
  • Identifying the causative agent is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. Chapter 8: Tinea Nigra 145

choices.text: Antibiotic therapy reduces occurrence of Nephritis
Immunosuppressants are to be given if crescents are seen in biopsy

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
• Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis primarily occurs after skin or throat infections caused by nephritogenic strains of streptococci.
  • Antibiotic therapy does not reduce the risk of nephritis; it only helps to eliminate the active infection.
  • Immunosuppressive therapy is not indicated, even in the presence of crescents on biopsy.
  • Prognosis is typically better in children than in the elderly.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Antibiotics do not prevent the development of nephritis.
  • Option B: Immunosuppressants are not used, even with crescents.
  • Option C: Prognosis is better in children compared to the elderly.

Key Takeaways:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is immune-mediated and typically follows streptococcal infections.
  • Antibiotics treat the infection, but they don't prevent nephritis; immunosuppressants are not indicated.
  • Prognosis is worse in the elderly.

Topic: Glomerulonephritis

Type: Good to Know

Difficulty: Moderate

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 233

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with painless jaundice, pruritus, dark urine, and pale stools. He reports unintentional weight loss and recent onset of diabetes without a family history or obesity. On examination, he is icteric with a palpable gallbladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Head Tumours

  • Common Presentation: Painless jaundice, pruritus, dark urine, pale stools, and recent-onset diabetes in individuals over 50 without family history or obesity.
  • Important Signs: Courvoisier sign (painless, palpable gallbladder) suggests a non-stone obstruction, usually neoplastic.
  • Advanced Presentation: Weight loss, epigastric discomfort, and vague abdominal symptoms. Back pain indicates possible retroperitoneal infiltration.
  • Risk Factor: New-onset diabetes, especially in older patients, may be an early indicator of pancreatic cancer.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical presentation, supported by imaging such as CT or MRI, and biopsy.

Option A) Incorrect. Chronic pancreatitis typically presents with epigastric pain and a history of alcohol use or gallstones but lacks painless jaundice and recent-onset diabetes.

Option B) Incorrect. While ampullary carcinoma can present with jaundice, it is less commonly associated with a palpable gallbladder or recent-onset diabetes.

Option C) Correct. Painless jaundice, recent-onset diabetes, and a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier sign) are classic signs of pancreatic head carcinoma.

Option D) Incorrect. Gallstones may cause jaundice but are typically associated with colicky pain and not with a Courvoisier sign.

Key Points:

Painless jaundice is a hallmark of pancreatic head carcinoma.

Tags:

Topic: Pancreatic Head Tumours

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: FMGE AUG 2020

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 72, Pages -1281

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of muscle pain, cramping, and weakness in her legs. Her symptoms started shortly after starting a new medication for the management of hyperlip idemia. Laboratory results are positive for an elevated serum creatine phosphokinase. After further discussion, the patient reveals that she consumes grapefruit juice on daily basis. Which of the following drugs most likely caused this patient presentation?
questions.solution:
Adverse drug reactions of statins

  • Gastrointestinal complaints
  • Headache
  • Rashes and sleep disturbances
  • Rise in serum transaminase (Monitoring of liver function is recommended)
  • Muscle aches are the commonest (10%) side effect. Rise in creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels occurs infrequently.
  • Myopathy & rhabdomyolysis is the only serious reaction (rare)
  • Myopathy and liver injury is more common when nicotinic acid/gemfibrozil or CYP3A4 inhibitor-ketoconazole/ grape fruit juice/ erythromycin/ cyclosporine/HIV protease inhibitor is given concurrently.

Fenofibrate interferes the least with statin uptake/metabolism and should be preferred for combining with them.

Option A: No specific adverse effect, except reversible hepatic dysfunction and rarely myositis has been noted with ezetimibe.

Option B: Epigastric distress, loose motions. Skin rashes, body ache, eosinophilia, impotence, headache and blurred vision. Gemfibrozil + statin increases risk of myopathy and they should not be combined

Option C: Nicotinic acid is a cutaneous vasodilator: marked flushing, heat and itching (especially in the blush area) occur after every dose.

  • Dyspepsia is very common; vomiting and diarrhoea
  • Dryness and hyperpigmentation of skin
  • Liver dysfunction and jaundice.

Key takeaway:

  • Muscle aches are the commonest (10%) side effect. Rise in creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels occurs infrequently.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 686

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman undergoes a mastectomy for a palpable breast mass. Histopathological examination reveals:
Small, uniform cells infiltrating the breast parenchyma
Absence of glandular architecture
Presence of signet ring cells
Loss of E-cadherin
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells infiltrating the breast parenchyma, absence of glandular architecture, and presence of signet ring cells.

  • Loss of E-cadherin is also characteristic of lobular carcinoma.

Histopathology:

  • Single-file pattern of invasive tumor cells, lacking the formation of duct-like structures.
  • Cells are usually small and uniform, with loss of E-cadherin expression (a key diagnostic marker differentiating it from invasive ductal carcinoma)

A. Invasive ductal carcinoma typically shows glandular architecture and is often positive for E-cadherin.

C. Ductal carcinoma in situ is a non-invasive lesion and does not show infiltration of the breast parenchyma.

D. Lobular carcinoma in situ is a non-invasive lesion and does not show signet ring cells.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells infiltrating the breast parenchyma, absence of glandular architecture, and presence of signet ring cells.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1052.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins is encoded by a bacteriophage and is associated with bacterial infection?
questions.solution:
1. Diphtheria toxin: Encoded by bacteriophage in Corynebacterium diphtheriae, causes diphtheria by blocking protein synthesis.
  2. Cholera toxin: Produced by Vibrio cholerae, encoded by a bacteriophage, leads to severe diarrhoea by increasing cAMP.
  3. Botulinum toxin C and D: Produced by Clostridium botulinum, bacteriophage-encoded, causes flaccid paralysis by blocking acetylcholine release.
  4. Verocytotoxin (Shiga toxin): Found in Shigella dysenteriae and E. coli, encoded by a bacteriophage, causes haemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).
  5. Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins A and C: Bacteriophage-encoded toxins in Streptococcus pyogenes, linked to toxic shock syndrome and scarlet fever.
  6. Tetanus toxin: Produced by Clostridium tetani, leads to spastic paralysis but not bacteriophage-encoded.

KEY TAKE AWAY: Bacteriophage-encoded toxins include a variety of important toxins produced by different bacteria, which can contribute to the pathogenicity of bacterial infections.

Tags: good to know

Reference: Sastry, A. S., & Bhat, S. K. (2022). Review of Microbiology & Immunology (With DVD) (4th ed.). Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers. Chapter: (Bacteriophage and Toxins), Page no. 41.

questions.text: Which diagnostic method is particularly useful for identifying sub-clinical lesions of Malassezia infections?
questions.solution:
• Wood's Lamp Examination is effective in identifying sub-clinical lesions by revealing fluorescence in affected areas, particularly in cases of pityriasis versicolor caused by Malassezia.
  • The fluorescence observed under the Wood's Lamp can highlight scaly lesions that are not easily noticeable, making it a crucial tool for early detection.
  • Histopathological Examination, while confirming diagnosis by identifying fungal elements in tissue, may not effectively visualize subtle or sub-clinical lesions.
  • PCR Fingerprinting is primarily employed for species identification and epidemiological studies; it is not designed for visualizing sub-clinical lesions.
  • Lymphocyte Blastogenesis assesses immune response to infections but does not provide a direct method for visualizing or diagnosing lesions.

Why Not Others:

  • b) Histopathological Examination: Useful for confirming a diagnosis but may miss sub-clinical manifestations that Wood's Lamp can detect.
  • c) PCR Fingerprinting: Not focused on visualizing lesions; it serves a different diagnostic purpose related to species identification.
  • d) Lymphocyte Blastogenesis: Measures immune response but does not visualize lesions, making it unsuitable for this context.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wood's Lamp Examination is a valuable tool for identifying both clinical and sub-clinical lesions of Malassezia infections.
  • This method enhances the detection of infections that might otherwise remain unnoticed, aiding in timely diagnosis and treatment.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. Chapter 7: Malasseziosis 135

questions.text: HCV is associated with:
questions.solution:
Chronic HCV infection triggers an abnormal immune response, leading to the production of cryoglobulins (immunoglobulin complexes that precipitate in cold temperatures).

The immune complexes deposit in blood vessels, causing vasculitis and resulting in tissue damage.

Clinical Features:

  • Palpable purpura: Skin rash caused by small vessel vasculitis.
  • Arthralgia: Joint pain, especially in the hands and knees.
  • Peripheral neuropathy: Numbness, tingling, or weakness in the extremities.
  • Glomerulonephritis: Kidney inflammation leading to proteinuria, hematuria, and sometimes renal failure.
  • Fatigue: Generalized weakness and tiredness.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon: Fingers and toes turn white or blue in response to cold or stress.

Laboratory Findings:

  • Cryoglobulins: Detected in the blood.
  • Low complement levels: Especially low C4.
  • Positive rheumatoid factor (RF): Often present due to immune activation.
  • HCV RNA: Detectable in most cases since chronic HCV infection is the cause
  • Management -Antivirals against Hep C , corticosteroids, rituximab , plasmapheresis, etc

A) Anti LKM - 1 antibody - Incorrect. Anti-LKM-1 antibodies are associated with autoimmune hepatitis, not HCV.

B) Scleroderma - Incorrect. Scleroderma is an autoimmune disorder not specifically linked to HCV.

C) Cryoglobulinemia - Correct. HCV infection is associated with the production of cryoglobulins, leading to cryoglobulinemia.

D) Polyarteritis nodosa - Incorrect. Although HCV can be associated with various vasculitis, polyarteritis nodosa is less commonly associated compared to cryoglobulinemia.

Key Takeaway: HCV is notably associated with cryoglobulinemia.

TIPS AND TRICK Hepatitis C-Associated Cryoglobulinemia:

"COLD PALMS":

  • Cryoglobulins.
  • Outbreak of purpura.
  • Low complement levels (C4).
  • Disease of the kidneys (glomerulonephritis).
  • Palpable purpura.
  • Arthralgia.
  • Liver involvement (Hepatitis C).
  • Monoclonal or polyclonal cryoglobulins.
  • Systemic symptoms like fatigue and neuropathy.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hepatitis C and Related Conditions. CDC Hepatitis C and Related Conditions

questions.text: Examination of a suspicious stain shows the following finding. The test is?
questions.solution:
• The Barberios test is used for the detection of semen and is characterized by the formation of yellow, needle-shaped crystals when a stain is treated with certain reagents. This test is specific for identifying seminal fluid.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Florence test:
    • The Florence test detects the presence of blood by forming yellow, needle-shaped crystals. However, in practice, it's often referred to as the Florence Reaction, which is not commonly used to identify semen.
  • Option C - Teichmann test:
    • The Teichman test is also used for blood detection but is characterized by the formation of rhomboid-shaped crystals, not needle-shaped ones.
  • Option D - Takayama test:
    • The Takayama test detects blood and forms pink or reddish-brown crystals, not yellow needle-shaped crystals.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-The Barberios test is used for the detection of semen and is characterized by the formation of yellow, needle-shaped crystals when a stain is treated with certain reagents. This test is specific for identifying seminal fluid.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 434

choices.text: Topical antiglaucoma medications should be initiated immediately without considering the reduction of steroid use
Discontinuing or reducing the use of corticosteroids should be the first step in management, and IOP should be closely monitored
Steroid-induced glaucoma is typically irreversible, and surgical intervention should be considered as the first-line treatment
The patient's IOP should be managed solely with systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors without altering the corticosteroid regimen

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of asthma has been using topical corticosteroids for the past 6 months to manage their condition. During a routine ophthalmic examination, the patient is found to have an elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) of 26 mmHg. The ophthalmologist suspects steroid-induced glaucoma. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Correct Answer Overview: Discontinuing or reducing the corticosteroid use is crucial in managing steroid-induced glaucoma. This approach addresses the root cause of the elevated IOP. Regular monitoring of intraocular pressure (IOP) is essential to assess the effectiveness of the intervention and adjust treatment as necessary.
  • Option A: Initiating topical antiglaucoma medications is a part of the management but should follow the reduction or discontinuation of corticosteroid use. The primary step is to address the source of IOP elevation.
  • Option C: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not necessarily irreversible. While some cases may require surgical intervention if medical management fails, the primary focus should be on managing the condition through reduction of steroid use and monitoring.
  • Option D: Systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be used, but they are not the first-line treatment. The corticosteroid regimen should be reviewed and adjusted to effectively manage IOP.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Pages 421-423.

choices.text: MYOC gene: Involved in the development of congenital glaucoma due to its role in trabecular meshwork regulation
CYP1B1 gene: Commonly associated with Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG) due to its influence on aqueous humor production
GLC1A gene: Encodes for the myocilin protein, which is associated with POAG by affecting aqueous humor outflow
OPTN gene: Known for its role in POAG by influencing retinal ganglion cell survival and affecting intraocular pressure regulation

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a family history of Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG) is undergoing genetic testing. The results reveal mutations in several genes. Which of the following genes is correctly matched with its role in the pathogenesis of POAG?
questions.solution:
• Correct Answer Overview: OPTN gene: Known for its role in POAG by influencing retinal ganglion cell survival and affecting intraocular pressure regulation. The OPTN (optineurin) gene plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of POAG by affecting retinal ganglion cell function and survival, which is critical for the development of glaucoma.
  • Option A: MYOC gene is indeed associated with POAG, but it is more related to trabecular meshwork regulation rather than congenital glaucoma.
  • Option B: CYP1B1 gene is associated with congenital glaucoma rather than POAG.
  • Option C: GLC1A gene does not encode for myocilin; it is associated with the MYOC gene that encodes myocilin. Myocilin mutations are linked to POAG, but the GLC1A gene is not specifically involved.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology 9th Edition, Pages 346-347

questions.text: Alpha Antitrypsin deficiency is most commonly associated with which type of emphysema?
questions.solution:
• Emphysema is classified into distinct pathologic types, which include centrilobular, pan lobular, and Para septal. Centrilobular emphysema, the type most frequently associated with cigarette smoking, is characterized by enlarged air spaces found (initially) in association with respiratory bronchioles. Centrilobular emphysema is usually most prominent in the upper lobes and superior segments of lower lobes and is often quite focal. Pan lobular emphysema refers to abnormally large air spaces evenly distributed within and across acinar units.
  • Pan lobular emphysema is commonly observed in patients with α1AT deficiency, which has a predilection for the lower lobes. Para septal emphysema occurs in 10-15% of cases and is distributed along the pleural margins with relative sparing of the lung core or central regions. It is commonly associated with significant airway inflammation and with centrilobular emphysema.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2178

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Vitamin B12 deficiency?
questions.solution:
The important causes of Vitamin B12 deficiency include

  • Malabsorption
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Intestinal causes
  • Intestinal stagnant loop syndrome: jejunal diverticulosis, ileocolic fistula, anatomic blind loop, intestinal stricture, etc.
  • Ileal resection and Crohn's disease
  • Selective malabsorption with proteinuria
  • Tropical sprue
  • Transcobalamin II deficiency
  • Fish tapeworm

Also know type of autoantibodies in pernicious anemia:

  • Type 1 antibody: blocking antibody which prevents the binding of combination of cobalamin and intrinsic factor\
  • Type 2 antibody: prevents attachment of IF to ileal mucosa

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 771

questions.text: Shock Index is defined as?
questions.solution:
Shock Index is defined as the HR/systolic blood pressure (SBP) with a normal SI being 0.5-0.7. An elevated SI (>0.9) has been proposed to be a more sensitive indicator of transfusion requirement and of patients with critical bleeding among those with hypovolemic (haemorrhagic) shock than either HR or BP alone.

Modified shock index is defined as HR/Mean arterial pressure(MAP).

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2238

choices.text: TCBS (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salt Sucrose) Agar

questions.text: Which medium is specifically used for the isolation of Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Option B , C and D are incorrect

TCBS Agar (Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose Agar)

Purpose:
TCBS Agar is specifically designed to isolate Vibrio cholerae and other Vibrio species.

Key Features:

  • Selectivity: The high bile salt concentration in TCBS agar inhibits the growth of non-Vibrio bacteria.
  • Sucrose Fermentation Test: Vibrio cholerae ferments sucrose, producing acid and causing the pH indicator in the medium to change colour.

Colony Appearance:

  • Vibrio cholerae forms yellow colonies on TCBS agar due to sucrose fermentation, distinguishing it from other Vibrio species that may appear green or blue.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • MacConkey Agar(B) is used for Gram-negative bacteria but is not specific for Vibrio cholerae.
  • Cetrimide Agar(C) is selective for Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Mannitol Salt Agar(D) is used for Staphylococcus aureus.

Tags: neet 2021

Reference: Shastri A. Review of Microbiology and Immunology. 3rd Edition. Chapter: (General Bacteriology), Page no. 25.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with chronic respiratory disease and steatorrhea. His mother mentions that he tastes "salty" when kissed. Sweat chloride levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Genetics: Autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7, leading to abnormal chloride movement across cell membranes.
  • Systems Affected:
    • Lungs (chronic respiratory disease)
    • intestines (meconium ileus)
    • pancreas (exocrine insufficiency)
    • liver (cirrhosis and portal hypertension).
  • Diagnosis: Sweat test showing sodium and chloride levels above 90 mmol/L confirms diagnosis.
  • Pancreatic Involvement: Pancreatic duct blockage leads to replacement of the exocrine pancreas, causing pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • Treatment: Pulmonary physiotherapy, antibiotics, pancreatic enzyme replacement, and low-fat diet.

Option A) Pancreatic insufficiency: Incorrect. Although pancreatic insufficiency is common in cystic fibrosis, it is not a standalone diagnosis. It is a consequence of CF, not the primary disease.

Option B) Cystic fibrosis: Correct. CF is a genetic disorder characterized by elevated sweat chloride levels, chronic respiratory disease, and pancreatic insufficiency leading to steatorrhea.

Option C) Meconium ileus: Incorrect. Meconium ileus can occur in newborns with cystic fibrosis but is not the diagnosis in this chronic case.

Option D) Portal hypertension: Incorrect. Portal hypertension causes gastrointestinal and vascular issues but does not present with respiratory symptoms or steatorrhea.

Key Points:

Sweat chloride levels above 90 mmol/L are diagnostic of cystic fibrosis. Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency results in fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

Tags:

Topic :Cystic fibrosis

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: NEET PG 2023; INICET NOV 2023; INICET MAY 2024

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 72, page no. -1267

questions.text: 27 weeks of gestation with congenital anomalies. Whose presence is not required for authorization of MTP?
questions.solution:
• A lawyer's presence is not required for the authorization of a Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) for congenital anomalies. The primary requirement is the involvement of a medical team with specific specialists.
  • The lawyer's role typically comes into play in legal proceedings or when there are legal challenges, but not in the medical decision-making process for MTP.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Obstetrician:

Required: An obstetrician is essential for evaluating and managing the medical aspects of the pregnancy, including assessing the viability and risks involved with the continuation or termination of the pregnancy.

  • Option C - Pediatrician:

Required: A pediatrician's input is crucial when congenital anomalies are involved, as they provide insight into the nature and severity of the anomalies, which helps in making informed decisions about the MTP.

  • Option D - Sonologist:

Required: A sonologist, who performs and interprets ultrasound scans, plays a critical role in diagnosing congenital anomalies and assessing the gestational age of the fetus. This information is vital for decision-making regarding MTP.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The authorization process for MTP involves medical professionals such as obstetricians, pediatricians, and sonologists, but does not require a lawyer's presence.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 401

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of bronchiectasis predominantly involving middle lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
• Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection: This is the primary cause of bronchiectasis in the middle lobe, leading to localized damage and dilation of the bronchi.
  • Congenital Immunodeficiency: While it can lead to bronchiectasis, it does not specifically predominate in the middle lobe.
  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: This condition typically affects lung parenchyma rather than causing localized bronchiectasis in the middle lobe.
  • Predominant involvement of lobes:
    • Lower lobe: Scleroderma (due to recurrent aspiration).
    • Middle lobe: MAC infection.
    • Upper lobe: Post-radiation.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Congenital Immunodeficiency: Not primarily associated with the middle lobe.
  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: Does not cause bronchiectasis localized to the middle lobe.
  • All of the above: Incorrect as MAC is the only condition specifically linked to the middle lobe.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mycobacterium avium complex is the primary cause of middle lobe bronchiectasis.
  • Other conditions like congenital immunodeficiency and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis are not specific to this lobe.

Topic: Bronchiectasis

Type: Must Know

Difficulty: High

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal Medicine 21st edition page no 2173

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a long history of severe type 2 diabetes had been taking multiple daily injections of insulin, including an insulin glargine preparation. Which of the following sets of properties (Given in the table below) best describes the time course of effects of this preparation?
questions.solution:
• Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analogue that was designed to provide a broad plasma concentration plateau.
  • It has an onset of action of 1 to 4 hours, achieves a maximum effect after 4 to 6 hours, and can maintain this effect for over 24 hours.
  • It is usually given once daily to provide basal levels of insulin.

Option A : SemiLente insulin Shows this type of pharmacokinetic.

Option B & C : These pharmacokinetic data matches with short acting insulin like lispro, aspart and glulisine.

Key Takeaway

  • Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analogue, it has an onset of action of 1 to 4 hours, achieves a maximum effect after 4 to 6 hours, and can maintain this effect for over 24 hours.

Tags:

  • Insulin glargine
  • Good to know
  • Neet 2020 l Fmge Aug 2020

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 285

questions.text: A 15 year old girl with asthma precipitated by seasonal pollens is receiving prophylactic twice-monthly injections of a monoclonal antibody. Which of the following mediators of asthma is antagonized by this drug?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely taking omalizumab, a monoclonal antibody that inactivates immunoglobulin E and thereby prevents allergic asthma attacks.

Omalizumab

  • It is a humanized monoclonal antibody against IgE.
  • Administered via subcutaneous route. It Neutralizes free IgE in circulation without activating mast cells and other inflammatory cells.
  • In severe extrinsic asthma, it reduces exacerbations and steroid requirements. It's Reserved for resistant asthma patients with positive skin tests or raised IgE levels who require frequent hospitalization.

Option B: Montelukast Acts via Blocking Leukotriene C4.

Option C: Cetrizine, Fexofenadine & Loratidine etc drugs acts via blocking Histamine action.

Option D: Cyclosporine acts via Blocking Production of IL-2.

Key Takeaway:

  • Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against circulating IgE and is indicated to prevent the attack of bronchial asthma in patients not responding to combination of long acting β2 agonist and a high dose of inhalational steroid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 251

choices.text: Conjunctival cysts due to chronic irritation
Bitot's spots secondary to vitamin A deficiency
Pterygium with conjunctival growth extending onto the cornea

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a history of poor night vision, excessive dryness, and irritation in both eyes. On examination, the child has white, triangular patches of thickened, keratinized epithelium located on the conjunctiva of the bulbar conjunctiva. The patches are typically located temporally and appear to be associated with underlying conjunctival inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis and the primary cause of these ocular findings?
questions.solution:
Bitot's spots are specific signs of vitamin A deficiency. These spots are characterized by white, triangular patches of thickened, keratinized epithelium on the conjunctiva. They are typically located temporally and are indicative of underlying dryness and keratinization due to insufficient vitamin A.

Conjunctival cysts can appear as white or translucent lesions but are not associated with the characteristic triangular shape or the underlying vitamin deficiency.

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) presents with conjunctival papillae and may cause discomfort, but VKC is usually associated with seasonal allergies rather than vitamin deficiencies.

Pterygium is characterized by a growth of conjunctival tissue extending onto the cornea and is usually associated with chronic UV exposure, not vitamin A deficiency.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, pp. 108-109.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of severe acute pancreatitis four weeks ago. He now reports persistent abdominal discomfort and early satiety. A CT scan reveals a well-defined fluid collection adjacent to the pancreas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A pancreatic pseudocyst is a collection of pancreatic juice enclosed by a wall of fibrous or granulation tissue, typically arising after an episode of acute pancreatitis or trauma.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with persistent abdominal pain, discomfort, early satiety, or even a palpable mass. More than half of pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic duct.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scan typically shows a well-circumscribed fluid collection adjacent to the pancreas.
  • Differential: Must differentiate from other cystic lesions like cystic neoplasms. EUS with fluid aspiration for CEA levels and cytology helps differentiate.
  • Complications: Pseudocysts can rupture, become infected, or cause obstruction of adjacent structures. Larger pseudocysts (>6 cm) are less likely to resolve spontaneously and may require intervention.

Management:

  • Most pseudocysts resolve spontaneously.
  • Intervention: Required if the pseudocyst persists beyond 12 weeks, causes symptoms, or complications develop.
  • Surgical drainage: Most definitive, with low recurrence rates.

Option A) Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC) typically occurs in the early stages of acute pancreatitis (within the first week), whereas a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more to form.

Option B) Pancreatic abscesses are rare and usually present with signs of infection such as fever, rather than just discomfort and early satiety.

Option C) Correct. A pancreatic pseudocyst is a fluid collection that develops after an episode of acute pancreatitis, usually more than 4 weeks later, and is defined by a well-formed wall of granulation or fibrous tissue.

Option D) Solid pseudopapillary neoplasms are rare pancreatic tumors and are unlikely in this clinical scenario.

Key Points: A pseudocyst requires more than 4 weeks to form after an acute pancreatitis episode.

Tags:

Topic: Pancreatic Pseudocyst

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: FMGE JUNE 2021; INICET NOV 2022

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 72, Pages 1277

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which Mycobacterium tuberculosis achieves resistance to first-line antitubercular drugs such as isoniazid?
questions.solution:
• Mutation in the katG gene is the primary mechanism for isoniazid resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This gene encodes the catalase-peroxidase enzyme, which is responsible for activating isoniazid. Mutations in katG lead to a loss of enzyme function, rendering the drug ineffective.
  • Mutation in the rpoB gene is related to resistance against rifampicin, not isoniazid. Thus, while significant in its own right, it does not contribute to the resistance mechanism of isoniazid.
  • Overexpression of efflux pumps can play a role in drug resistance for some bacteria; however, it is not the primary mechanism for isoniazid resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The katG mutation is more directly involved in the resistance process.
  • Altered ribosomal RNA is linked to resistance against aminoglycosides and other antibiotic classes but is not relevant to isoniazid resistance, which is specifically tied to katG mutations.

Why Not Others:

  • Mutation in the rpoB gene does not affect isoniazid and is exclusively related to rifampicin resistance, highlighting its irrelevance to this question.
  • Overexpression of efflux pumps may contribute to general antibiotic resistance but is not the key factor in isoniazid resistance, making it less applicable here.
  • Altered ribosomal RNA pertains to different antibiotic resistance mechanisms and is not involved in isoniazid resistance mechanisms in Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Key Takeaway:
Mutations in the katG gene are a major mechanism by which Mycobacterium tuberculosis develops resistance to isoniazid, a crucial first-line drug in tuberculosis treatment. Understanding this mechanism is vital for developing effective treatment strategies against resistant strains.

Tags: neet 2020

Reference:

  1. Gillespie, S. H. (2002). Mechanisms of drug resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. International Journal of Tuberculosis and Lung Disease.
  2. Andrews, J. R., et al. (2018). Molecular mechanisms of drug resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals pallor, jaundice, and glossitis. Laboratory tests show:
Hemoglobin (Hb): 7 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 120 fL
Red blood cell count (RBC): 2 million/μL
White blood cell count (WBC): 3,000/μL
Platelet count: 50,000/μL
Serum vitamin B12: 50 pg/mL (normal: 200-900 pg/mL)
Peripheral smear findings: Macro ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophil.
What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MCV > 100 fL, Low serum vitamin B12 suggests Megaloblastic anemia.

Peripheral smear shows megaloblastic changes and confirms the diagnosis of Megaloblastic anemia.

On PBS:

  1. RBC- Macro-ovalocyte
    • Howell Jolly bodies -Made of DNA remnants
    • Cabot ring-mitotic spindles
  2. WBC changes-Hyper segmented neutrophils

Incorrect Options-

A. Iron deficiency anemia has low mcv.

C. No evidence of myeloproliferative disorder, it shows increase in a particular lineage of cells

D. Sickle cell anemia shows sickle shaped RBCs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Peripheral smear findings: Macro ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils with increased MCV points towards megaloblastic anemia.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 651.

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy with plasma cells>30%
Bone marrow biopsy with plasma cells>60%
Bone marrow biopsy with plasma cells>10%
Bone marrow biopsy with plasma cells>50%

questions.text: An elderly male presents with bone pain and generalised weakness. Evaluation shows severe Anaemia with raised serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL. HBA1C and fasting blood sugar are normal. serum protein electrophoresis shows monoclonal IgG 40 grams/L. Which of the following will confirm the diagnosis of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Clonal bone marrow plasma cells and any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

Evidence of one or more indicators of end-organ damage that can be attributed to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically:

  • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >0.25 mmol/L (>1 mg/dL) higher than the upper limit of normal or >2.75 mmol/L (>11 mg/dL)
  • Renal insufficiency: creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >177 μmol/L (>2 mg/dL)
  • Anemia: hemoglobin value of >20 g/L below the lower limit of normal, or a hemoglobin value <100 g/L
  • Bone lesions: one or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
  • Clonal bone marrow plasma cell percentage ≥60%
  • Involved: uninvolved serum free light chain ratio ≥100
  • >1 focal lesion on MRI studies

Definition of clonal Proliferation of plasma cell is >10% in bone Marrow

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 871

choices.text: Colicky abdominal pain, 'currant jelly' stools, vomiting

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the clinical triad of intussusception in infants?
questions.solution:
Acute Intussusception

  • Invagination of one part of the intestine into an adjacent segment, typically proximal into distal.
  • most common type: ileocolic
  • Common in children, peak incidence between 5-10 months.
  • 90% idiopathic; related to viral infections, Peyer's patch hyperplasia.
  • Older children and adults usually have a pathological lead point (e.g., Meckel's diverticulum, polyps, tumors).
  • Symptoms: Colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools ('currant jelly stools').
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound (target sign) and CT scan (pathognomonic target sign).
  • Management:
    • Non-surgical reduction (air/contrast enema)
    • surgery if reduction fails or a lead point is identified.


Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. This triad describes general gastrointestinal upset.

Option B: Correct. The classic triad of intussusception includes colicky abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and vomiting.

Option C: Incorrect. Bloody diarrhoea and fever may suggest infectious causes like bacterial gastroenteritis.

Option D: Incorrect. This triad is more indicative of volvulus or intestinal obstruction.

Key Points:

Intussusception typically presents with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools.

Tags:

Topic: Intussusception

Difficulty: Moderate, Must know

PYQ: NEET PG 2020, 2022; FMGE AUG 2020

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 78, page no.-1379

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has recently delivered a baby and is breastfeeding. She wants a contraceptive method that is safe during lactation and does not affect milk supply. Which contraceptive method should be recommended?
questions.solution:
Option B: Progestin-only pills

Progestin-only pills (POPs) are recommended for breastfeeding women as they do not contain estrogen, which can affect milk production. POPs are safe, effective, and do not interfere with breastfeeding, making them the most suitable choice for lactating mothers.

Option A: Combined oral contraceptives

Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen can decrease milk supply and is generally not recommended for breastfeeding women, especially in the early postpartum period. Estrogen can also increase the risk of thrombosis during the postpartum period.

Option C: Nuva Ring

The Nuva Ring is a combined hormonal contraceptive device that releases both estrogen and progestin. Similar to COCs, the estrogen component can potentially reduce milk supply, making it unsuitable for breastfeeding women who wish to maintain optimal milk production.



Option D: Contraceptive patch

The contraceptive patch also contains both estrogen and progestin. The estrogen component can impact milk supply, similar to COCs and the Nuva Ring, making it less suitable for breastfeeding women.

Type: Must know

Topic: Contraceptive of choice in lactating mothers

choices.text: Creating a toxic environment for sperm
Inhibition of implantation through hormonal release

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits the gynaecology clinic seeking a long-term, non-hormonal contraceptive method. She has no significant past medical history, is in a stable monogamous relationship, and desires contraception that requires minimal daily attention. She reports regular menstrual cycles and no known allergies. After discussing various options, she is interested in the Copper T 380A IUD. Based on the patient's preference for a non-hormonal, long-term contraceptive method, and her decision to use the Copper T 380A IUD, what is the primary mechanism by which this IUD prevents pregnancy?
questions.solution:
OPTION C) Creating a toxic environment for sperm:

This is the primary mechanism of action for the Copper T 380A IUD. The copper ions released by the IUD create an inflammatory reaction within the uterine cavity that is toxic to sperm. This reaction impairs sperm motility and viability, reducing their ability to fertilize an egg. Additionally, the copper ions disrupt the sperm's ability to undergo capacitation and the acrosome reaction, which are critical for fertilization. As a result, the Copper T 380A IUD effectively prevents pregnancy through this non-hormonal mechanism

OPTION A) Suppression of ovulation:

This mechanism is associated with hormonal contraceptives, such as birth control pills, patches, and hormonal IUDs. These methods work primarily by suppressing the release of eggs from the ovaries (ovulation). However, Copper T 380A IUD is non-hormonal and does not affect the ovulation process. Therefore, this option is incorrect for the Copper T 380A IUD.

OPTION B) Thickening of cervical mucus:

Thickening of cervical mucus is another mechanism utilized by hormonal contraceptives, particularly those containing progestin. Thicker mucus creates a barrier that makes it difficult for sperm to travel through the cervix and reach the egg. However, the Copper T 380A IUD does not contain hormones, so it does not work by altering cervical mucus.

OPTION D) Inhibition of implantation through hormonal release:

Hormonal IUDs, such as those containing levonorgestrel, may partially prevent pregnancy by inhibiting implantation through the hormonal effects on the endometrium. However, the Copper T 380A IUD does not release hormones and thus does not inhibit implantation through hormonal means. It primarily works by affecting sperm function rather than by altering the uterine lining in a hormonal way. This option is incorrect for the Copper T 380A IUD.

Key takeaway: The Copper T 380A IUD primarily prevents pregnancy by releasing copper ions that create an inflammatory and toxic environment for sperm within the uterine cavity, impairing their motility and function, thus preventing fertilization.

Type: Must know

Topic: Long Acting Reversible Contraception

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 261

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with chronic dacryocystitis. She reports a history of recurrent epiphora, conjunctival injection, and a purulent discharge from the inner canthus. During examination, you note the presence of a palpable mass in the lacrimal sac region. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent for this chronic condition?
questions.solution:
Chronic Dacryocystitis:

  • Definition: Chronic dacryocystitis is an inflammatory condition of the lacrimal sac resulting from long-standing obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct. The obstruction causes tear accumulation, leading to chronic infection and inflammation.
  • Etiology:
    • Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction:
      • Congenital Causes: Common in infants due to incomplete canalization of the nasolacrimal duct.
      • Acquired Causes: Includes duct stenosis or blockage due to chronic sinusitis, nasal polyps, or age-related changes.
    • Infection:
      • Bacterial: Most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenzae.
      • Fungal or Viral: Less common but possible, especially in immunocompromised patients.
      • Other Causes:<ul
      • Trauma: Physical injury to the eye or surrounding structures.
      • Tumors: Benign or malignant growths causing obstruction.
    • Symptoms:
      • Epiphora: Persistent tearing due to inadequate drainage.
      • Purulent Discharge: Thick, yellow or green discharge from the eye, typically expressed by palpation over the lacrimal sac.
      • Conjunctival Injection: Redness and swelling of the conjunctiva.Lacrimal Sac Tenderness: Pain and tenderness localized to the area of the lacrimal sac, often exacerbated by palpation.
    • Diagnosis:
      • Clinical Examination:
        • Inspection: Look for signs of swelling, redness, and discharge.
        • Palpation: Gentle pressure over the lacrimal sac to detect tenderness and express discharge.
        • Dacryocystography:
          • Technique: Contrast dye is injected into the lacrimal sac, and X-ray imaging is used to visualize the nasolacrimal duct.
          • Findings: Shows the site and extent of obstruction or any anatomical anomalies.
    • Treatment:
      • Antibiotic Therapy:
        • First-Line: Broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover common bacterial pathogens.
      • Surgical Intervention:
        • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): The primary surgical treatment to bypass the obstructed nasolacrimal duct.
          • Procedure: Creation of a new drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac to the nasal cavity in to middle meatus.
        • Complications:
          • Chronic Infection: Persistent infection may lead to recurrent symptoms and the need for additional treatment.
          • Abscess Formation: Localized collection of pus in the lacrimal sac.
          • Sinusitis: Can occur if infection spreads to adjacent sinuses.
        • Option A) Herpes Simplex Virus: Typically associated with acute infections, including epithelial keratitis and dendritic ulcers, not commonly the causative agent in chronic dacryocystitis.
        • Option B) Staphylococcus aureus: A common bacterial pathogen responsible for chronic dacryocystitis. It frequently causes chronic infections due to its ability to form abscesses and persist in the lacrimal sac.
        • Option C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Often associated with contact lens-related infections or severe acute keratitis, but less common in chronic dacryocystitis.
        • Option D) Aspergillus fumigatus: A fungus more commonly related to fungal infections in the eye, particularly in immunocompromised patients. It is not a typical pathogen in chronic dacryocystitis.

    Reference: Kanski, J.J., Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Chapter on Diseases of the Lacrimal Apparatus, pp. 170-175.

questions.text: A 30 years old male visited hospital with complaint of pain, numbness and tingling in his left forearm and hand when he raises it above his head. On examination doctor found his left hand colder and paler compared to right hand when arm was abducted and external rotated. He has no history of trauma. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Thoracic outlet syndrome: It is characterized by compression of neurovascular structure as they pass through thoracic outlet It is presents with pain, numbness, tingling and diminished pulse with arm movements



Option wise explanation:

Option A: Carpal tunnel syndrome: It is compression of median nerve at the wrist causing numbness and tingling on the thumb, index and middle finger.

Option B: Cervical Radiculopathy: It involve nerve root compression at cervical spine but not with present with a diminished pulse or cold extremity.

Option C: Rotator cuff injury: It cause shoulder pain and weakness but not neurovascular symptoms like numbness or diminished pulse.

questions.text: When an excitable tissue is stimulated it responds completely or it does not respond at all. It is known as all or none law. Which tissue does not follow it?
questions.solution:
• Option A) Motor nerves do not follow the all-or-none law. It is made up of many nerve fibers.
    • Once the stimulus reaches the threshold, the entire nerve fiber will generate an action potential that propagates along the nerve without any decrease in intensity.
    • In a motor unit single motor neuron follows all or none law.
  • Option B) Skeletal muscle fibers also stick to the all-or-none law. If the stimulus is strong enough to reach the threshold, the entire muscle fiber contracts fully. If the stimulus does not reach the threshold, no contraction occurs in the skeletal muscle fiber.
  • Option C) Cardiac muscle works in syncytium. Cardiac muscle fibers also follow the all-or-none law. When a stimulus is above the threshold, the entire cardiac muscle fiber contracts completely. This ensures that the heart contracts uniformly to pump blood effectively.
  • Option D) Motor unit is a single motor neuron and the muscle fibers supplied by it. Motor unit strictly follows all or none law.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 225

questions.text: A 56 year old female presented to medicine opd seeking treatment for deep vein thrombosis. Later she was prescribed dabigatran by her physician. As patient was also having mild renal impairment there were multiple hemorrhagic episodes due to dabigatran toxicity. Which of the following monoclonal antibody is approved for the reversal of serious bleeding due to dabigatran toxicity?
questions.solution:
Bleeding is the major side effect of dabigatran.

In elderly patients with atrial fibrillation, the risk of major bleeding with dabigatran is like that with warfarin, about 3.0%. However, the risk of intracranial bleeding is reduced by 70% with dabigatran compared with warfarin.

Additional risk factors for bleeding with dabigatran include renal impairment and concurrent use of antiplatelet agents or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Idarucizumab

  • Idarucizumab, A specific reversal agent for dabigatran, is a humanized mouse monoclonal antibody fragment directed against dabigatran.
  • The antibody binds dabigatran with an affinity 350-fold higher than that of dabigatran for thrombin, and the essentially irreversible idarucizumab-dabigatran complex is cleared by the kidneys.
  • It rapidly reverses the anticoagulant effects of dabigatran, and patients have then safely undergone major surgery.

Reversal Agents for Direct Oral Anticoagulants



Option A: TCR signaling on CD4+ cells after engagement with an MHC class II-peptide complex is enhanced by activating coreceptors CD 40 & CD 150 which is activated by Dacetuzumab.

Option C: Pembrolizumab is monoclonal antibodies against PD-1 receptors on T-cells.

Option D: Natalizumab is highly effective in multiple sclerosis.

  • Key Takeaway :
  • Idarucizumab, A specific reversal agent for dabigatran, is a humanized mouse monoclonal antibody fragment directed against dabigatran.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 14th edition, page no. 718, 720

questions.text: An 75 year old agricultural worker is brought to the emergency department after an abrupt onset of bowel and bladder incontinence and muscle weakness. He is given oxygen and antidotal drug treatments. Which of the following drug mechanism would increase muscle strength in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has signs and symptoms of organophosphate toxicity that are caused by inhibition of cholinesterase and excessive stimulation of muscarinic and nicotinic receptors by acetylcholine.
  • The treatment of organophosphate intoxication includes administration of pralidoxime, which reactivates cholinesterase and leads to increased acetylcholine degradation.
  • The patient's muscle weakness is caused by prolonged depolarization of skeletal muscle.
  • Specific antidotes of Anti-ChE poisoning:

(a) Atropine

It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.

It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action.

All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinisation appear

(b) Cholinesterase reactivators

Oximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.

  • Pralidoxime is ineffective as an antidote to carbamate anti-ChEs (physostigmine, neostigmine, carbaryl, propoxur)
  • Treatment should be started as early as possible (within few hours), before the phosphorylated enzyme has undergone 'aging' and become resistant to hydrolysis.

Other oximes are

  1. Obidoxime -> more potent than pralidoxime
  2. Diacetyl-monoxime (DAM) -> lipophilic.
  • Key Takeaway
  • Pralidoxime and diacetyl monoxime are cholinesterase regenerator compounds used for organophosphate poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 122-123

questions.text: In uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus, Metabolic Alteration takes place leading to
questions.solution:
• A decreased insulin-to-glucagon ratio leads to a decrease in fatty acid synthesis and an increase in adipose triacylglycerol degradation, leading to fatty acid release into the circulation.
  • The liver takes up the fatty acids, and within the mitochondria, fatty acids undergo beta -oxidation. As acetyl CoA accumulates, the ketone bodies, acetoacetate and b-hydroxybutyrate, are formed and are released into the circulation.
  • These ketone bodies are used to fuel the heart, brain, and muscle. Nonenzymatic decarboxylation of acetoacetate forms acetone, which can be smelled by some providers on the breath of patients in diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Because triglycerides are degraded under these conditions, there is not an increase in triglyceride storage. Pancreatitis does not result from an inability to produce insulin

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chap 22

A 60-year-old man presents with Rapidly progressive dementia, Ataxia, Myoclonus. EEG shows periodic sharp wave complexes Autopsy reveals: br>Spongiform changes in the cerebral cortex
Vacuolation of neurons
Astrocytosis
Electron microscopy reveals Kuru plaques.

questions.solution:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a prion disease characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, ataxia, and myoclonus, with EEG showing periodic sharp wave complexes.

  • Spongiform changes, vacuolation of neurons, and astrocytosis are characteristic histopathological features.

Option A-Huntington's disease typically shows caudate nucleus atrophy.


Option B -Alzheimer's disease typically shows amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles.

B. Parkinson's disease typically shows Lewy bodies.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with Hypercalcemia, Elevated calcitonin levels, Thyroid nodule on ultrasound.
Histopathological examination of the thyroid nodule reveals:
Increased number of parafollicular cells (C-cells)
Formation of nodular aggregates
Amyloid deposition
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
C. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant tumor originating from parafollicular cells (C-cells).

Elevated calcitonin levels and amyloid deposition are characteristic features.



A. Hashimoto thyroiditis typically shows lymphocytic infiltration and no nodular aggregates of C-cells.


B. Follicular thyroid adenoma typically shows follicular architecture and no amyloid deposition.



C. Papillary thyroid carcinoma typically shows papillary architecture and nuclear features.


KEY TAKEAWAYS-. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant tumor originating from parafollicular cells (C-cells).

Elevated calcitonin levels and amyloid deposition are characteristic features.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1091.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman underwent a total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goiter. Twelve hours after surgery, she suddenly develops respiratory distress, with a tense swelling in the neck. As a junior resident on duty, What is the most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Postoperative Complications of Thyroidectomy

  • Haemorrhage: The most life-threatening complication. Hematoma typically occurs within the first 24 hours and can cause airway obstruction if untreated. Immediate management includes removing sutures to release pressure.
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Paralysis: RLN injury can be unilateral or bilateral, transient or permanent. Routine postoperative laryngoscopy can detect transient vocal cord paralysis.
  • Superior Laryngeal Nerve Injury: This leads to a loss of vocal cord tension, affecting voice power and range, especially in professional voice users.
  • Management of RLN Injury: Re-anastomosis should be performed if the nerve is transected. Speech therapy and voice medialisation procedures can be used for permanent vocal cord paralysis.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. While securing the airway is important, the first step is to release the pressure by removing skin sutures to prevent airway obstruction.

Option B) Incorrect. Compression may worsen the situation. Releasing the hematoma is more critical.

Option C) Incorrect. Although surgical evacuation may ultimately be needed, the initial step is to relieve the pressure by opening the wound.

Option D) Correct. Removing skin sutures immediately can relieve pressure caused by the hematoma, preventing airway compromise.

Key Points:

Post-thyroidectomy hematoma can cause life-threatening airway obstruction and requires immediate relief of pressure.

Tags:

Topic: Postoperative Complications of Thyroidectomy

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ: INICET NOV 2020, JUNE 2020; NEET PG 2020, 2021, 2019

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 55, Pages 865

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy has been growing at the third percentile since 4 years of age. His parents are concerned because both of their heights are at the 25th percentile and they are worried he will not catch up. The boy is otherwise healthy. He denies headaches or abdominal pain. The boy's bone age is 12 months delayed from his chronologic age. His parents request further evaluation to identify the cause of his poor growth. Of the following, the BEST next step in the evaluation of this child is to
questions.solution:
• An endocrine cause of poor growth is likely when linear growth slows down or arrests while weight gain is either normal or increasing. Hence, Insulin like growth factor and Thyroxine levels are expected to be normal.
  • There are no other signs of other hormone deficiency as expected in pituitary tumor. Hence, getting a pituitary MRI will be useless.
  • In children with normal growth velocity and normal final height prediction, the likely cause is constitutional. The child will catchup in growth with age. Hence, parents are to be reassured about the condition.

Reference: Nelson Pediatric symptom- based diagnosis, pg. 791
