questions.text: A 9-month-old child presents to the emergency room after reportedly falling from his high chair. The parents report no loss of consciousness, other trauma, or medical problems. Your examination reveals a few old bruises but no evidence of acute trauma or fracture. CT scan of the brain without contrast reports bilateral frontal subdural hematomas and notes two healing skull fractures that she estimates to be approximately 3 weeks old. Which of the following is the best next step in this child's management?
questions.solution:
• This child has evidence of old skull fractures with subdural hematomas. Head magnetic resonance imaging would help to determine the hematoma age. If the hematoma blood age correlates with the estimated skull fracture age, child abuse should be considered. Neurology may be helpful later, but an immediate consultation would be of limited benefit before additional data were gathered.
  • Discharge with the information presented in the case is dangerous; the child likely requires hospital admission and the involvement of social services.
  • Bleeding studies are unlikely to be helpful initially but may be required at some point if child abuse is suspected and a court case is anticipated.
  • The child has no history consistent with a bleeding disorder, and a bleeding disorder does not explain the old fractures.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA edition, pg.3056

questions.text:
Choose the option with the correct statement about inter-vertebral discs (IVD) :
1. Nucleus pulposus is derived from ectoderm
2. Annulus fibrosus is derived from mesoderm
3. Nutrition of IVD is derived through diffusion through CSF
4. IVD allows spinal motion and stability.
questions.solution:
Intervertebral Discs (IVDs)

  • Functions:
    • Allow spinal motion and stability. (Option D)
    • Act as cushioning for axial loads on the spine.
  • Components:
    • Central Nucleus Pulposus:
      • Derived from the notochord. (Option A)
      • Hydrated gel with compressibility.
      • Low collagen (type II) and high proteoglycan (and glycosaminoglycan) content.
      • Proteoglycans make up a higher percentage of dry weight.
      • With time, undergoes loss of proteoglycans and water (desiccation).
    • Surrounding Annulus Fibrosis:
      • Derived from mesoderm. (Option B)
      • Provides extensibility and increased tensile strength.
      • High collagen (type I) and low proteoglycan content.
      • Proteoglycans make up a lower percentage of dry weight.
      • Superficial layer contains nerve fibers.
  • Composition:
    • Water: 85%
    • Proteoglycans
    • Type II Collagen: 20% of dry weight in the nucleus pulposus.
    • Type I Collagen: 60% of dry weight in the annulus fibrosis.
  • Neurovascularity:
    • Dorsal Root Ganglion: Gives rise to the sinuvertebral nerve, innervating the superficial fibers of the annulus.
    • Avascular: Nutrients and fluid diffuse from the vertebral end plates. Diffusion is impaired by calcification with aging. (Option C)
  • Aging Disc:
    • Early Degenerative Disc Disease:
      • An irreversible process.
      • IL-1β stimulates the release of MMPs, nitric oxide, IL-6, and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2).
    • Changes:
      • Decreased water content and conversion to fibrocartilage.
      • Decreased hydrostatic pressure due to fewer large proteoglycans (aggrecan).
      • Fibronectin cleavage or fragmentation is associated with degeneration.
      • Increase in keratan sulfate concentration and decrease in chondroitin sulfate.
      • Increase in relative collagen concentration, with no change in absolute quantity.

Reference: Miller's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 164

questions.text:
What are the Functions of a male health worker posted under health department, covering population of 5000:
A. Accompany pregnant female to hospital
B. Immunization of children as per schedule
C. IUCD insertion
D. Malaria slide preparation
questions.solution:
In the context of a male health worker posted under the health department, covering a population of 5,000, the following functions are typically part of their responsibilities:

  • A. Accompany pregnant female to hospital: Male health workers may assist in referring and ensuring that pregnant women receive timely care, but this is not their primary role.
  • B. Immunization of children as per schedule: This is a key responsibility, as male health workers are involved in ensuring that children receive their vaccinations according to the immunization schedule.
  • C. IUCD insertion: Typically, IUCD insertion is performed by trained female health workers like ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) or medical officers.
  • D. Malaria slide preparation: Male health workers are involved in preparing malaria slides for diagnosis, particularly in areas where malaria is prevalent.
  • Given this context, the correct answer is: B. -B & D

Here are the key functions that a male health worker typically performs in a community setting,



KEY TAKEAWAYS- A male health worker posted under health department, covering population of 5000 is concerned with immunization, health education, malaria slide preparation, etc.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-10, Page no.: 705-710.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with sudden onset of severe eye pain, decreased vision, and redness following recent cataract surgery. On examination, the patient has a hypopyon and vitreous opacities. Vitrectomy is performed, and cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this case, given the typical time frame and clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
endophthalmitis:

  1. Definition
    • Endophthalmitis is a severe, sight-threatening inflammation of the intraocular structures, primarily caused by infection. It involves both the anterior and posterior segments of the eye.
  2. Etiology
    • Most commonly results from postoperative infection (e.g., following cataract surgery, intravitreal injections).
    • Can also be caused by trauma (penetrating eye injury introducing pathogens) or endogenous spread (bloodborne infection from another body site, such as endocarditis or systemic fungal infection).
  3. Common Causative Organisms
    • Bacterial:
      • Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (most common in postoperative cases)
      • Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp., and Pseudomonas aeruginosa
    • Fungal:
      • Candida and Aspergillus species in endogenous fungal endophthalmitis, more common in immunocompromised individuals.
  4. Clinical Presentation
    • Severe eye pain
    • Rapidly progressive vision loss
    • Redness and photophobia
    • Hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber)
    • Vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous, presenting as hazy media)
    • Swollen eyelids, corneal edema, and decreased intraocular pressure may also be seen.
  5. Diagnostic Workup
    • Clinical Examination: Findings include hypopyon, anterior chamber inflammation, vitritis, and reduced visual acuity.
    • Vitreous or Aqueous Tap: Samples taken for culture, Gram stain, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to identify causative organisms.
  6. Treatment
    • Intravitreal Antibiotics: Direct injection into the vitreous to target infection. Common drugs include vancomycin (Gram-positive coverage) and ceftazidime (Gram-negative coverage).
    • Vitrectomy: Surgical removal of infected vitreous may be necessary in severe cases to clear the infection and improve outcomes.
  7. Prevention
    • Prophylactic antibiotics: Administered perioperatively in cataract surgery (usually intracameral or topical).
    • Sterile techniques during ocular procedures to reduce the risk of introducing infections.
    • Prompt management of ocular trauma to prevent infection.
    • Option A) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This is a common bacterial pathogen responsible for post-surgical endophthalmitis, particularly within the first few weeks following cataract surgery. It is known for causing rapid onset, severe symptoms, and is associated with poor outcomes if not promptly treated.
    • Option B) Aspergillus flavus: A fungal organism, less commonly responsible for acute post-surgical endophthalmitis but may be considered in chronic or more atypical cases, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.
    • Option C) Herpes Simplex Virus: More often associated with herpetic keratitis or retinitis rather than acute endophthalmitis following cataract surgery.
    • Option D) Candida albicans: Typically causes endogenous endophthalmitis or in immunocompromised individuals, and is less common as a post-surgical pathogen compared to Pseudomonas

    Reference:

    • Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th Edition, Chapter on Infectious Endophthalmitis, pp. 378-382.

choices.text: Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1); characterized by Lisch nodules and optic nerve gliomas.
Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2); typically presents with bilateral vestibular schwannomas and cataracts.
Von Hippel-Lindau Disease; known for retinal hemangioblastomas and pancreatic cysts.
Tuberous Sclerosis Complex; presents with retinal astrocytic hamartomas and angiofibromas.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presents with multiple skin lesions and recent onset of visual disturbances. On examination, the patient has a few cafe-au-lait spots on the skin, along with a well-defined, yellowish lesion in the iris. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the typical ophthalmic manifestation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
• Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1):
    • Key Ophthalmic Findings:
      • Lisch Nodules: Pigmented iris hamartomas visible on slit-lamp examination.
      • Optic Nerve Gliomas: These tumors can cause vision loss and are commonly associated with NF1.
    • Skin Lesions: Cafe-au-lait spots are common, and neurofibromas may be present.
  • Option B) Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2):
    • Ophthalmic Findings: Bilateral vestibular schwannomas and cataracts are characteristic. Not typically associated with Lisch nodules.
  • Option C) Von Hippel-Lindau Disease:
    • Ophthalmic Findings: Retinal hemangioblastomas. Not associated with Lisch nodules or cafe-au-lait spots.
  • Option D) Tuberous Sclerosis Complex:
    • Ophthalmic Findings: Retinal astrocytic hamartomas. Not associated with Lisch nodules or cafe-au-lait spots.

Reference:

  • Kanski, J.J., Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Chapter on Neurofibromatosis, pp. 115-118.
  • Parson's 22/e section VI chapter 28 diseases of the lids pg 466-467 Neurofibromatosis

questions.text: Which of the following demonstrates highest correlation between variables?
questions.solution:
The highest possible value for a correlation coefficient is +1.00 or -1.00, indicating a perfect correlation.

Correlation coefficients cannot exceed +1.00 or go below -1.00.

Given the options:

  • Option A (+2.00) is not possible since correlation values cannot exceed +1.00.
  • Option B (-0.75) shows a strong negative correlation.
  • Option C (+0.25) shows a weak positive correlation.
  • Option D (+0.50) shows a moderate positive correlation.

Therefore, Option b (-0.75) demonstrates the highest correlation (in magnitude) between the variables.

Additional Key Points:

  • Direction: The sign of the coefficient (positive or negative) indicates the direction of the relationship.
    • Positive Correlation (+): As one variable increases, the other also increases.
    • Negative Correlation (-): As one variable increases, the other decreases.
  • Magnitude: The absolute value of the correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the relationship.
    • Values close to +1 or -1 represent stronger relationships.
    • Values close to 0 represent weaker relationships.
  • Linear Relationship: The correlation coefficient only measures linear relationships; it does not capture non-linear patterns.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The coefficient of correlation is a statistical measure that quantifies the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables. It is commonly represented by the symbol r. The value of the correlation coefficient ranges between -1 and 1, where:

  • r = 1: Perfect positive linear relationship (as one variable increases, the other increases).
  • r = -1: Perfect negative linear relationship (as one variable increases, the other decreases).
  • r = 0: No linear relationship between the variables

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-12, Page No -226-230.

choices.text: Activation of GABA B receptors in the spinal cord
Blockade of excitatory neurotransmitter release in the brain
Blockade of Ca2+ channels in the skeletal muscle membrane
Blockade of Ca2+ channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A 49-year-old man diagnosed with inguinal hernia was prepared for surgery. Shortly after the initiation of general anaesthesia with halothane and succinylcholine, the patient developed muscle rigidity, tachycardia, fluctuating blood pressure, profuse diaphoresis, and high fever (104.2°F). The anaesthesia was discontinued and a drug was administered by rapid intravenous push. Which of the following was most likely the mechanism of action of the administered drug?
questions.solution:
• The clinical picture of the patient suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia.
  • A rare but potentially life-threatening disorder that can be triggered by a variety of stimuli including Administration of certain Inhaled anaesthetics (mainly halothane) and Neuromuscular blocking agents (mainly succinylcholine)

The disorder is related to a hereditary impairment in the ability of the sarcoplasmic reticulum to sequester calcium

Therefore, a prolonged release of calcium occurs

Triggering event through sarcoplasmic calcium channels

This causes massive muscle contraction, hyperthermia, and lactic acidosis

Dantrolene is a drug of choice in this disorder because it blocks Ca2+ channels in the skeletal muscle sarcoplasmic reticulum,

Thus preventing the massive release of calcium.

Dantrolene :



  • Key Takeaway:
  • Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. It acts via Blockade of Ca2+ channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 381,382

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic woman presents to the emergency room with signs and symptoms of urinary tract infection, including fever, dysuria and bacteriuria. Given that she is diabetic, she is admitted for treatment with intravenous ciprofloxacin. Which of the following is the most accurate mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin is a quinolone, a group of antibiotics that inhibit bacterial topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase).

Option A: The antibiotic classes that inhibit the 30S ribosome include aminoglycosides and tetracycline.

Option B: Inhibitors of the 50S ribosome include chloramphenicol, erythromycin, and clindamycin.

Option C: Bacterial cell wall inhibitors include penicillins, cephalosporins, and vancomycin.

  • Key Takeaway
  • Ciprofloxacin is a quinolone, a group of antibiotics that inhibit bacterial topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 760

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the benefits of various interventions in diabetes?
1. Lifestyle interventions can reduce the incidence of diabetes by 50%
2. Risk of microvascular disease reduces by 30% per 1% drop in HbA1c
3. Use of ACE inhibitors reduces the risk of nephropathy by 10%
4. Risk of macrovascular disease reduces by 35% per 10 mmHg drop in blood-pressure
5. Annual eye examination reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by 40%
questions.solution:
• The use of ACE inhibitors in diabetics reduces the risk of nephropathy by 42% and cardiovascular risk by 22%.
  • Annual eye examination in diabetics reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by 60-70%.

Interventions in diabetes:

  • Glycaemic control in diabetics with HbA1C > 9% reduces microvascular disease risk by 30% per 1% drop in HbA1C
  • Blood pressure control in patients with BP - 130/80 mmHg reduces microvascular and macrovascular disease risk by 35% per 10 mmHg drop in blood pressure.
  • Lifestyle modification reduces the incidence of diabetes by 35-58%
  • Metformin administered as a preventive therapy reduces the incidence of diabetes by 25-31%.
  • Proper foot care reduces the risk of serious foot disease by 50-60%.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The use of ACE inhibitors in diabetics reduces the risk of nephropathy by 42% and cardiovascular risk by 22%.

Annual eye examination in diabetics reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by 60-70%.

REFERENCE:- Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 6, Page No-446-451.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine and pigmented macules on the lips. Which gene is typically mutated in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)

  • Autosomal dominant disorder with multiple hamartomatous polyps in the GI tract.
  • Mucocutaneous pigmentation on lips, mouth, and fingers.
  • Increased risk of GI and extra-GI cancers (pancreas, breast, ovary).
  • Common symptoms:
    • GI bleeding, obstruction, intussusception.
  • Diagnosis via endoscopy or genetic testing (STK11/LKB1 mutation).
  • Management: Regular surveillance, polypectomy to prevent complications.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. APC mutations are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Option B: Correct. STK11 mutations are seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which is characterized by hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Option C: Incorrect. MSH2 mutations are associated with Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer).

Option D: Incorrect. MLH1 is also associated with Lynch syndrome.

Key Points:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by hamartomatous polyps and STK11 gene mutations.

Tags:

Topic : Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Difficulty: Moderate,Must know

PYQ: INICET NOV 2020

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 77 page no.-1356

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
• Hyperthermia refers to elevated body temperature. In chronic starvation, the body’s metabolic rate decreases, and thermoregulation mechanisms work to conserve heat rather than generate excess heat. Therefore, hyperthermia is not a characteristic change seen in chronic starvation.

Chronic Starvation causes the development of the following changes in the order mentioned below:

  • Loss of well-being, hunger, and hunger pains.
  • Mental and physical lethargy and easy fatigue.
  • Progressive loss of weight which is rapid in the first six months.
  • Polyuria.
  • Increasing wasting, the body weight is reduced by about 40% of the normal.
  • Pigmentation and anemia.
  • Hypothermia and not Hyperthermia; peripheral vascular stasis in cold and hypotension.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Exhaustion: Chronic starvation leads to the depletion of energy reserves in the body, resulting in fatigue, weakness, and exhaustion.
  • Option C - Heart atrophy: In chronic starvation, the body conserves energy by reducing its metabolic rate. This can result in muscle wasting, including the heart muscle, leading to heart atrophy.
  • Option D - Hypotension: Hypotension refers to low blood pressure. In chronic starvation, the body tries to conserve fluids and maintain blood volume, which can result in decreased blood pressure.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In chronic starvation, the body’s metabolic rate decreases, and thermoregulation mechanisms work to conserve heat rather than generate excess heat. Therefore, hyperthermia is not a characteristic change seen in chronic starvation.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 335,336

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. His liver function tests reveal a cholestatic liver enzyme pattern, and MRCP shows stricturing of the bile ducts. Which of the following is most commonly associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

  • Chronic cholestatic liver disease linked to ulcerative colitis.
  • Causes inflammation, fibrosis, and stricturing of bile ducts, leading to a "beaded" appearance on cholangiography.
  • Affects mostly young men in their 30s.
  • Diagnosed by cholangiography; liver biopsy may be needed.
  • Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma and gallbladder cancer.
  • No specific treatment; liver transplantation is definitive for advanced disease.
  • Temporary relief by biliary stenting, but risk of cholangitis.
  • In patients with PSC and ulcerative colitis, the condition usually progresses even following colectomy.

Option A. Hepatitis B infection: Incorrect. Hepatitis B is not commonly linked with PSC.

Option B. Ulcerative colitis: Correct. PSC is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis.

Option C. Hepatitis C infection: Incorrect. Hepatitis C is not linked with PSC.

Option D. Gallstones: Incorrect. Gallstones are not associated with PSC.

Key Points:

  • Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for advanced disease or cholangiocarcinoma risk.
  • Biliary stenting can provide temporary relief for obstructive jaundice, but with risk of cholangitis.

Tags:

Topic: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 69, page no. -1207.

choices.text: Empirical antibiotic therapy and aspiration for culture

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male presents with fever, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. A CT scan reveals a multiloculated cystic mass with an air-fluid level in the liver. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Liver Abscess

  • Common Causative Agents: Polymicrobial, typically Klebsiella, Escherichia coli, and Streptococcus milleri group.
  • Risk Factors: Elderly, diabetic, and immunosuppressed individuals.
  • Diagnosis: Multiloculated cystic mass on CT or ultrasound, confirmed by aspiration.
  • Management: Includes aspiration for microbiological diagnosis and broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., metronidazole, third-generation cephalosporins).

Option A. Immediate surgical resection: Incorrect. Surgery is rarely the first-line treatment unless there is failure of drainage or the abscess is unresponsive to other treatments.

Option B. Empirical antibiotic therapy and aspiration for culture: Correct. Initial management of a liver abscess includes identifying the source, aspirating for microbiology, and administering antibiotics.

Option C. Hydatid cyst management protocol: Incorrect. Hydatid cysts require specific antiparasitic treatment, not empiric antibiotics, and are managed differently.

Option D. Observation with serial imaging: Incorrect. Active management is needed in the form of antibiotics and aspiration; observation alone is not appropriate for liver abscesses.

Tags:

Topic: Liver Abscess

Difficulty Level: Must know

PYQ: INICET MAY 2023; NEET PG 2023,2021

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 69 page no. -1209.

questions.text: Which of the following prenatal diagnostic tests is associated with the lowest risk of fetal loss?
questions.solution:
Option A: Amniocentesis

Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test typically performed between 15 and 20 weeks of gestation to obtain amniotic fluid for genetic testing. Although it is considered relatively safe, it carries a small risk of fetal loss, estimated at about 0.1-0.3%. The risk arises from potential complications such as infection, rupture of membranes, or injury to the fetus during the procedure.

Option B: Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS)

CVS is performed earlier than amniocentesis, usually between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation, to obtain placental tissue for genetic testing. It has a slightly higher risk of fetal loss compared to amniocentesis, approximately 0.2-0.5%. The increased risk is due to the invasive nature of the procedure, which can cause miscarriage, infection, or injury to the placenta.

Option C: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT)

NIPT is a screening test that analyzes cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal blood. It poses no risk of fetal loss because it is non-invasive and only requires a maternal blood sample. NIPT is highly accurate for detecting common chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome, but it is a screening rather than a diagnostic test, meaning abnormal results need confirmation by invasive testing like amniocentesis or CVS.

Option D: Cordocentesis

Cordocentesis, or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), involves taking a blood sample from the umbilical cord and is usually performed after 18 weeks of gestation. It has the highest risk of fetal loss among the options listed, estimated at about 1-2%. The procedure is used for more detailed testing, such as fetal anemia or infections, but the invasiveness contributes to its higher risk.

Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is associated with the lowest risk of fetal loss because it is non-invasive and only requires a maternal blood sample, unlike invasive procedures such as amniocentesis, CVS, and cordocentesis, which carry varying risks of miscarriage due to their invasive nature.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Prenatal diagnosis

Reference: Arias’ practical guide to high risk delivery 4th edition, Page no. 9-11

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for a patient with prolonged latent phase of labor?
questions.solution:
Option C: Provide hydration and rest

Providing hydration and rest is the most appropriate initial management for prolonged latent phase of labor. Ensuring adequate hydration and rest can help alleviate maternal fatigue, reduce stress, and potentially facilitate the progression of labor. It is a conservative and non-invasive approach that allows for the latent phase to naturally transition into the active phase.

Option A: Administer intravenous oxytocin

While oxytocin is commonly used to augment labor in cases of labor dystocia, it is not the first-line management for a prolonged latent phase of labor. The latent phase can often be managed conservatively with rest and hydration, allowing the cervix to continue effacing and dilating. Oxytocin may be considered later if active labor does not progress after initial conservative measures.

Option B: Perform immediate cesarean section

Immediate cesarean section is not appropriate as an initial management step for a prolonged latent phase of labor. Cesarean delivery is typically reserved for cases of failed induction, fetal distress, or other obstetric complications. The latent phase can often be prolonged without indicating immediate surgical intervention, especially if the mother and fetus are stable.

Option D: Apply fetal scalp electrode

Applying a fetal scalp electrode is used for internal monitoring of the fetal heart rate, typically when external monitoring is inadequate or there is a concern for fetal distress. It is not a management strategy for a prolonged latent phase of labor and does not address the progression of labor.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Management of labour

Reference: Dutta’s Obstetrics 9th edition, Page no. 463

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate 30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?
ABG - Metabolic acidosis
Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL
Blood Urea - 100 mg/dL
Creatinine - 3.4 mg/dL
Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomepizole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 583

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension. Blood pressure is around 170/86 mmHg on multiple measurements. He is prescribed amlodipine. At follow-up one month later, his blood pressure is 138/78 mmHg. But he had developed pitting lower extremity edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his edema?
questions.solution:
• Edema is a common adverse effect of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like amlodipine.
  • These drugs block calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle leading to a fall in blood pressure.
  • Peripheral edema may occur in patients with Ca2+ channel blockers but is not the result of generalized fluid retention; rather, it most likely results from increased hydrostatic pressure in the lower extremities owing to precapillary dilation and reflex postcapillary constriction
  • This raises capillary hydrostatic pressure, causing edema.

Options A, B, C : Heart failure, hypoalbuminemia, renal failure, may all cause pitting edema. None of these is likely in this patient as physical examination of this patient have no complaints other than edema.

Key takeaway:

  • Pitting lower extremity edema is a common adverse effect of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like amlodipine.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 14th edition, page no. 616

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is advised by other family members to see his physician because genetic screening has detected a disease in other family members. On physical examination, a stool sample is positive for occult blood. A colonoscopy is performed, followed by a colectomy. The figure shows the gross appearance of the mucosal surface of the colectomy specimen. Molecular analysis of this is most likely to show a mutation in which of the followinggenes?
questions.solution:
This young patient's colon shows hundreds of polyps. This is most likely a case of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome,

  • Which results from inheritance of one mutant copy of the APC tumor-suppressor gene (a few FAP cases are associated with DNA mismatch repair genes).
  • Every somatic cell of this patient most likely has one defective copy of the APC gene.
  • Polyps are formed when the second copy of the APC gene is lost in many colon epithelial cells.
  • Without treatment, colon cancers arise in 100% of these patients because of accumulation of additional mutations in one or more polyps, typically before 30 years of age.
  • Patients with the gene for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal carcinoma also have an inherited susceptibility to develop colon cancer, but in contrast to patients with FAP, they do not develop numerous polyps.

Option B & C. Sporadic colon cancers may have CpG island hypermethylation along with K-RAS mutations, while others have p53 mutations, but the somatic cells of patients with these cancers do not show abnormalities of these genes.

Option D. NOD2 mutations are linked with Crohn disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome, which results from inheritance of one mutant copy of the APC tumor-suppressor gene (a few FAP cases are associated with DNA mismatch repair genes).

Reference: Robbins And Cotran, 10th Edition, Page No. 813.

choices.text: Obstruction of the appendiceal lumen by fecalith

questions.text: What is the most common cause of acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the appendiceal lumen by fecalith is the most common cause of acute appendicitis (50-70% of cases).

Acute appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix, and it usually occurs due to obstruction of the appendix lumen. Below are the primary causes:

  1. Fecaliths (Appendicoliths):
    • Hard masses of stool block the opening of the appendix, leading to inflammation and infection.
  2. Lymphoid Hyperplasia:
    • Enlargement of lymphoid tissue within the appendix, often following a viral infection, can block the appendix lumen.
    • Common in children and young adults.
  3. Infections:
    • Bacterial or viral infections (e.g., gastrointestinal infections or respiratory infections) can trigger inflammation and swelling of the appendix.
  4. Foreign Bodies:
    • Rarely, swallowed objects such as seeds, parasites, or other foreign materials may obstruct the appendix.
  5. Tumors:
    • Appendiceal tumors, such as carcinoid or adenocarcinoma, can obstruct the appendix and cause inflammation.
  6. Parasites:
    • In some cases, parasitic infections (e.g., pinworms) can block the appendix and lead to appendicitis.

Pathophysiology:

Obstruction leads to bacterial overgrowth, increased pressure within the appendix, reduced blood supply, and eventually, inflammation, infection, and potential rupture if not treated.

B. Infection with E. coli and other bacteria can contribute to appendicitis, but is not the primary cause.

Autoimmune response (C) and trauma (D) are rare causes of appendicitis

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Acute appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix, and it usually occurs due to obstruction of the appendix lumen

Reference: Robbins And Cotran, 10th Edition, Page No. 819.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of anorexia, nausea and vomiting, and abdominal discomfort. He also had pain on motion and stiffness in several joints. The man, recently diagnosed with renal tuberculosis, started a four-drug combination regimen 1 month ago. Lab results showed serum aspartate aminotransferase of 280 U/L and serum uric acid of 25 mg /dL. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient symptoms and signs?
questions.solution:
• The gastrointestinal symptoms and the high aminotransferase levels (which suggest some liver dysfunction), together with the joint pain and hyperuricemia, strongly indicate that pyrazinamide is the drug that caused these adverse effects.
  • Hepatotoxicity is the major limiting adverse effect of pyrazinamide, is dose-related, and is far less common today with current dosing regimens.
  • Arthralgia is also common and dose-related.
  • Hyperuricemia is seen in more than 50% of patients taking the drug and is likely due to inhibition of uric acid secretion.

Option A: Rifampin is also hepatotoxic and may cause skin rash, flu like syndrome and anemia. Hepatotoxicity due to rifampicin is uncommon without pre-existing liver disease. It presents as hyperbilirubinemia

Option C: Isoniazid causes peripheral neuritis. It is also hepatotoxic and can cause hemolysis in G-6 PD deficient patients.

Option D: Streptomycin is not hepatotoxic.

Key Takeaway

  • Hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia are the major limiting adverse effect of pyrazinamide

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 819

questions.text: At which stage of the demographic transition model is population growth expected to stabilize?
questions.solution:
The demographic cycle, also known as the demographic transition, describes the historical and ongoing shifts in population trends observed in societies as they progress through economic and social development. The cycle typically consists of four stages, although some models include a fifth stage.

STAGE:4 -Low Birth Rate and Low Death Rate; hence the population is stable.


KEY TAKEAWAYS- The demographic cycle (or demographic transition) refers to the sequence of stages a country passes through from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as it develops economically and socially

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. park,27th Edition, Chapter -08, Page no.556-558

questions.text: Which of the following is not a manifestation of hyperparathyroidism in CKD?
questions.solution:
• Hyperparathyroidism in CKD stimulates bone turnover and leads to conditions like osteitis fibrosa cystica and brown tumors, causing significant bone pain and fragility.
  • PTH is classified as a uremic toxin, with elevated levels linked to various complications, including muscle weakness and fibrosis of cardiac muscle.

Manifestations of Hypoparathyroid state in CKD include:

  • Adynamic bone disease characterized by reduced bone volume and mineralization and may result from excessive suppression of PTH production, chronic inflammation, or both
  • Complications of adynamic bone disease include an increased incidence of fracture and bone pain and an association with increased vascular and cardiac calcification. calcium will precipitate in the soft tissues into large concretions termed tumoral calcinosis.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Brown Tumour: This is a classic manifestation of severe hyperparathyroidism due to increased osteoclastic activity and bone resorption.
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica: This condition arises from prolonged high PTH levels, causing significant bone remodeling and damage.
  • All of the above: Since A and B are correct manifestations of hyperparathyroidism, this option is incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hyperparathyroidism in CKD causes significant bone turnover, leading to osteitis fibrosa cystica and brown tumors.
  • Tumoral calcinosis is linked to adynamic bone disease, where low PTH levels result in soft tissue calcium deposition, not elevated PTH levels.

Topic: Chronic kidney disease

Type: Must Know

Difficulty: High

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2313

choices.text: Daughter cysts forming within the mother cyst
Detached endocyst floating within the cyst
Perforation of the cyst into the biliary tree

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant pain and is suspected to have a liver hydatid cyst. On imaging, a "water lily sign" is observed. What does this sign represent in hydatid disease?
questions.solution:
Hydatid Disease

  • Caused by infection with the Echinococcus granulosus
  • The liver is the most common site, but other organs may also be involved.

Waterlily Sign:

  • Seen on imaging in hydatid cyst (echinococcosis).
  • Caused by the detachment of the endocyst (inner membrane), which floats in the cyst's fluid, creating a layered appearance similar to waterlily petals.


Option A. Calcified cyst wall: Incorrect. Calcification of the cyst wall may occur in chronic hydatid disease, but it is not associated with the "waterlily sign."

Option B. Daughter cysts forming within the mother cyst: Incorrect. While daughter cysts are characteristic of hydatid disease, they are not responsible for the "waterlily sign."

Option C. Detached endocyst floating within the cyst: Correct. The "waterlily sign" refers to the appearance of the detached endocyst floating within the fluid of the cyst, resembling a waterlily. This occurs due to the rupture of the hydatid cyst's inner membrane.

Option D. Perforation of the cyst into the biliary tree: Incorrect. Cyst perforation into the biliary tree is a complication but does not produce the "waterlily sign."

Key Points:

  • The waterlily sign is a classic radiological finding in hydatid disease representing the floating detached endocyst.
  • It is an important diagnostic clue in cases of hepatic hydatid cyst.

Tags:

Topic: Hydatid Cyst

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ: FMGE AUG 2020; INICET MAY 2022; INICET NOV 2022

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 6, page no.- 77

choices.text: All of the phenomenology listed above are true for this speech sample

questions.text:
A 30 year old psychotic patient brought to the Hospital for Psychiatric Consultation. Here is speech sample of the patient.
"I have something in my mind that you know very well. My thoughts have been known by people as they hear it on radio. Whenever I thought something, my neighbors start doing the same before I act on my thoughts."
Identify the phenomenology of this patient?
questions.solution:
Speech sample- something in my mind that you know very well.

My thoughts have been known by people as they hear it on radio.

My neighbours start doing the same before I act on my thoughts.

This example shows Thought Alienation Disorder- Thought Broadcasting.

Different Thought Alienation Disorder.

  • Thought Insertion- patient knows that thoughts are being inserted into their mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from outer agency.
  • Thought Deprivation, the patient finds that as they are thinking, their thoughts suddenly disappear and are withdrawn from their mind by a foreign agency.
  • Thought Broadcasting- the patient knows that as they are thinking, everyone else is thinking in unison with them.

Bizarre Hallucination- There is no such term in Phenomenology of Psychiatry. There can be a bizarre delusion but not a bizarre hallucination.

Key Takeaways- Thought Broadcasting- the patient knows that as they are thinking, everyone else is thinking in unison with them.

Reference: Fish’s clinical Psychopathology- Signs and Symptoms in Psychiatry, 3rd edition. Page No:37

questions.text: All of them are natural derivative of this plant except?
questions.solution:
• Heroin is a semi synthetic opiate. Other semi-synthetic derivatives include
    • Oxycodone
    • Buprenorphine

Key Takeaways- Heroin is a semi synthetic opiate. Other semi-synthetic derivatives include Oxycodone, Buprenorphine

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition; Page no-1417

questions.text: A patient presented with breathlessness and dyspnoea on exertion. The treating physician ordered a pulmonary function test which turned out to be normal. Then he advised to undergo a CXR which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pericardial effusion is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space, which is the cavity surrounding the heart. This space is normally filled with a small amount of fluid that lubricates the heart and allows it to move smoothly within the chest cavity. When fluid accumulates, it can interfere with the heart's ability to function properly.

Causes:

  • Infections: Viral, bacterial, or fungal infections can lead to inflammation and fluid buildup.
  • Inflammatory diseases: Conditions like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Cancer: Tumors in the pericardium or metastasis from other cancers.
  • Kidney failure: Can lead to fluid overload.
  • Trauma: Injury to the chest can cause bleeding into the pericardial space.
  • Post-surgical: After heart surgery or procedures.
  • Idiopathic: Sometimes, the cause is unknown.

1. Chest X-ray:

  • Findings:
    • Enlarged cardiac silhouette (indicating possible effusion).
    • Possible signs of cardiomegaly (enlarged heart).
    • Indirect signs such as a "water bottle" appearance of the heart shadow.

2. Echocardiogram (Ultrasound of the Heart):

  • Findings:
    • Direct visualization of fluid in the pericardial space.
    • Signs of cardiac tamponade (pressure on the heart due to fluid accumulation) by showing diastolic collapse of the right atrium or ventricle.

3. Computed Tomography (CT) Scan:

  • Findings:
    • Detailed delineation of the fluid around the heart.
    • Assessment of associated structures and possible causes of effusion (e.g., tumors, infections).
    • Can help evaluate the extent of effusion and its impact on surrounding structures.

4. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):

  • Findings:
    • Clear visualization of fluid accumulation and its impact on heart function.
    • Can provide detailed information on the pericardial tissue and potential underlying causes.

5. Fluoroscopy:

  • Dynamic assessment of the heart’s motion and pericardial fluid.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pericardial effusion is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space, which is the cavity surrounding the heart

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 360.

questions.text: A 2-year-old patient presented with cyanosis and difficulty in feeding. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) is a congenital heart defect that presents with a combination of four specific cardiac anomalies. It is one of the most common types of cyanotic congenital heart disease, which means it causes a lack of oxygen-rich blood reaching the body, leading to a bluish tint to the skin, lips, and nails (cyanosis).

The Four Key Anomalies of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  1. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
    • Description: A hole between the two lower chambers of the heart (ventricles).
    • Impact: Allows oxygen-poor blood from the right ventricle to mix with oxygen-rich blood in the left ventricle, reducing the efficiency of oxygenated blood delivery to the body.
  2. Pulmonary Stenosis:
    • Description: Narrowing of the outflow tract from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery.
    • Impact: Obstructs blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs, leading to decreased oxygenation of blood and increased pressure in the right ventricle.
  3. Overriding Aorta:
    • Description: The aorta (the large artery that carries blood from the heart to the body) is positioned directly over the ventricular septal defect and straddles both ventricles.
    • Impact: Allows oxygen-poor blood to flow directly into the aorta from both ventricles, further reducing the amount of oxygenated blood distributed to the body.
  4. Right Ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH):
    • Description: Thickening of the muscular walls of the right ventricle.
    • Impact: Results from increased pressure that the right ventricle has to work against due to pulmonary stenosis, affecting its function and efficiency.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

The findings on chest Xray in Tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:

  • Boot-shaped Heart: Due to right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) and upturned cardiac apex.
  • Reduced Pulmonary Vascular Markings: Often due to decreased blood flow to the lungs.
  • Cardiomegaly: Enlargement of the heart may be observed.

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 304.

questions.text: Which ultrasound finding is most commonly associated with Down syndrome in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Option A: Increased nuchal translucency

Increased nuchal translucency (NT) is the most common and earliest ultrasound finding associated with Down syndrome in the first trimester. NT is a fluid-filled space at the back of the fetal neck, and measurements greater than the normal range for gestational age are strongly associated with chromosomal abnormalities, particularly trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). It is a highly sensitive marker for Down syndrome when measured between 11 to 14 weeks of gestation.

Option B: Absence of nasal bone

Absence or hypoplasia of the nasal bone is another ultrasound marker for Down syndrome, often identified in the first trimester. However, it is less commonly seen than increased nuchal translucency. The absence of the nasal bone can increase the risk assessment for Down syndrome but is not as sensitive as increased NT.

Option C: Short femur length

Short femur length is more commonly associated with Down syndrome in the second trimester rather than the first. It is considered a soft marker for chromosomal abnormalities, but it is not a primary finding in the first trimester ultrasound.

Option D: Echogenic bowel

Echogenic bowel, where the fetal bowel appears as bright as bone on ultrasound, is also more typically seen in the second trimester and is a less specific marker for Down syndrome. It can be associated with various conditions, including chromosomal abnormalities, cystic fibrosis, and intrauterine infections, but it is not a common first trimester finding for Down syndrome.

Type: Must know

Topic: Prenatal diagnosis

Reference: Arias’ practical guide to high risk delivery 4th edition, Page no. 2

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the clinic with elevated blood pressure readings of 160/100 mmHg, significant proteinuria, and mild edema. She reports headaches and visual disturbances. Her laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, low platelet count, and normal renal function tests. The obstetrician suspects preeclampsia. Which renal lesion is most characteristic of the condition suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option a: Glomerular endotheliosis

Glomerular endotheliosis is the hallmark renal lesion in preeclampsia. It is characterized by swelling of the glomerular endothelial cells, narrowing of the capillary lumen, and loss of endothelial fenestrations, leading to impaired glomerular filtration and proteinuria. This lesion is specific to preeclampsia and reflects the endothelial dysfunction central to the pathophysiology of the disorder.

Option b: Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis, are specific to diabetic nephropathy and are characterized by nodular accumulations of extracellular matrix in the glomeruli. These lesions are not associated with preeclampsia and do not appear in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.

Option c: Interstitial nephritis

Interstitial nephritis involves inflammation of the renal interstitium and is commonly due to drug reactions, infections, or autoimmune conditions. It is not a characteristic lesion of preeclampsia and does not contribute to the renal pathology seen in this condition.

Option d: Swan neck deformity of PCT

Swan neck deformities are structural changes associated with reflux nephropathy and certain types of chronic kidney disease. They are not seen in preeclampsia and are unrelated to the endothelial damage that defines glomerular endotheliosis in preeclamptic patients.

Type: Must know

Topic: Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy

Reference: Dutta’s Obstetrics 9th edition, Page no. 258

choices.text: Severe Aortic regurgitation with aortic stenosis

questions.text: Austin Flint murmur is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
• Austin Flint Murmur Characteristics:
    • A soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur.
    • Caused by the diastolic displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve due to the regurgitant flow from aortic regurgitation (AR).
    • Not associated with hemodynamically significant mitral valve obstruction.
  • Conditions Associated:
    • Chronic Aortic Regurgitation: Commonly associated with Austin Flint murmur due to prolonged volume overload leading to changes in the mitral valve dynamics.
    • Acute Aortic Regurgitation: Does not typically produce this murmur; presents with more acute and severe symptoms without the chronic adaptations seen in severe chronic AR.
    • Aortic Stenosis with AR: Although both conditions may coexist, the murmur is specifically indicative of chronic AR.
    • Mitral Regurgitation: Austin Flint murmur is not related to this condition.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A (Severe acute AR): Incorrect; acute AR does not produce Austin Flint murmur.
  • Option B (Severe AR with aortic stenosis): Incorrect; this murmur is specific to chronic AR.
  • Option D (Severe mitral regurgitation): Incorrect; the murmur is not associated with mitral regurgitation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Austin Flint murmur is indicative of severe chronic aortic regurgitation, arising from altered mitral valve dynamics due to diastolic displacement.
  • Recognizing the distinguishing features of acute vs. chronic AR is essential for accurate diagnosis and management.

Topic: Valvular heart disease Clinical findings in acute vs chronic AR

Type: Must know

Difficulty: High

Reference: Harrison's principles of medicine 21st edition page no-1985

questions.text: Faget sign is?
questions.solution:
• For every 1°C (1.8°F) increase in core temperature, the heart rate typically rises by 15–20 beats/min. Infections that are associated with relative bradycardia (Faget’s sign), where patients have a lower heart rate than might be expected for a given body temperature. Although this pulse–temperature dissociation is not highly sensitive or specific for establishing a diagnosis, it is potentially useful in low-resource settings given its ready availability and simplicity.

Infections associated with relative bradycardia:

  • Salmonella typhi, Francisella tularensis Brucella spp.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) Leptospira interrogans Legionella pneumophila Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Tick borne organisms
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus) Babesia spp.
  • Other
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae Plasmodium spp. (malaria)
  • Viruses/viral infections
  • Yellow fever virus Dengue virus
  • Viral hemorrhagic feversa Viral myocarditis

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 943

questions.text: Pyoderma or impetigo is a superficial infection of skin caused by?
questions.solution:
• Impetigo, a superficial infection of the skin, is caused primarily by GAS and occasionally by other streptococci or Staphylococcus aureus.
  • The usual sites of involvement are the face (particularly around the nose and mouth) and the legs, although lesions may occur at other locations.
  • Lesions generally are not painful, and patients do not appear ill. Fever is not a feature of impetigo and, if present, suggests either infection extending to deeper tissues or another diagnosis.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 1192

questions.text: A 55 years old female patient was operated case of right modified radical mastectomy for CA breast before 02 days. Drain was kept under the flap and axilla. Output was 100 mL / day . Drains retained in the wound until drainage diminishes to less than ________ per day.
questions.solution:
Catheters are retained in the wound until drainage diminishes to <30 mL per day.

Seromas beneath the skin flaps or in the axilla represent the most frequent complication of mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection, reportedly occurring in as many as 30% of cases.

The use of closed-system suction drainage reduces the incidence of this complication.

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery; 11th edition; chapter 17 ; page 593.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low grade fever, headache and nasal congestion. He has a flushed face and has developed lacy reticular rash on the trunk and external surface of his arms and legs. Palms and soles are spared. His mother has been ill with low grade fever and joint stiffness and pain. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Scarlet fever is an upper respiratory tract infection associated with a characteristic rash, which is caused by an infection with pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin)–producing GAS in individuals who do not have antitoxin antibodies.
  • The rash appears within 24-48 hour after onset of symptoms, although it may appear with the first signs of illness. It often begins around the neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. The rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption producing bright red discoloration of the skin, which blanches on pressure. It is often accentuated in the creases of the elbows, axillae, and groin. The skin has a goose-pimple appearance and feels rough. The cheeks are often erythematous with pallor around the mouth. After 3-4 days, the rash begins to fade and is followed by desquamation, initially on the face, progressing downward, and often resembling a mild sunburn. Occasionally, sheet-like desquamation may occur around the free margins of the fingernails, the palms, and the soles.
  • The pharynx is red, the tonsils are enlarged and often covered with a white, grayish, or yellow exudate that may be blood-tinged. There may be petechiae or "doughnut" lesions on the soft palate and posterior pharynx and the uvula may be red and swollen.
  • In addition, the tongue is usually coated and the papillae are swollen. After desquamation, the reddened papillae are prominent, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.
  • Typical scarlet fever is not difficult to diagnose; the milder form with equivocal pharyngeal findings can be confused with viral exanthems, Kawasaki disease, and drug eruptions. Staphylococcal infections are occasionally associated with a scarlatiniform rash.
  • A history of recent exposure to a GAS infection is helpful, as evidenced here by sick mother with joint pain and fever. Identification of GAS in the pharynx confirms the diagnosis.
  • Rubella rashes and Roseola infantum rashes develops 3 days after fever onset.

Mnemonic for Day of appearance of rash in a febrile patient is

  • Very Sick Person Must Take Double Tablets
  • Very - Varicella (day 1)
  • Sick - Scarlet fever (day 2)
  • Person - Pox-small pox (day 3)
  • Must - Measles (day 4)
  • Take - Typhus (day 5)
  • Double - Dengue (day 6)
  • Tablets - Typhoid (day 7)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, pg. 1441

questions.text: In cataract surgery, which of the following steps primarily involves the manipulation of viscoelastic substances and is critical for maintaining anterior chamber stability?
questions.solution:
• Option a) Making the corneal incision: This step involves creating an opening in the cornea, typically using a surgical blade or laser, to access the anterior chamber, but it does not specifically involve the use of viscoelastic substances for anterior chamber stability.
  • Option b) Performing capsulorrhexis: This step involves creating a controlled tear in the anterior capsule of the lens. It is crucial for exposing the lens material for phacoemulsification and typically involves the use of viscoelastic substances to maintain the stability of the anterior chamber and prevent collapse during the procedure.
  • Option c) Conducting phacoemulsification: This step uses ultrasound waves to fragment the lens material and does not primarily involve the manipulation of viscoelastic substances.
  • Option d) Implanting the intraocular lens (IOL): This step involves placing the artificial lens into the eye. While viscoelastic substances may be used to assist in IOL placement, the primary use of viscoelastic substances is during the capsulorrhexis to maintain anterior chamber stability.

Reference: Kanski, J.J., Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Chapter on Cataract Surgery, pp. 150-155.

choices.text: The window period is the time during which HIV tests are less likely to detect HIV infection due to the body not yet producing detectable antibodies or viral antigens.
The window period refers to the time immediately after HIV infection when patients are highly infectious but do not show any symptoms.
The window period is the time when patients on antiretroviral therapy are most likely to experience side effects.
The window period is the duration between the initial HIV infection and the development of AIDS.

questions.text: In the context of HIV/AIDS epidemiology, which of the following is true about the "window period"?
questions.solution:
The window period in HIV refers to the time between a person's exposure to the virus and when a test can accurately detect HIV infection.

During this period, the person may be infected with HIV but may test negative because their immune system hasn't produced enough antibodies, or the viral load isn't high enough to be detected by the test.

Types of HIV Tests and Window Periods:

  • Nucleic Acid Tests (NAT): Detect HIV RNA directly. They have the shortest window period of 10–33 days.
  • Antigen/Antibody Tests (4th generation): Detect the p24 antigen and HIV antibodies. They can usually detect HIV within 18-45 days.
  • Antibody Tests (3rd generation): Detect antibodies produced by the immune system against HIV, with a window period of 23-90 days.

A) The window period is the time during which HIV tests are less likely to detect HIV infection due to the body not yet producing detectable antibodies or viral antigens. - Correct. The window period is the gap between HIV infection and the time when current tests can reliably detect the infection.

B) The window period refers to the time immediately after HIV infection when patients are highly infectious but do not show any symptoms. - Incorrect. This statement describes a period of high viral load but does not accurately define the window period in testing.

C) The window period is the time when patients on antiretroviral therapy are most likely to experience side effects. - Incorrect. This refers to the time of treatment side effects, not the window period of HIV testing.

D) The window period is the duration between the initial HIV infection and the development of AIDS. - Incorrect. This period describes the progression of HIV to AIDS, not the window period for detection.

Key Takeaway: The window period is crucial for understanding the limitations of HIV testing and emphasizes the need for follow-up testing if recent exposure is suspected.

The window period for HIV varies based on the type of test used, typically ranging from 2 weeks to 3 months. During this time, individuals can still transmit the virus even if their test result is negative. Therefore, follow-up testing is essential for accurate diagnosis.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). HIV Testing. CDC HIV Testing

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for viral DNA
Serum antibody testing for Shigella species

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child is admitted to the hospital with a history of abdominal cramps, fever, and frequent bloody diarrhoea over the past two days. The child's parents mention that the child recently returned from a trip to a region with poor sanitation. Upon physical examination, the child appears dehydrated and lethargic. The laboratory results show the presence of white blood cells and red blood cells in the stool. The healthcare provider suspects an infectious etiology.
Based on the clinical presentation and the epidemiological history, which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of Shigella infection?
questions.solution:
Shigella is gram rod, non-lactose fermenter, oxidase, and can invade the GI tract via M cells of Peyer patches.

Symptoms: Sudden onset of watery diarrhoea that may progress to bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, tenesmus (painful straining to pass stool), and fever.

Stool Examination:

  • Microscopy: The presence of leukocytes (pus cells) and erythrocytes (red blood cells) in stool indicates invasive diarrhoea, suggesting dysentery.
  • Culture: Stool culture is the gold standard for diagnosing Shigella. It helps in identifying the specific serogroup and determining antibiotic susceptibility.
    • Common serogroups: Shigella dysenteriae, Shigella flexneri, Shigella boydii, and Shigella sonnei.

A) Stool culture for bacterial pathogens: Correct. Stool culture is the gold standard for diagnosing Shigella infection. It allows for the isolation and identification of Shigella species from the stool samples. Given the clinical presentation of bloody diarrhoea and recent travel to a region with poor sanitation, stool culture is the most appropriate test for confirming Shigella.

B) Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for viral DNA: Incorrect. While PCR is useful for detecting various pathogens, including viruses, Shigella is a bacterial pathogen. PCR for viral DNA would not be appropriate for diagnosing a bacterial infection such as Shigella.

C) Serum antibody testing for Shigella species: Incorrect. While serological tests for antibodies against Shigella might be available, stool culture is preferred for the direct detection of the pathogen in cases of acute diarrheoa. Serological tests are less commonly used in routine diagnosis of Shigella infections.

D) Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for rotavirus: Incorrect. EIA for rotavirus is used to detect rotavirus, a common cause of viral gastroenteritis, not Shigella. Given the clinical symptoms and history, EIA for rotavirus would not confirm Shigella infection.

Key Takeaway: Stool culture is the definitive diagnostic test for Shigella infection and should be performed to confirm the diagnosis in cases of suspected bacterial gastroenteritis.

Accurate diagnosis is essential to avoid complications such as dehydration, hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), and toxic megacolon.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Shigella. CDC Shigella

questions.text: A 09-month-old presented with swelling of leg. Above image shows presence of fracture of bowed femur, thin bones. Blue Sclera is present. Past history suggestive of multiple fractures in various bones in healing stage. Which is among the best suitable for this condition?

  • Option a) In the Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a group of connective tissue disorders that involve impaired integrity of supporting structures, defects in the genes that encode α collagen-1, procollagen N-peptidase, or lysyl hydroxylase result in mobile joints and skin abnormalities.

Genes or enzyme affected in Osteogenesis Imperfecta is COL1A1 /COL1A2 .


Option B) Vitamin C is required for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases. The consequent deficit in the number of Hydroxyproline and Hydroxy lysine residues undermine the conformational stability of collagen fibers, leading to bleeding gums, swelling joints, poor wound healing.

Option D) Vitamin D Deficiency is commonest cause of developing Rickets in children, Bones of Children are under mineralized due to poor absorption of Calcium. Bow Leg, Rachitic Rosary and Harrison sulcus are symptoms and signs present in Rickets.

choices.text: Increased blood flow in large epicardial vessels

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman recently diagnosed with variant angina started treatment with Isosorbide mononitrate and diltiazem. Which amongst the following actions most likely mediates the therapeutic effect of nitrates in the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Nitrates dilate large epicardial vessels, thus increasing epicardial blood flow.

This action is the most important for the therapeutic effect of these drugs in variant angina, which is characterized by coronary spasm.

Mechanism of relief of angina

  • Variant angina

The relaxant effect on larger coronary vessels is the principal action of nitrates benefiting variant angina by counteracting coronary spasm.

  • Classical angina

The primary effect is to reduce cardiac work by action on peripheral vasculature, though increased blood supply to ischaemic area may contribute.


Mechanism of action of nitrates in classical angina - ↓ Preload

Mechanism of action of nitrates in variant angina → Dilation of coronary arteries

Option A: By causing venous dilation, nitrates can cause a decrease, not an increase, of left ventricular end-diastolic volume.

Option C: Nitrates can cause reflex tachycardia and reflex increase in cardiac contractility, but these are detrimental, not therapeutic, effects in patients with angina.

Option D: Nitrates can decrease diastolic perfusion time (as a consequence

of reflex tachycardia), but this is a detrimental effect in patients with angina.

Key Takeaway

  • Nitrates dilate large epicardial vessels, thus increasing epicardial blood flow. This action is the most important for the therapeutic effect of these drugs in variant angina, which is characterized by coronary spasm.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 586

questions.text: Which of the following strains of Escherichia coli is commonly associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs)?
questions.solution:
• Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC): Incorrect - Commonly causes traveler's diarrhea due to enterotoxins, but is not linked to urinary tract infections.
  • Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC): Incorrect - Responsible for gastrointestinal diseases, especially hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS), not involved in UTIs.
  • Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC): Incorrect- Causes dysentery-like symptoms similar to Shigella infections, with no significant role in urinary tract infections.
  • Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC): Correct- UPEC is the primary strain involved in community and hospital-acquired UTIs. It possesses virulence factors like adhesins (P-fimbriae), hemolysin, and toxins, which allow it to colonize and invade the urinary tract.

Why Not Others:

  • ETEC: Causes traveler's diarrhea, not associated with the urinary tract.
  • EHEC: Causes hemorrhagic colitis due to Shiga toxin, unrelated to UTIs.
  • EIEC: Invades intestinal cells causing dysentery, not linked to urinary infections.

Key Takeaway:
Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) is the leading cause of UTIs due to its ability to adhere to and invade the urinary tract, facilitated by specialized virulence factors.

Tags: Inicet 2021

Tag Line: EASY

Reference: Shastri, A. (2021). Essentials of Medical Microbiology (3rd ed.). Publisher. Chapter-76, pp: 745.

choices.text: Gram-positive bacilli with terminal round spores

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the appearance of Clostridium tetani under the microscope?
questions.solution:
• A. Gram-negative cocci with terminal spores:
    • Incorrect: C. tetani is gram-positive and rod-shaped (bacilli), not cocci.
    • Gram-negative organisms do not retain the crystal violet stain used in the Gram staining procedure.
  • B. Gram-positive bacilli with terminal round spores:
    • Correct: C. tetani appears as gram-positive rods with terminal round spores, resembling a "drumstick" shape.
    • This unique morphology is crucial for laboratory identification of the bacterium.
  • C. Gram-positive cocci with central spores:
    • Incorrect: Misclassifies C. tetani as cocci and incorrectly states the spores are central rather than terminal.
    • Central spores are characteristic of other organisms like Bacillus anthracis.
  • D. Gram-negative bacilli with subterminal spores:
    • Incorrect: C. tetani is gram-positive and has terminal spores, not subterminal.
    • Misidentifying it as gram-negative misrepresents its true characteristics.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Incorrect classification of C. tetani as gram-negative and cocci.
  • C: Incorrect shape and placement of spores (cocci instead of bacilli, central instead of terminal).
  • D: Incorrectly categorizes C. tetani as gram-negative and suggests subterminal spores, which it does not have.

Key Takeaway:

Clostridium tetani is identified as gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria with terminal round spores, essential for its classification and diagnosis in clinical microbiology. This distinctive morphology aids in recognizing the organism responsible for tetanus.

Tags: Fmge 2021

Tag Line: Easy

Reference: Shastri, A. (2021). Essentials of Medical Microbiology(3rd ed.). Publisher. Chapter-72 Tetanus, pp: 702-704.

questions.text: Kupffer cells play a key role in:
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver. Below are key points about them:

  1. Location: Found lining the sinusoids of the liver.
  2. Function: Act as phagocytes, engulfing and digesting bacteria, cellular debris, and toxins from the blood.
  3. Role in Immune Response: First line of defence in the liver's immune system, removing pathogens and worn-out cells.
  4. Endocytosis: Efficient at clearing circulating antigens and immune complexes from the bloodstream.
  5. Iron Metabolism: Help in recycling iron from old red blood cells.
  6. Cytokine Production: Secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines, which play a role in liver inflammation and systemic immune responses.
  7. Origin: Derived from bone marrow monocytes and settled in the liver during early development.

Incorrect Options:

D. Kupffer cells are important in the immune response to viral infections, such as hepatitis B and C.

A. Lipid metabolism is primarily carried out by hepatocytes.

B. Iron homeostasis is regulated by hepatocytes and macrophages in the spleen.

C. Detoxification of xenobiotics is primarily carried out by hepatocytes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Kupffer cells are important in the immune response to viral infections, such as hepatitis B and C.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 825.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with Alzheimer disease dies of pneumonia. The gross appearance of the right kidney at autopsy is shown in the figure. The left kidney is normal in size, with a smooth cortical surface and a single 0.6-cm, fluid-filled cyst. The appearance of the right kidney is most suggestive of renal injury from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The ureteral, pelvic, and calyceal dilation results from long-standing obstruction leading to hydroureter and hydronephrosis.

Ureteral obstruction can cause hydronephrosis and hydroureter because it prevents urine from flowing properly in the urinary tract:

  • Hydronephrosis

This condition occurs when the renal pelvis and calyces swell due to urine building up in the kidneys. It can be caused by a number of things, including kidney stones, tumors, and blood clots.

  • Hydroureter

This condition occurs when the ureter dilates. It can be caused by a urethral valve obstruction, or by prolonged preservation of the ureteric membrane.

Ureteral obstruction can have serious consequences, including:

  • Permanent kidney damage: If left untreated, kidney damage can become permanent and difficult to reverse.
  • Renal failure: Long-standing hydronephrosis can lead to renal failure.
  • Urinary tract infections: Urinary stasis from a blockage can increase the risk of infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: With benign nephrosclerosis, the kidneys become smaller and develop granular surfaces, but there is no dilation.

Option C & D: The scarring that accompanies analgesic nephropathy or chronic pyelonephritis can be marked; it is associated with significant loss of renal parenchyma, but not with pelvic dilation.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 946.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cardiovascular anomaly seen in infants born to mothers with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Most common congenital heart defect seen in infants of mothers with Diabetes Mellitus: Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Most specific congenital heart defect seen in infants of mothers with Diabetes Mellitus: Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

Option A: Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common cardiovascular anomaly associated with gestational diabetes.. Maternal diabetes, including gestational diabetes, is known to increase the risk of various congenital heart defects, with VSD being notably prevalent among these anomalies.

Option B: Coarctation of the aorta

While it is a significant cardiovascular anomaly, it is not the most common defect seen in infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes. This condition is less frequently associated with gestational diabetes compared to VSD.

Option C: Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Although ASDs are congenital heart defects that can occur in infants of mothers with gestational diabetes, they are not as commonly associated with gestational diabetes as VSD.

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

While PDA can occur in infants of diabetic mothers, it is not the most common cardiovascular anomaly associated with gestational diabetes compared to VSD.

Type: Must know

Topic: Congenital anomalies in Infants of Diabetic Mothers (IDM)

Reference: Aria's practical guide to high risk delivery 4th edition, Page no: 260

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia has been on Anti-Psychotic medication since last 10 days and landed up in casualty with complaints of High-Grade Fever, rigidity, brown colored urine and tachycardia. What can be the suspected diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Patient is known case of Schizophrenia- On anti-psychotic medication for 10 days.

Presented with complaints of

  • High Grade Fever
  • Rigidity
  • Brown colored Urine (Myoglobinuria)
  • Tachycardia

Suggestive of anti-psychotic induced Movement disorder- Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome


Clinical Features

  • Life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during the course of antipsychotic
  • The motor and behavioral symptoms include muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agitation.
  • The autonomic symptoms include hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.
  • Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatinine phosphokinase, liver enzymes, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria, occasionally associated with renal failure.

Option A: Akathisia- subjective feelings of restlessness, objective signs of restlessness, or both. Examples include a sense of anxiety, inability to relax, jitteriness, pacing, rocking motions while sitting, and rapid alternation of sitting and standing.

Option D: Acute Dystonia- are brief or prolonged contractions of muscles that result in obviously abnormal movements or postures, including oculogyric crises, tongue protrusion, trismus, torticollis, laryngeal-pharyngeal dystonia, and dystonic postures of the limbs and trunk.


KEY TAKEAWAYS: A patient on antipsychotics for schizophrenia -Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome Life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during the course of antipsychotic treatment.

The motor and behavioral symptoms include muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agitation.

The autonomic symptoms include hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.

Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatinine phosphokinase, liver enzymes, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria, occasionally associated with renal failure.

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, page no: 1961-1963
