questions.text: Select true statement about Cheiralgia paresthetica:
questions.solution:
Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenberg Syndrome)

  • Definition:
    • Compressive neuropathy of the Superficial Branch of the Radial Nerve (SBRN)(Option A)
  • Cause:
    • Nerve compression occurs between the brachioradialis and Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus (ECRL) with forearm pronation.
    • Compression results from a scissor-like action between the tendons.
  • Presentation:
    • Symptoms include pain, numbness, and paresthesias over the dorsoradial hand.
    • Difficulty wearing a watch or jewellery due to pain over the nerve.
  • Provocative Tests:
    • Forceful forearm pronation for 60 seconds.
    • Tinel test.
  • Nonoperative Treatment:
    • Activity modification.
    • Splinting.
    • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
  • Surgical Decompression:
    • Considered if a 6-month trial of nonoperative treatment fails.

Option B: Compressive neuropathy of median nerve is called carpal tunnel syndrome.

Option C: Compressive neuropathy of lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is called meralgia paresthetica.

Option D: Compressive neuropathy of ulnar digital nerve is called bowler's thumb

questions.text:
What constitutes effective CPR?
A. RR: 20-24/min
B. Chest compression: 100-120/min
C. Allow chest recoil
D. 5-6 cm compression
questions.solution:
High-quality CPR performance include:

  • Chest compression fraction >80%
  • Compression rate of 100-120/min, push hard and fast.
  • Allowing proper recoil time for the chest
  • Compression depth of at least 50 mm (2 inches) in adults and at least 1/3 the AP dimension of the chest in infants and children
  • 30:2 compression: ventilation ratio
  • No excessive ventilation

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no: 3201

Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines

questions.text: You are seeing a newborn of 39 weeks gestation born via normal vaginal delivery to a mother who had no prenatal care. APGAR scores are 7 and 9. At four hours of life, the nurse noted respiratory distress. On physical examination, her heart rate is 150 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 70 cycles per minute, temperature is 98F with barrel-shaped chest, a scaphoid-appearing abdomen, and absence of breath sounds on the left chest. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The girl has findings that are suspicious for congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a developmental defect of the diaphragm that allows abdominal viscera to herniate into the chest.
  • Although routine prenatal ultrasound screening may identify CDH at a mean gestational age of 24 weeks, there is a wide range of reported sensitivity in its detection.
  • Physical findings include a barrel-shaped chest, a scaphoid-appearing abdomen (because of loss of the abdominal contents into the chest), and absence of breath sounds on the ipsilateral side.
  • No evidence of meconium passage during perinatal period, MAS ruled out.
  • Baby is full term, hence RDS ruled out.
  • Congenital lobar emphysema is a very rare disorder characterized by respiratory distress. But findings of scaphoid abdomen are absent.

Reference: Avery's diseases of the newborn, 1st SA ed, pg: 772

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary vector for the transmission of Wuchereria bancrofti, the most common cause of lymphatic filariasis?
questions.solution:
• Aedes mosquitoes (option A) are primarily vectors for diseases like dengue and Zika virus, and are not associated with the transmission of Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • Anopheles mosquitoes (option B) are well-known as vectors for malaria, making them irrelevant for lymphatic filariasis.
  • Culex mosquitoes (option C) are the primary vectors for Wuchereria bancrofti, transmitting the parasite that causes lymphatic filariasis, making this option correct.
  • Tsetse flies (option D) are responsible for transmitting trypanosomiasis(sleeping sickness), and do not play a role in filariasis transmission.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Incorrect. Aedes mosquitoes transmit dengue and Zika, not lymphatic filariasis.
  • B) Incorrect. Anopheles mosquitoes are exclusive vectors for malaria, not for Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • D) Incorrect. Tsetse flies are not involved in filariasis transmission but are linked to trypanosomiasis.

Key Takeaway: Wuchereria bancrofti is a major cause of lymphatic filariasis and is primarily transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, highlighting the importance of controlling these mosquito populations to reduce disease transmission.

Tags: neet 2021

Reference: Paniker, CK Jayaram. Paniker's textbook of medical parasitology. JP Medical Ltd, 2017.Chapter-20: Filarial worms, pp: 208

questions.text: Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to?
questions.solution:
Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing.

When the distance between the firing and the victim is between 30-50 cm (in the case of pistols and revolvers), it is a near-shot wound. The victim is within the range of powder deposition, so there is some amount of tattooing present. But it is outside the range of flame, so there will not be any burning or singeing. There will not be any blackening, as it is outside the range of smoke as well.

The injuries related to firearms are:

  • Burn injuries: Occur due to flame released during the firing. It is seen in contact shot wounds or distances up to 5-8 cm. Singeing of hair is caused due to burns.
  • Blackening: Occurs due to the deposit of smoke. It can be removed with a wet cloth. This can be seen up to around 15 cm of firing.
  • Tattooing: Occurs due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing.
  • Greasing and collaring: Occur due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues, during its penetration. It can be found in contact, near-shot, or distant shot wounds.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 210

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient is progressing towards the heart failure. Blood pressure is 90/48. Ejection fraction is only 25%. The patient was given intravenous digitalis group of drug digoxin. The drug helps via which of the following effect.
questions.solution:
• The drug digoxin (digitalis group) is derived from common foxglove plant known as Digitalis purpurea.

Mechanism of action - Direct inhibition of Na+/K+-ATPase causes indirect inhibition of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, this increases intracellular Ca2+ leads to ↑ positive inotropy. Stimulates. vagus nerve ↓↓ HR.


Clinical use - Heart failure and atrial fibrillation

Adverse effects - arrythmia (ventricular bigeminy) , AV block yellow vision , hyperkalemia

Antidote - for digoxin toxicity DIGIBIND (Fab fragments)

  • Option b: due to positive inotropic effect of digoxin, It improves left ventricular emptying and decreases the ventricular filling pressure.
  • Option c: Digoxin decreases the AV nodal conduction velocity thus delaying AV transmission to the ventricles.
  • Digitalis reduces the number of impulses transmitted through the AV node and thus, provides effective rate control in atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male has a brainstem injury. On examination doctor found respiratory rate is 9 per minute. On spirometry it is found that his inspiratory volume is about 650 ml/ breath. Which respiratory center is likely to be inhibited in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: The pneumotaxic center, located in the pons, plays a crucial role in regulating the rate and pattern of breathing.


  • It inhibits the apneustic center and helps to limit the duration of inspiration, thereby promoting normal breathing patterns and a normal respiratory rate.
  • Damage to the pneumatoxic center can result in excitation of apneustic center cause deep and slow respiration.

Option b: The apneustic center, also located in the pons, is involved in promoting deep, prolonged inspirations by stimulating the dorsal respiratory group. Its inhibition increases the rate but decreases the depth of respiration.

Option c: Dorsal respiratory group- mainly causes normal respiration. Normal inspiration is an active process while normal expiration is passive process.

Option d: Ventral respiratory group- It functions in both inspiration and expiration. Totally inactive during normal quiet breathing. It operates during overdrive

References: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed, page no: 531-532

choices.text: Reduced oxidative stress in red blood cells
Increased phagocytosis of infected red blood cells
Impaired parasite growth due to decreased NADPH availability
Enhanced immune response to malaria parasites

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which G6PD deficiency provides protection against malaria?
questions.solution:
G6PD deficiency reduces the amount of NADPH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate) in red blood cells, which is a critical cofactor for the parasite's antioxidant defenses.

  • With less NADPH, the parasite is more susceptible to oxidative stress, making it harder for it to survive and replicate within the red blood cell.
  • This reduced oxidative stress environment makes it more difficult for the malaria parasite to thrive, providing partial protection against malaria.

Incorrect Options:

A. Reduced oxidative stress provides partial protection against malaria

B. Phagocytosis is an important immune response, it's not the primary mechanism by which G6PD deficiency provides protection against malaria.

D. G6PD deficiency doesn't directly enhance the immune response to malaria parasites.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: NADPH is important for the parasite's growth, the primary mechanism of protection is related to reduced oxidative stress.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 640.

choices.text: CBNAAT can detect only Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex but not drug resistance
The test provides results within 48-72 hours

questions.text: 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinician suspects pulmonary tuberculosis and decides to use a rapid molecular diagnostic test. Which of the following statements about the CBNAAT (GeneXpert) is TRUE?
questions.solution:
• CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test), commonly known as GeneXpert, is a rapid molecular test used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB). It detects the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA and can simultaneously identify resistance to rifampicin, which is a key first-line anti-TB drug.
  • The test is automated, providing results in about 2 hours.
  • CBNAAT detects mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance.

Indications for CBNAAT Testing:

  1. Pulmonary TB: Sputum or other respiratory samples (e.g., bronchoalveolar lavage) are tested for TB diagnosis, especially in suspected MDR-TB cases.
  2. Extrapulmonary TB: CSF (for TB meningitis), pleural fluid, lymph node biopsy, ascitic fluid, etc., can be tested for diagnosing TB in extrapulmonary sites.
  3. HIV Co-infected Patients: CBNAAT is highly recommended for TB diagnosis in HIV-positive patients, as they often have paucibacillary TB (low bacterial load) and are at higher risk for MDR-TB.
  4. Pediatric TB: The test is useful in children who often present with smear-negative TB or extrapulmonary TB, as it offers a non-invasive diagnostic tool using gastric lavage or induced sputum samples.

A) CBNAAT can detect only Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex but not drug resistance.- Incorrect. CBNAAT (GeneXpert) not only detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis but also identifies resistance to rifampicin, which is a key feature of multidrug-resistant TB.

B) The test provides results within 48-72 hours.- Incorrect. One of the advantages of CBNAAT is its rapid turnaround time. It usually provides results within 2 hours, making it much quicker than 48-72 hours.

C) CBNAAT detects both Mycobacterium tuberculosis and its resistance to rifampicin.- Correct. The CBNAAT (GeneXpert) is designed to detect the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and also identifies resistance to rifampicin, a critical drug used in the treatment of TB.

D) CBNAAT requires sputum samples that are decontaminated and concentrated before testing.- Incorrect. CBNAAT does not require prior decontamination or concentration of sputum samples. The test uses a cartridge system that directly processes the sputum sample for molecular testing.

Key Takeaway: CBNAAT (GeneXpert) is a rapid diagnostic tool for tuberculosis that detects both the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and resistance to rifampicin, providing results in approximately 2 hours.

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO). Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT) for Tuberculosis. WHO CBNAAT

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Poxvirus is recognized as the largest DNA virus. It belongs to the Poxviridae family and is notable for its complex and large brick-shaped structure. The genome of Poxviruses is linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), which can be as large as 200-300 kilobase pairs, making it significantly larger than other DNA viruses. The Poxvirus family includes viruses that cause diseases such as smallpox and cowpox.


Other DNA viruses mentioned:

  • Adenovirus: Medium-sized DNA virus, known for causing respiratory infections and conjunctivitis.
  • Herpesvirus: A family of large DNA viruses that include herpes simplex, varicella-zoster (causes chickenpox), and Epstein-Barr virus, but not as large as Poxvirus.
  • Parvovirus: The smallest DNA virus, with a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genome. It is known for causing fifth disease in children.

Key Takeaway:
Poxvirus is the largest DNA virus, distinguished by its size and complex structure. Understanding the size and structure of viruses helps in identifying their capabilities and the diseases they may cause.

Note: parvovirus is the smallest DNA virus

Tags: fmge 2020

CDC Reference:
CDC - Smallpox Overview

questions.text: Following is an image of a patient who has refractive error. Identify the refractive error.

There is axial shortening of eyeball

questions.text: Identify the disease due to disorder of Pyrimidine Metabolism
questions.solution:
• In Pyrimidine catabolism, Enzymes required is Orotate Phosphoribosyl Transferase for conversion of Orotic Acid into OMP.
  • Disorder related to Pyrimidine catabolism; enzyme deficiency leads to overproduction of Orotic Acid which excretes in urine.
  • The Orotic Aciduria that accompanies the Reye Syndrome probably is a consequence of the inability of severely damaged mitochondria to utilize carbamoyl Phosphate, which then becomes available for cytosolic overproduction of Orotic Acid.
  • Type 1 Orotic Aciduria reflects a deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and OMP decarboxylase.
  • The rarer Type II orotic Aciduria is due to deficiency of OMP decarboxylase.

Option A): SCID - is Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disease. It is due to Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Option B): Lesch Nyhan Syndrome: It is overproduction of hyperuricemia characterized by frequent episodes of uric acid lithiasis reflects a defect in Hypoxanthine Guanine phosphoribosyl Transferase as enzyme of Purine Salvage Pathway.

Option D): Hunter Syndrome is example of Mucopolysaccharidoses. It is Type II MPS. Enzyme Iduronate Sulfatase is defective and GAG - Dermatan Sulfate and Heparin Sulfate are affected. Symptom includes Mental Retardation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a noticeably enlarged, red, and bulbous nose. The patient has a long-standing history of facial redness and acne-like eruptions. On examination, the nasal skin shows thickening and a prominent, irregular appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rhinophyma is a subtype of rosacea characterized by thickening of the nasal skin, leading to a bulbous and irregular appearance. It typically occurs in patients with a long history of rosacea, particularly those with significant facial redness and acne-like eruptions.it is due to sebaceous gland hypertrophy

Option A: Acne vulgaris typically affects adolescents and young adults and presents with comedones, papules, and pustules, rather than the thickened, bulbous nasal appearance seen in rhinophyma.

Option C & D: Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma are types of skin cancer that might present with nodules or irregular lesions, but they do not typically cause the characteristic thickening and bulbous appearance associated with rhinophyma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with pigmentation over neck and axilla. He was obese and was a known case of diabetes. Patient was chronic alcoholic. Skin lesions were asymptomatic. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D - Acanthosis nigricans

Acanthosis nigricans is characterized by hyperpigmented, velvety patches of skin, often found in body folds such as the neck and axilla.

It is strongly associated with insulin resistance, obesity, and diabetes, which matches the patient's profile.

The asymptomatic nature of the lesions and their location further supports this diagnosis.

Option A - Intertrigo

Intertrigo is an inflammatory condition that occurs in skin folds where there is friction, moisture, and warmth. It typically presents with erythema and irritation rather than pigmentation. It usually affects areas such as the groin, under the breasts, and other skin folds. Since the patient's lesions are asymptomatic and specifically pigmented, intertrigo is less likely.

Option B - Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation

Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation occurs after an inflammatory process or skin injury, resulting in increased pigmentation in the affected area. It generally follows a history of inflammation, trauma, or irritation, which is not described in this case.

Option C - Deficiency dermatitis

Deficiency dermatitis, usually presents with specific skin symptoms such as rash or inflammation rather than just pigmentation. In niacin deficiency there will be eczematized skin over photo exposed parts of the body

Tag: Acanthosis nigricans

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 64.3.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing infertility treatment. The physician advised to undergo a HSG examination which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Uterine anomalies are congenital malformations of the uterus that arise from abnormal development of the Müllerian ducts during embryogenesis. These anomalies can affect the size, shape, and structure of the uterus and are often associated with reproductive issues, such as infertility, recurrent pregnancy loss, and complications during pregnancy.

Classification of Uterine Anomalies:

The American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) classifies uterine anomalies into several categories based on the type of developmental defect:

  1. Arcuate Uterus: Mild indentation of the uterine fundus, typically with minimal reproductive impact.
  2. Septate Uterus: A fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity, increasing risk of miscarriage
  3. Bicornuate Uterus: Two uterine horns due to incomplete fusion, linked to miscarriage and preterm labor.
  4. Unicornuate Uterus: A single, underdeveloped uterine horn, associated with miscarriage and ectopic pregnancy.
  5. Didelphys Uterus: Two separate uterine cavities with two cervix , often causing reproductive complications.
  6. Agenesis/Hypoplasia: Absence or underdevelopment of the uterus, typically leading to infertility and amenorrhea.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Bicornuate Uterus: Two uterine horns due to incomplete fusion, linked to miscarriage and preterm labor.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 1862

questions.text: A patient presented with claudication of limbs. He had a history of chronic smoking and tobacco eating. The physician ordered an investigation which is shown below. Identify the investigation being done.
questions.solution:
CT Angiography (CTA) is a specialized imaging technique used to visualize blood vessels and evaluate blood flow within the body. It combines computed tomography (CT) with contrast agents to provide detailed, cross-sectional images of the vascular system.

Purpose:

  • Assessment of Blood Vessels: Evaluates arteries and veins for abnormalities such as aneurysms, stenosis, dissections, and blockages.
  • Pre-surgical Planning: Provides detailed vascular mapping to aid in the planning of surgical or interventional procedures.
  • Diagnosis of Vascular Diseases: Helps diagnose conditions like pulmonary embolism, coronary artery disease, and peripheral artery disease.

Indications:

  • Detection of Aneurysms: Identifies abnormal dilations or bulges in blood vessels.
  • Evaluation of Arterial Stenosis or Occlusion: Detects narrowing or blockage in arteries.
  • Assessment of Trauma: Evaluates vascular injuries resulting from trauma or accidents.
  • Pulmonary Embolism: Diagnoses blood clots in the lungs by visualizing the pulmonary arteries.
  • Coronary Artery Disease: Assesses the coronary arteries for blockages or other abnormalities.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: CT Angiography (CTA) is a specialized imaging technique used to visualize blood vessels and evaluate blood flow within the body

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 2049.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and bleeding per rectum. On doing a blood test, the Hb levels were found to be low. He was admitted for further investigations. On doing a CT scan, a mass lesion was found near the descending colon. There was a suspicion of malignancy and underwent a PET-CT. Which metabolite is used in PET-CT?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG (Fluorodeoxyglucose) is a radiopharmaceutical used in positron emission tomography (PET) imaging to assess metabolic activity in tissues. It is particularly valuable in diagnosing and monitoring various conditions, including cancer, infections, and inflammatory diseases.

How 18F-FDG Works:

  • Radiopharmaceutical: 18F-FDG is a glucose analog labeled with the radioactive isotope fluorine-18.
  • Metabolic Uptake: Cells that are highly active metabolically, such as cancer cells or inflamed tissues, uptake more glucose compared to normal cells. 18F-FDG is taken up in a similar manner to glucose, allowing imaging of these areas.
  • Positron Emission: Fluorine-18 emits positrons as it decays. When these positrons interact with electrons in the body, they produce gamma rays, which are detected by the PET scanner to create images.

Applications:

  1. Cancer Diagnosis and Staging:
    • Detection of Tumors: Identifies tumors based on their increased glucose metabolism.
    • Staging: Assesses the extent of cancer spread (metastasis).
    • Monitoring Response: Evaluates how well a tumor is responding to treatment.
  2. Assessment of Infections and Inflammation:
    • Infection Detection: Locates areas of infection by identifying regions with high metabolic activity due to inflammatory responses.
    • Inflammatory Diseases: Helps in diagnosing and assessing diseases characterized by inflammation, such as sarcoidosis or vasculitis.
  3. Evaluation of Neurological Conditions:
    • Brain Imaging: Assists in the evaluation of brain function and detecting abnormalities in neurological conditions like epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, and other dementias.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: 18F-FDG (Fluorodeoxyglucose) is a radiopharmaceutical used in positron emission tomography (PET) imaging to assess metabolic activity in tissues. It is particularly valuable in diagnosing and monitoring various conditions, including cancer, infections, and inflammatory diseases.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 1643.

questions.text: Modified Mallampati grading is used to evaluate:
questions.solution:
Modified Mallampati grading is a classification system used to predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation based on the visualization of the oral cavity and the extent to which the base of the tongue obstructs the view of the larynx.It assesses the structures within the oral cavity, including the soft palate, uvula, fauces, and visibility of the tonsillar pillars. A higher Mallampati grade indicates a more difficult intubation, with Grade 1 being the easiest and Grade 4 being the most challenging.

Reference: Miller's Anaesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1379.

questions.text:
A 44 year individual sustained a road traffic accident and was diagnosed to have Maisonneuve fracture in left lower limb. Choose the possible outcomes of this particular injury from given options.
1. Fibula neck fracture is usually missed
2. Medial malleolus fracture united well conservatively
3. May result in CPN injury and foot drop
4. Needs surgical intervention
questions.solution:
Maisonneuve fracture - It is a type of ankle fracture in which fracture of the neck of the fibula occurs.

Statement 1 - As the pain is usually in the ankle region the fracture of fibula neck is usually missed

Statement 3 - CPN palsy and foot drop post fibula neck fracture is a common and known complication

Statement 2 - Medial malleolus does not get fractured in Maisonneuve fracture

Statement 4 - It can be treated conservatively with above knee cast

Maisonneuve Injury

  • Definition:
    • High-energy leg injury involving fibular fracture and syndesmotic ligament damage.
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • Twisting or rotational force applied to the leg.
    • Common in sports or accidents.
  • Key Components:
    • Fibular Fracture: Typically proximal (near the knee).
    • Syndesmotic Injury: Damage to the ligament connecting tibia and fibula.
    • Associated Injuries: May include ankle fractures or dislocations.
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe lower leg pain.
    • Swelling and bruising.
    • Difficulty bearing weight.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination.
    • X-rays for bone fractures and alignment.
    • MRI or CT scan for soft tissue and syndesmotic injury.
  • Treatment:
    • Nonoperative: Rest, immobilization, physical therapy if stable.
    • Operative: Surgery for realignment and stabilization if severe.
  • Prognosis:
    • Generally good with appropriate treatment; rehabilitation is key for recovery.

Reference: Koval's Handbook of fractures' 5th edition, page no. 442

questions.text: A 33 year individual sustained injury to right arm while driving 2 wheeler. Xray showed lower third humerus shaft fracture. He also has wrist drop and EMG-NCV shows findings consistent with neuroma in continuity. Classify the nerve injury according to Sunderland classification.
questions.solution:
Radial nerve injury is a common complication in distal third humeral shaft fractures. The notorious fractures are known as Holstien-Lewis fractures.

There are 2 classification systems for nerve injuries.

  • Seddon's classification divides them in 3 categories namely neuropraxia, axonotmesis and neurotmesis.
  • Sunderland classification further divides axonotmesis type injury into further three categories making 5 categories in total as shown in the table.

Neuroma in continuity - If the endoneural tube is interrupted, the sprouts, as many as 100 from one axonal stump, may migrate aimlessly throughout the damaged area into the epineural, perineural or adjacent tissues to form an end-neuroma or a neuroma in continuity. An end-neuroma may form when the proximal-end is widely separated from the distal-end. A side neuroma usually indicates a partial nerve cut.

Reference: Miller's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1532

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic factor in GTN according to the FIGO scoring system?
questions.solution:
Older age is considered a poor prognostic factor in GTN, influencing treatment response and overall outcome.

Option A: Age over 40 years

According to the FIGO scoring system for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN), age over 40 years is considered a poor prognostic factor. Advanced maternal age can be associated with a more aggressive disease course and a higher likelihood of poor outcomes. The FIGO system incorporates age as a factor when assessing the overall prognosis and treatment strategy for GTN.

Option B: Low serum hCG levels

Low serum hCG levels are generally associated with a better prognosis in GTN. Lower levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are indicative of a less aggressive form of the disease and a more favourable response to treatment. High hCG levels, on the other hand, are associated with poorer prognostic outcomes.

Option C: Metastasis confined to the pelvis

Metastasis confined to the pelvis is considered a favourable prognostic factor in the FIGO scoring system. Limited or localized metastasis indicates that the disease is less widespread and generally more amenable to treatment compared to widespread metastasis.

Option D: Molar pregnancy as antecedent pregnancy

Molar pregnancy as the antecedent pregnancy is associated with a better prognosis. GTN following a molar pregnancy, especially a hydatidiform mole, typically responds well to chemotherapy. In contrast, GTN following a term pregnancy, abortion, or ectopic pregnancy is associated with poorer outcomes and higher scores in the FIGO system.

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of father's death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby is not their son's. DNA is positive. The child is called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posthumous child:

  • A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one or both parents. In this case, since the child was born after the father's death but is confirmed by DNA to be the biological child of the deceased father, the correct term is "posthumous child."

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Suppositious child:
    A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely claimed to be the legitimate child of a deceased person, but this term is not commonly used in modern legal or medical contexts. It does not apply to the situation described.
  • Option B - Fabricated child:
    A fabricated child is not a standard term used in legal or medical contexts. It suggests falsification but is not relevant in the context of a child's legitimacy or paternity.
  • Option D - Illegitimate child:
    An illegitimate child is one born out of wedlock. However, since the issue in this case is related to the timing of birth relative to the father's death rather than marital status, "illegitimate child" is not the most accurate term here.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- A posthumous child is born after the death of one or both parents.

REFERENCE: - The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 396

questions.solution:
• Metabolic Disorder mentioned in above case summary is Alkaptonuria. Finding of Black Pigments in intervertebral Discs, changes of Urine color - black & metabolic cause with enzyme deficiency is suggestive of Homogentisate Oxidase defect which catalyze the Homogentisate to Methylacetoacetate.

questions.text: Which of the following is strongest binding factor for hemoglobin?
questions.solution:
• Above all molecules can bind to hemoglobin with varying affinity.
  • Option A) Carbon monoxide:
    • Carbon monoxide has the highest binding affinity for hemoglobin among the options listed.
    • Hemoglobin binds to CO approximately 200-250 times more strongly than it binds to oxygen.
    • When CO binds to hemoglobin, it effectively reduces the ability of hemoglobin to bind and release oxygen because it stabilizes hemoglobin in a form that is less likely to release oxygen to tissues.
  • Option B) Carbon dioxide:
    • Carbon dioxide binds to hemoglobin, but not as strongly as carbon monoxide.
    • CO2 binds to the amino groups in hemoglobin, forming carbaminohemoglobin. This binding affects hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen through the Bohr effect.
  • Option C) Oxygen: Binding is not as strong as CO.
    • Oxygen binds to hemoglobin at the heme sites. The binding of one oxygen molecule increases the affinity of hemoglobin for additional oxygen molecules due to cooperative binding.
  • Option D) H+: Hydrogen ions bind to hemoglobin but with less strength.
    • Importance- Increased H+ concentration (lower pH) decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release in tissues where it is needed.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.1491

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with breathlessness during physical exertion. Upon examination, the doctor diagnoses her with circulatory hypoxia. Which physiological mechanism would enhance oxygen release from hemoglobin in response to stagnant hypoxia?
questions.solution:
• Here if we look at the O2-Hb dissociation curve increase in PH, decrease in CO2, decreased in temperature are the causes for this curve to shift to left.
  • Increase in BPG shift the Hb-O2 dissociation curve to right.
  • If hypoxia is more than few hours BPG level increases considerably. It causes curve shift to right. This shift causes O2 to be released to the tissues at as much as 10 mm Hg higher tissue O2 pressure than would be the case without this increased BPG.
  • In some conditions especially stagnant hypoxia this mechanism is very helpful to adapt.

References: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed page no. 526

questions.text: A 42-year-old female is presented to the doctor with a complaint of weakness in the lower extremities, waddling gait. Repetitive stimulation of the motor nerve facilitates accumulation of Ca2+ in the nerve terminal and increases acetylcholine release, leading to an increase in muscle strength. Probable diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution:
• Eaton lambert syndrome and myasthenia gravis are immune disorders which involves muscle contraction leading to weakness.
  • In myasthenia gravis weakness usually appears on facial muscles and then gradually progress down.
  • In lambert eaton syndrome Repetitive stimulation of the motor nerve facilitates accumulation of Ca2+ in the nerve terminal and increases acetylcholine release, leading to an increase in muscle strength. It is opposite to myasthenia gravis. Similar feature like this syndrome is seen with the use of aminoglycosides (Amikacin)
  • Grave's disease and Hashimoto's thyroiditis are immune disorders involving thyroid gland.
  • Prednisolone is a drug useful in autoimmune disorder. It does not cause autoimmune disorder.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 328
